urn:contentItem:5Y2F-WRG1-JCMN-Y20Y-00000-00Broadcom inks new $15 billion deal with Apple to supply wireless chips through mid-20232020-01-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:25ZLexisNexisBroadcom inks new $15 billion deal with Apple to supply wireless chips through mid-2023Adrian Potoroaca

Jan 25, 2020( TechSpot: http://www.techspot.com Delivered by Newstex) Recap: When it's not busy trying to acquire Qualcomm for the exorbitant sum of $117 billion, Broadcom is forging new deals with big tech giants like Apple for essential components. The latest was spotted in a recent SEC filing and shows the two companies reached a new multi-year agreement that sent Broadcom's shares up two percent in after-hours trading. Broadcom's tech is slowly eating the world[1], even as many of us are unaware of its presence in many of our favorite gadgets.

The company's reach is so powerful that it has US and EU regulators probing every aspect of its business to make sure it doesn't abuse its dominance in key semiconductor markets. Recently, the silicon giant revealed in an SEC filing[2] spotted by the Wall Street Journal that it has signed a new agreement with Apple for "the supply of a range of specified high-performance wireless components and modules." The company already has a deal inked in 2019 for "RF components and modules" which are used in iPhones and iPads, making up about $10 of the bill of materials if you go by JP Morgan's estimates[3].This could mean that Broadcom could rake in no less than $15 billion in revenue over the next three and a half years, which is a big win for the company.It's no secret that Apple is one of Broadcom's largest customers, accounting for somewhere between 20 to 25 percent of its net revenue over the last two years. Back in December, the rumor mill was abuzz with reports[4] that Broadcom was exploring a potential sale of its RF division for around $10 billion.Given Apple's appetite for strategic acquisitions that give it more control over key components that go into its products, it wouldn't be surprising to see it snapping Broadcom's RF unit. The only deal-breaker might be the asking price, as Apple only paid $1 billion for Intel's modem division in a deal latter described by one of the parts as grossly undervalued[5]. urn:contentItem:5WG8-R3D1-JBYT-H3FM-00000-00Broadcom's tech is slowly eating the world2019-07-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:24ZLexisNexisBroadcom's tech is slowly eating the worldJuly 02

July 02 -- The European Commission has recently opened an antitrust investigation into Broadcom, one of the largest players in the semiconductor industry, amid concerns that it has been using exclusivity deals in order to corner the competition.


The investigation is focused on the company's chipsets found in many modems and TV set-top boxes, and there is a proposal for an interim ban on the alleged contractual restrictions in order "to avoid any risk of serious and irreparable harm to competition."
Broadcom is also under fire by the US Federal Trade Commission, whose investigation is similar in scope, citing abusive practices in the sale of chipsets found in Wi-Fi and Ethernet chips. All of this came into focus as the company tried their luck at a hostile takeover of Qualcomm for over $100 billion, which was recently shot down by Trump's executive order. But that didn't stop it from shelling out $18.9 billion for CA Technologies, a software and services company that helps it expand its reach to corporate customers.
The company naturally disagrees with the allegations, but the antitrust battle could bubble up in the E.U., and while Broadcom told regulators it doesn't expect any material impact from the interim ban, the Commission can hit it with fines of up to 10% of its global revenues - or something around $2 billion, which are already suffering from the Huawei ban.
It's easy to look at this and dismiss it as yet another battle between regulators and big tech that will take years to get to a conclusion. Most people don't know that Broadcom's chips are inside almost every gadget you might have, powering internet connectivity in everything from phones to laptops, routers, and IoT devices such as the Raspberry Pi 4.
The effects of the investigations could affect both manufacturers and consumers.

Corporate Participants

* Timothy C. Gokey

Broadridge Financial Solutions, Inc. - COO and Corporate SVP

Conference Call Participants

* Jason Gurandiano

Presentation

JASON GURANDIANO: (technical difficulty) attending this session. This is a session I've been looking forward to all day, which is the opportunity to speak with a senior leader of Broadridge.

Just to introduce myself, I'm Jason Gurandiano. I run the fintech franchise here at RBC and have been doing fintech for over 20 years, which means I'm one of the few people who might actually have done it almost as long as Vince Roux, who's the Head of Corporate Development at Broadridge. So I don't know what it says about Vince and I, but we have roles. So that's definitely one conclusion you can draw.

When I think through the evolution of the fintech landscape, I've been amazed at some companies that had been there early and haven't evolved and some companies who -- and this is meant to be praise, by the way, before I go there, who started off with a legacy footprint and have evolved at a pace that exceeded who you've might have thought as being a market leader previously. So my hats off to Broadridge. And most impressive, I think, in your case has been the combination of both organic initiatives, the ability to see where the puck is going, because we are a Canadian bank, as well as inorganic initiatives and in deploying capital in a smart fashion.

And so I can't give you a better lead off than that, so I'm going to ask you to introduce yourself and then we'll go from there.

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY, COO AND CORPORATE SVP, BROADRIDGE FINANCIAL SOLUTIONS, INC.: Thank you very much. So Tim Gokey. I am the Chief Operating Officer of Broadridge, which means the business units report to me. I've been with Broadridge for 7 years. Prior to that, I was the President of the tax business at H&R Block, and prior to that, I was with McKinsey & Company in financial services for about 15 years.

JASON GURANDIANO: Thank you.

Questions and Answers

JASON GURANDIANO: So I think before we sort of delve into the meat of the conversation, I think Broadridge, as I mentioned, is a name that's been around for a long period of time. What I would like to impose upon you to do is sort of give an overview of the businesses because I think there is -- there's a perception and truth, and sometimes, those often don't match up. And so if I can impose upon you to sort of walk through the portfolio of businesses that comprise the Broadridge platform today and then we could talk about some of the specific dynamics as it applies to those.

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: Absolutely. And just -- actually, going back to your introduction, so I said I've been with Broadridge 7 years. When I came here is really because I was thinking about the next phase of my career, and I looked at the company and the market positions and the assets that Broadridge had. I thought it was a fantastic growth platform, and that's definitely proved to be true over time. So let me just take a minute to talk about the company. We are a global fintech leader. We have about $4 billion in revenue, market cap just under $9 billion and a couple of major business franchise. And I'll come back and talk about those in a bit more detail, but really significant positions in a couple of areas that are attractive, large markets that are growing. We are -- our whole theme is around creating sustainable long-term growth for the company, really by investing in trends that we believe are aligned with financial services industry around mutualization, digitization, data and analytics. We'll come back and talk about those in more detail as well. We've really been investing behind organic growth, more sales to our existing and new clients, more products, mostly organic, but inorganic also. And we really -- the focus of our company is around what we call a service profit chain, which is really engaged associates delivering great outcomes for clients and that leading to very good long-term outcomes for shareholders. And so from a shareholder perspective, we think about delivering upper single-digit recurring fee revenue growth, leading to some operating leverage, low double-digit earnings growth, pay a dividend, do some share buybacks, be able to deliver sustainable low teens total returns to shareholders over long periods with low volatility NOI growth.

JASON GURANDIANO: At scale, too.

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: If we could all do that, yes, that would be a great day.

JASON GURANDIANO: That's good. That's pretty good.

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: All of that is predicated really on the core businesses, and there are -- we have 2 major reporting segments: Investor Communications, Global Technology and Operations. On the Communications side, the core of that business is a business that our CEO founded almost 30 years ago in regulatory communications. And the core activities there are working with broker-dealers to help them send to all of their clients the communications that all public companies and fund companies need to get to their clients around proxies, prospectuses, annual statements. And so it's a fairly boring set of stuff, and we are basically at the stage to become an industry utility for doing that. But because of that activity, we end up with a relationship with nearly every broker dealer, with a service relationship with every fund company, a service relationship with every public company, with every -- and investor, and we end up with every position of every investor in the U.S. and Canada in our data. And so that -- and we don't do anything with that, which we'll come back to as an opportunity, but that gives...

JASON GURANDIANO: Which begs the questions.

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: Yes. It gives us a really privileged position in terms of working with those firms in terms of kinds of solutions that they need and how we can help them with other things. And so in that communications business, we built a series of other businesses around that. Customer Communications, where we're doing statements, confirmations, bills, a range of things and now that's beginning to go outside of financial services, serving advisers, serving companies on tax. So a range of things that are really providing a lot of organic growth, serving the fund industry. So those all really made that Communications business be a nice growth engine for us. That's the largest part of the company. The other side is Global Technology and Operations, and in that business, we provide technology platforms on a software-as-a-service basis, largely in cash securities, largely to the sell side, mostly back and middle office. We have 18 of 23 U.S. primary dealers are at our fixed income platform, 6 of the top 10 largest global institutions are on our equities platforms. And so we have a pretty ubiquitous position there in capital markets and wealth management as well. And because of the needs and trends around those firms looking at next-generation operations, that's provided a nice growth platform for us as well.

JASON GURANDIANO: So the -- ubiquitous is the term I was going to used, so you stole that term from me before I could use it. But given the footprint that you have and the points of connectivity that you have across-the-board and sort of touching third-party ecosystem, one of the constant concerns that you hear out there as it relates to either the financial institutions themselves or the technology providers, instead of financial institutions, is step function changes in the way people either receive, understand, consume communication. And you alluded to the communication part of your business and then, obviously, the technology piece. How do you think of the electronification of those dynamics and how that plays into Broadridge's wheelhouse, given that -- if you own all the points of contact, I imagine they kind of got to go through you somehow.

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: Yes. No, it's a great question, and digitization has been one of the key things that we have been investing in. We view it as a -- obviously, one of the mega trends and a real potential opportunity for us. So we have been investing, really, for a long time in what I would call traditional digitization, and that's basically working on e-delivery. And we have the incentive structure that's been created between ourselves, our clients, their clients and the regulator to such that we're incented to do that and we save the industry, literally, billions now in the evolution from paper to digital delivery. And so at this stage on the regulatory side, just under half of the communications are digitized. At the same time, today's digital experience for delivery communications is terrible. You get an email, it has a link, you click on the link, it takes you to a website, you enter a password, if you can remember it, and you try to do that across all of your accounts and it's just -- it's not a good experience. So we believe, in the future, there's going to be a very different paradigm, that the important digital communications that people receive, they're really going to want to have a place to go, and it'll be different for different people, that's secure where, really, with one log on, they're able to get all the different things that they need. And we're not sure when or exactly how that's going to happen, but what we do know is it's very complicated for mailers, because if you don't exactly know where that's going to be and have to integrate with all these places, it's pretty expensive and concerning. So we're building, basically, the hub to have everyone integrate with us, and we can integrate with all those points of output and help the mailers within our platform project their brand into those points of communication. Starting with all the cloud drives, we're integrated to all of the cloud suites. We think that's a big channel. Online banking is an interesting channel. We're working with a lot of the big tech players as well. And we think that is something that over time will really change the way communications take place, and we think it'd be a good opportunity for us over time.

JASON GURANDIANO: No, understood. Understood, yes. So when you think about electronification, I think the next natural sort of segue is into -- as we talked about the way people consume data, it's being felt in a way that people actually invest their money, right? So we've seen this massive trend and movement away from the active portfolio to the passive portfolio, which has disrupted various parts of the ecosystem on the asset management side. How do you think about the impact of that type of behavior and how it applies to the prospects for Broadridge going forward? There's various terms, the uberification of financial services, whatever tag line that I'm not smart enough to invent - that you could apply there.

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: As we think about the shift from active to passive and sort of the broader commoditization of asset management, we would say it's probably a mild positive for us, given how we're positioned. But let me just go in a bit deeper into that as to why. Think about the different sides of the business. On the Investor Communication side, really, the driver of the activity that we do on behalf of the industry is positions. So whether someone is in an active fund or a passive fund or in a mutual fund or an ETF or an underlying stock, it creates a position or a managed account, in which case it creates a lot of positions. And so even as we've seen a significant shift from active to passive, the number of positions has continued to go up and that has continued to drive modest, modest growth for us. The other side of the ledger is on the technology platform side. There, you can think about the wealth managers we serve and how their business model is evolving. I think they are finding new ways to make money. I think they're really focused on how they serve clients and sort of in the life events and things like that. So I think they'll be fine out of this. Then the other side is really asset management industry, and the asset management industry over the next 10 years will be going through all the pain that the sell side is going through the past 10 years. And that really causes people to rethink their business model, to rethink how can they take cost out of the ecosystem that naturally leads to conversations with technology players like ourselves in terms of how we can help them reengineer what they're doing to reduce costs. So we think, over time, that could be a positive for us.

JASON GURANDIANO: And I think that's a very important point to sort of focus on. This -- there's this cost intention that exist within fintech between the financial institution's desire to own the stack. We have to own it. It's ours. There's a lot of reasons why versus the realities of the world and the way the world's progressing and, frankly, cost controls and more tempered top lines. How do you sort of see that battle playing out, the in-source versus the outsource? Do you think you're kind of further along that? The value proposition is now so clear to your various counterparties that you're starting to pluck a way at sort of that nexus of costs that still remains in-sourced within these institutions. Or is there still more game to be played there?

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: I think it's always slower than you want it to be because of the cost of change in transition. But I think more than in any time in the past -- and this really gets of the whole theme of mutualization. And if you think -- at root, what Broadridge does is look for non-differentiating activities, hopefully, ones that are sort of yucky and at a big pain for our institution, for our clients and ones where no single institution can really invest enough to do it right. And if we can take over that activity and do it on behalf of multiple institutions, then we can put the right technology behind it, put the right process behind it. We can do it better. We can deliver them a better end product at much lower cost and still make a nice return for our shareholders. And so that's sort of thematically. I think because of the agencies of the global financial crisis, more firms have created a much sharper focus on what's truly differentiating for them. And so they're much more focused on putting their investment dollars on client experience, front end kinds of things and really saying there's a lot of stuff that truly -- they might have argued in the past were differentiating, but is really not. And so that has actually opened up a lot of territory for us.

JASON GURANDIANO: And is the dialogue that you're having is it you're identifying that spot where there's a pain point? Or do you have sort of a proactive outreach of institution that's saying "I just -- I can't do this anymore, can you help me?"

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: It is both. First of all, clearly, we have a lot of existing solutions where there -- for some reason, there's a client that inexplicably has not chosen -- not to do it with us yet. So there's always those conversations.

JASON GURANDIANO: So the ignorants, yes.

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: And -- but when you think about new solutions, there are -- there's one we're working on right now that I won't go into because we're working on it, but this is in the wealth management where there's a -- basically, new regulation is going to cause a bunch of new reporting requirements. All of our wealth management clients have the same challenge. They're not exactly sure how they're going to solve it. And multiple, or independently, have come to us and said, "Broadridge, could you figure out how to solve that for us?" And those are the conversations we love to have.

JASON GURANDIANO: So let's take a step back away from sort of the Broadridge-centric, and let's take more of an industry perspective. When you sort of step back and think through -- whether it's securities or the capital markets technology stack or securities processing, obviously, there is the prospect of disruption of some sort. Blockchain is the one area that seems to be gaining further and further momentum. We see real investment dollars flow in, both from the VC world, but probably more importantly for you, from the financial institutions that look at this as being something there. They don't know quite what it is, but it's something. And so how has that sort of -- how are you thinking about -- the evolution of that? How do you ensure that you are sort of -- remain the tip of the spear as it relates to being the service provider and thought leader with your client base?

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: Yes. It's a great point. We are -- there's clearly something there.

JASON GURANDIANO: It's clear as I have no other way but to be great. Eloquent of me, right? Something's not good.

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: And the question is what and when. But what we really say to our clients is we believe we can be the on-ramp for you to take advantage of whatever that is. When you think about blockchain and how it evolves, the biggest cost of all of that is not going to be creating that core thing that's blockchain, but integrating all the systems that exist in the client onto that thing and so if -- for clients that are part of our platform, that's going to all sort of come with it. So to make that happen, we are investing in lots of different ways. We are -- we're core investor in Digital Asset Holdings, so one of the startups that we talked to -- we talked to all the startups. We have a -- we made some investments. We bought some technology from a company called Inveshare in the proxy space that we think will help us. We have a core team that is working on -- alongside clients, typically, on a series of use cases where we think there's the most promise in the areas that really touch the ecosystem where we're the logical players. So for instance, we just did a proof-of-concept with JPMorgan and Northern Trust and Santander in global proxy. We are working with TTCC in repos. So with 6 different use cases going and really by becoming knowledgeable, working on Hyperledger, on Ethereum, on Quorum, all the different technologies, have those covered, doing use cases on each of those. That's the way we think we'll be in the best position to help our clients figure out how to best leverage those technologies in the areas that are relevant for us.

JASON GURANDIANO: Understood. So sticking with some of the macro dynamics, we've been blessed with a relatively strong equity markets for pretty close to a decade. One of the questions that does come up when you talk about the broader fintech ecosystem, especially an enterprise that is somewhat levered to the capital markets and the velocity of the capital markets, how do you think about the prospects of either a downturn or correction? What are some of the sort of the levers that a company, such as yourself, can pull to sort of insulate yourself from the esoteric factors -- the external factors that have a direct bearing on either your company itself or your underlying client base?

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: Yes. It's -- I think we have to assume that there will be a significant downturn sometime in the next few years. We -- by the nature of what we do, we're fairly resilient to that. No one is immune to it. But when you think about -- so let's say -- think about the Communications piece. The biggest part of that business, the driver of our revenues, again, is positions. Positions -- when people are happier, they do invest in more stuff. And when they're less happy, they invest in less stuff. But it's pretty, pretty slow. So in the midst of the global financial crisis, if you look at stock record growth, it was minus 1%. So it wasn't positive. So let's say -- it's -- in a good year, it's been as high as -- at a plus 5%, but it's not dramatically down. It just sort of stops growing. And even through the crisis, the mutual fund positions continue to grow. So the Communications business is pretty robust after that. On the Global Technology and Operations side, most of our fees are not directly responsive to trades. They're mostly more "fee-for-service." There is some leverage there. About 30% of the revenues are levered against trades, and they're -- volatility creates more trades. Lack of volatility creates fewer. So if you have a market correction, you can go either way.

JASON GURANDIANO: Okay. M&A, so it's been a tool that you've managed to wield quite effectively. Vince, I'll pick on -- Vince. He's here. He's a discriminating buyer. So he's selective in his deployment of capital. Is that something that you foresee as a continued sort of avenue to accelerate growth across the organic initiatives? And how do you think about the deployment of capital between your 2 main divisions?

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: Yes. Well, I think -- we think of M&A as a sort of a make or buy decision, and we're pretty disciplined around capital deployment generally. So I think you know, but just for everyone, we're fairly capital-light company in terms of the amount of CapEx that it takes to sustain our core business. That gives us free cash flow that is, I think, right around the same as net income, maybe a little better even sometimes. And we deploy -- we pay a dividend. We invest in our core business. Those are first 2 priorities. We have done selective tuck-in M&A, which I'll come back to, and we do share buybacks. As we said, we're pretty disciplined around that, and that's a core part of the thesis. On the M&A side, we really look at this through our clients' lens and where can we -- what do they need. We're a natural person that can add value to that. If you think about fintech, it's sort of an evergreen place for tuck-in M&A because there's always change. There always new teams going out and creating something, and they get it to $10 million, $20 million in revenue. And 10 other teams have failed to get it that far. And we can partner with those folks, and we think about this almost as recruiting, and really helping an entrepreneur to realize their vision about how to become significant in the industry. Because when you get to, say, $10 million of revenue and now you want to sell that solution to RBC, RBC is probably not going to buy it from them. But they will buy it from us. And it's not about cost. A lot of people, when they're talking about M&A is how much cost can take out of the target. In our case, it's usually there are servers in the closet some place, and we're going to put in a Tier 4 data center. And so it's how much more is it going to cost to really industrialize it and bring it to our clients in the way that they want to.

JASON GURANDIANO: Cost guys (inaudible), those are the payments guys. Let's stay away from them.

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: Exactly. So we've had -- have had good success, and we track all the returns, and I'd say our unlevered IRRs are very, very good. But more important than that is the value that it's brought to our clients. And by making that our ecosystem that much stronger, it really improves our client value proposition as well.

JASON GURANDIANO: Last question, and it's not on this page and it's not a controversial one, so this should be easy one. What are you most proud of about Broadridge? And what do you think is the one fact that you wish people understood about Broadridge but don't? So that's 2 questions actually.

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: Yes. I think the Broadridge growth for a long time was predicated on -- and with the business that our CEO, Rich Daly, built predicated on being a disruptor and really bringing something that's really new to the industry. And when that thing, the regulatory communications that has really got to scale, I think there was a period there where we have really great client relationships. We really take a very long-term view of how we work with clients. We're viewed as very fair. People like doing business with us. But we became viewed as sort of a bit of legacy company without a lot of new solutions. And so I think the thing that I'm both most proud of and that I would want -- really want people to know is how we have really changed over the past 7 years, become more of a technology company, really reengineering our core platforms, bringing in new solutions, really being much more forward-thinking in partnership with our clients to really help map out with them where the industry is going to and be able to be a better partner industry to them really -- that even than we are in the current.

JASON GURANDIANO: Understood. I'm supposed to be impartial, but I'm a big fan of Broadridge. So thank you very much for your time. It was great.

TIMOTHY C. GOKEY: Thank you.

urn:contentItem:5S45-S551-DYRW-V4MY-00000-00BROKEN FACEBOOK NEEDS TO GROW UP2018-03-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:25ZLexisNexisEXPERTISEPg. 21BROKEN FACEBOOK NEEDS TO GROW UP

Mark Zuckerberg is clearly a smart guy. He got over the decision-making challenge of what to wear by donning precisely the same style of grey T-shirt every single day.

His reasoning is simple, somewhat reassuring to his supporters and yet breathtakingly arrogant: "I really want to clear my life to make it so that I have to make as few decisions as possible about anything except how to best serve this community... I'm in this really lucky position, where I get to wake up every day and help serve more than a billion people. And I feel like I'm not doing my job if I spend any of my energy on things that are silly or frivolous about my life."

He said this in 2014 when Facebook as a company was arguably at its peak: massive growth in audience and revenue numbers, especially on mobile phones; ubiquitous; popular; a largely uncritical public and media perception; everyone clamouring to be a friend of The Zuck.

But what he said about his one-style-fits-all clothing and need to serve a grateful billion people reveals a lot about how Silicon Valley's giant companies operate, with a dangerous mixture of idealism, naivety, arrogance and leadership that borders on dictatorship. It is this that has created just the conditions for the hot water in which Facebook now find themselves, amid a swirl of allegations over the harvesting and use of personal data from its users by political consultants Cambridge Analytica - and whether it was used to influence the outcome of the US presidential election or the Brexit referendum.

Both Cambridge Analytica and Facebook deny any wrongdoing, but with the social network's share price on the slide and Zuckerberg facing calls to testify before the US Congress about how his firm will protect users, this does seem to be a moment of reckoning for the company, and a warning for the rest of the "Big Five" tech firms - Apple, Alphabet, Microsoft and Amazon. Their weaknesses have long been apparent, even if they are not always clear to all those working on the inside. I worked at Microsoft for 18 largely happy years, from 1996 to 2014, and have deep knowledge of how seemingly-brilliantly run companies can walk into the type of nightmare scenario now unfolding for Facebook from the Cambridge Analytica allegations.

Facebook's 2014 uncritical peak highlights the most dangerous moment for that handful of giant technology platform companies, who have such a massive influence on everything that happens in the western world (China has its own versions of these firms), when optimism is unchecked, and self-questioning is overlooked. When Zuckerberg talked complacently about "serving" more than one billion people, there is little indication he understood how the platform he had created - where all those people share data and information - would spew up the sort of challenges that are now bearing down on his company like an army of Irish front row forwards.

Facebook, Google, Microsoft, Apple and Amazon are great companies. They have changed the world, mostly in a good way. But there are common characteristics in their make-up which mean that there are times when they are inevitably blind to what is really going on out in a cyberworld that is largely unpoliced and populated by very many bad guys.

It is up to the authorities to conclude whether Cambridge Analytica are among the 'bad guys', but what is already clear is that their problems are also Facebook's problems. The Californian firm is finding out what happens when it remains blind to - or uninterested in - what else is going on out there.

The Silicon Valley giants have each been led by undoubted geniuses - Zuckerberg, Sergey Brin and Larry Page, Bill Gates, Steve Jobs and Jeff Bezos - men who retained an iron rule and microscopic control over their companies even as they became too large for one or two people to understand all the details of what could go wrong. The fact that Zuckerberg's personal 2018 resolution is to "fix" Facebook's problems demonstrates that the company allowed too many issues to go unchecked - but that he still sees himself as the individual to resolve them.

Until they are forced to grow up, all of the West Coast mega-platforms are undermined by an inherent culture of wide-eyed idealism that fails to see the dangers hidden in the very products they are successfully creating.

I have a number of very good friends who work for Facebook. Some previously worked at Microsoft, Google and other big tech firms. Not surprisingly there is a merry-go-round of job-swapping around those firms and a recruitment war to bring the best ones on board from their rivals. All of them have an evangelical zeal at the heart of their culture that ensures employees are totally committed to the cause. They believe.

Facebook's mission statement, until 2017, was "to give people the power to share and make the world more open and connected". It is now, to "give people the power to build community and bring the world closer together". They are classic platform mission statements supported wholeheartedly and uncritically by everyone who works there.

But the original left the company vulnerable. If part of Zuckerberg's goal is to make the world open and connected, if he and his software engineers build a platform that can do just that, then there should be no surprise that politicians, criminals, intelligence agencies, the military, marketers and many others will want to use that openness for their own agenda. Even now that some of those darker consequences are becoming clearer, the evangelical belief of the Facebook zealots is unshakable. The idea that being open and connected is the right thing - end of story - is bought into totally at the company's Menlo Park campus, in California, and its offices around the world. And it leads to an arrogance that is inherent in Zuckerberg's belief that he wakes every morning to serve a billion people - and spreads around the company.

Two years ago, prior to Brexit and the election of Donald Trump, I spent quite a lot of time discussing with Facebook people and other observers about how the firm should work with media partners, and the dangers of the company's laid back, tunnel-visioned 'dive into our platform, the water's warm' approach. Emily Bell, the former Guardian journalist and now an academic at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, was presciently warning that "Facebook is eating the world", but the people inside the company didn't care and were utterly unworried as they marched forward into a world of 'fake news' and 'echo chambers.' The revenue was rolling in with more than 80% of mobile ad revenue coming to Facebook and Google, so why worry?

One reason for this apparent nonchalance, apart from the naivety and arrogance, is the way Facebook likes to self-identify as just a 'platform'. This is what every tech firm wants to be. It means your software is the basis for other companies and consumers to come and create whatever they want. The platform companies aim to lock you in to their platform, so that you use their services and no-one else's. It is why they all have their own operating system, browser, communication services, music and content services and hardware such as phones and Alexa-type devices. Every little piece that you do on that company's platform locks you in a bit more. It is why most people are either Apple iPhone users or Google Android owners: once you are in, it is very hard to get out. One of the problems with the 'we are just a platform' argument is that it allows companies to absolve responsibility from the bad stuff that is going on.

A newspaper is not a platform. It publishes what its editors believe are the right things to publish for their audience. Those editors are legally accountable for that content. The tech platforms are desperately trying to argue that they are not publishers but platforms; that what other people publish or do on their platform is nothing to do with them. It is exactly this attitude that allowed 'fake news' to establish itself.

It is like saying that if you are a phone company and two crooks discuss a bank raid over the phone, that is nothing to do with you. We had a classic and difficult platform issue in the early 2000s at Microsoft's MSN. This was relatively early in the history of the internet and we had chatroom technology that was fun, interesting, a bit scary and mostly unpoliced. In the UK, we started to get a lot of heat about how paedophiles were going into these chatrooms to groom children.

The official line was that we were a platform, and that the problem was nothing to do with us. The bosses in the US were not very interested. They didn't see it as a big issue... "We are just the platform".

I am glad to say that we took a stand with our leadership in Redmond, Washington State, and got them to agree that we could close down those chatrooms in 2003. We made the right decision, recognising that we were not just a platform and had a responsibility to do the right thing. I don't see Facebook yet fully recognising that they have to take responsibility for their own platform.

That internal Microsoft dispute over chatrooms also indicates another of the challenges for these global tech giants: those that arise when the technology is built centrally and distributed to local teams. It is a fantastic economically-brilliant model: essentially, one size fits all around the globe. Just see how Amazon's global platform is essentially destroying High Streets, shopping malls and retail chains across continents.

At MSN, we always had local editorial teams who had full oversight as to what was being published in each market: a local versus global balance that meant that we could ensure local sensibilities were taken into account. Facebook doesn't appear to have this to the same extent. They have local sales and marketing teams, but in other areas the company can appear very clumsy. One high profile example came in 2016, when Facebook demonstrated a lack of local understanding in its mishandling of the publication, in Norway, of the iconic 1972 photograph showing a naked Vietnamese girl running along a road after a napalm attack. Facebook initially removed the image, saying it violated its community standards barring child nudity. The incident even led to the Norwegian prime minister having a post deleted.

Such an impersonal intervention also hints at another problem for Facebook and others - the subjugating of common sense to the power of technology. The top software engineers are not only utterly brilliant people. They believe utterly in technology and the power that it brings. They believe that Artificial Intelligence will bring only good. They may say that they are concerned at the effects that AI will bring, but they will push on regardless. I had a brilliant genius of a boss at Microsoft who believed that we would be able to replace all journalists and editors with algorithms in due course. He has moved on now, but the process is continuing.

If tech firms involve humans in their process they not only create expenses, but also throw up other problems for the companies that it would be simpler to avoid. Such sites use technology to identify naked skin in pictures. At Microsoft, back in the day, we had a team in the Philippines to then check if the image was decent or not. The law and regulations were basically on the basis of 'notice and take down'. If you were alerted to bad content, then you should take it down. If you didn't notice, then it wasn't your issue. These are classic platform rules. Once again, we had issues with potential paedophile content. The lawyers told us that we couldn't mount our own campaign to 'notice' the content actively. If we did, then we could be liable. We went covert. We found bad content. We got rid of it. We alerted authorities when we needed to. We didn't tell anyone what we were doing. It was common sense. And the technology was not in charge.

Another weakness that these companies have is their very size. One of the fascinations about working for the Big Five is that the job you do has impact on millions and millions of people. The attractions of working at these places are well documented and all true: you are well compensated in terms of salary and stock grants; the kitchens have free food, Diet Coke, fruit and chocolate; many have gyms and fitness areas; it is fine to work from home regularly. But it is also seductive to be working on products that are used by millions of people. I remember introducing my then 14-year-old son to a mate from Facebook. He was instantly a total fanboy. But for those lucky men and women who fill those jobs there is a danger they get so wrapped up in the kudos of their role, making more and more money, hitting their key performance indicators and growing around the world, that they forget how it can go wrong. And that when it goes wrong, it affects so many people, can change governments, force companies out of business, result in young children being abused online. Not enough people in these organisations are focused on ensuring the bad stuff doesn't happen.

Many people will have read Dave Eggers' The Circle or seen the movie, starring Emma Watson and Tom Hanks. It shows the platform company as a cult, where the core is rotten and the staff are believers. It looked very far-fetched but really it isn't. I don't believe the core of Facebook, or Microsoft or the others are rotten, although I never bought Google's claim to Do No Evil. But as the Cambridge Analytica scandal shows - and the fake news problems of the past few years have exposed - there is a vulnerability at the heart of these firms that they seem unable to fix themselves, because they are simply unable to see it.

Microsoft changed radically when faced with break-up action from the Department of Justice and the EU regulators, around the turn of the millenium. It is hard to describe just how much of a wake-up call that was for everyone in the organisation everywhere. It was a near-death experience that, I believe, made it a much better and more responsible company.

It feels like Facebook is now edging closer to that scenario itself. Maybe Zuckerberg will eschew his grey T-shirt and dig out his old 2009 tie when he faces the Commons Select Committee rather than sending along his minions.

urn:contentItem:3X4K-BBV0-00MP-T4RV-00000-00Brokerages, Net Stocks Tick Higher in Pre-Holiday Action1998-12-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:25ZLexisNexisMARKETS; Market RoundupBrokerages, Net Stocks Tick Higher in Pre-Holiday ActionBy Aaron L. Task, Senior WriterDecember 25, 1998 1:30 PM ET

After a surprisingly hectic week, Wall Street finally acted like it's supposed to in pre-holiday trading. Major proxies ended mixed as stocks sauntered quietly through a shortened session. 

Blue-chip technology stocks faltered but select Internet names (naturally) remained alluring to investors. In the material world, financial and consumer-focused leaders were strong (but not Herculean), while drug makers, transports and energy concerns exhibited modest weakness. 

Major IndicesINDEXCHANGE%VALUEYR TO DATEDOW15.96+0.2%9217.99+16.6%S&P 5002.27-0.2%1226.27+26.3%Nasdaq9.50-0.4%2163.04+37.7%RUSSELL 20000.78+0.2%405.57-7.2%TSC INTERNET1.52+0.4%429.77+174%TREASURY BONDCHANGEVALUEYIELD30-YEAR19/32100 15/325.218%

 

The Dow Jones Industrial Average was the best performer of major gauges, closing up 15.96, or 0.2%, to 9217.99. The blue-chip proxy overcame an early decline to as low as 9178.60 but closed off its intraday high of 9245.54. 

IBM (IBM:NYSE) and J.P. Morgan (JPM:NYSE) were the strongest Dow components, the latter evincing the strong overall session for financial stocks. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange/KBW Bank Index slid 0.2% but the American Stock Exchange Broker/Dealer Index gained 2.5%. 

The S&P 500 rose as high as 1229.72 but saw its string of record-setting closes ended at three, falling 2.27, or 0.2%, to 1226.27. 

Hamstrung by weakness in big tech names such as Cisco (CSCO:Nasdaq) and Microsoft (MSFT:Nasdaq), the Nasdaq Composite Indexalso fell from historic heights, shedding 9.50, or 0.4%, to 2163.04. 

The Russell 2000 managed to rise 0.78, or 0.2%, to 405.57. 

"There's not a helluva lot going on," said Jim Volk, co-head of institutional trading at D.A. Davidson in Portland, Ore. "The [Dow] is up but quietly rallying before Christmas. The market is seasonally strong except for the little down drift a few days ago." 

Volk said he expects more quietude in the coming week but with the positive drift continuing. "It looks like people want to the market to continue to rally into the end of the year," he said. "But my sense is most major accounts are done for the year, especially the big hedge funds." 

In New York Stock Exchange trading, 249.6 million shares were traded while advancers bested declining stocks 1,471 to 1,298. In Nasdaq Stock Market activity, 447 million shares were exchanged while gainers led 1,983 to 1,738. New 52-week highs bested new lows 95 to 28 on the Big Board and by 75 to 45 in over-the-counter trading.
 
Internet Madness Takes No Holiday 

Micron Technology (MU:NYSE) was a highlight among traditional tech names, falling 3.2% despite late yesterday posting a narrower-than-expected first-quarter loss. But Micron was up 22% since Dec.1 heading into today, double the gain of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange Semiconductor Index, so some retrenchment was due. 

While the Nasdaq 100 slid 0.7%, TheStreet.com Internet Sector index rose 0.4%. Gains by Infoseek (SEEK:Nasdaq) and @Home (ATHM:Nasdaq) led the index but much of the excitement today in secondary and tertiary names. 

Delia's (DLIA:Nasdaq) climbed 67% after announcing it will expand its online offerings to include a store at Yahoo!'s (YHOO:Nasdaq) shopping site. 

Meanwhile, CVF Technologies (CNV:NYSE) rose 43% after announcing it will begin selling its herbal and nutritional products online. Also notably higher on even the hint of online developments were PC Connection (PCCC:Nasdaq), higher by 65%; SkyMall (SKYM:Nasdaq), which gained 110%; and Internet America (GEEK:Nasdaq), up a further 42%. 

On the flip side, Multiple Zones (MZON:Nasdaq) slid 47% and uBid (UBID:Nasdaq) shed 35%; both enjoyed big gains yesterday. 

"Anybody who would argue the Internet stocks are not in the midst of a speculative bubble is blind," Richard Bernstein, chief quantitative analyst at Merrill Lynch, said in an interview earlier this week. "It's the biggest speculative bubble of our lifetime. A moose bubble." 

Bernstein is not convinced (as are others) the action in Net stocks portends a disaster for the market as a whole. "You can make a doomsday scenario out of anything, but there have been speculative bubbles of smaller proportions that have not affected the broader market," he said. 

Nonetheless, the quant maven said what is going on in Netland is "mind-boggling" and believes (as do most) that it will end badly. "All that has to happen is Wal-Mart (WMT:NYSE) decides to open a Web site and it's all over for most retailers on the Web," he said. "Yes, there is the psyche of the Net community but ultimately is comes down to who has the best price. When it comes to commodity distribution, nobody does it better than Wal-Mart and they can undercut everybody because of existing agreements. With that lurking out there, it amazes me what's going on." 

At least we're not alone. 

Among other indices, the Dow Jones Transportation Average fell 10.15, or 0.3%, to 3044.08; the Dow Jones Utility Average lost 0.51, or 0.2%, to 314.54; and the American Stock Exchange Composite Index gained 1.71, or 0.3%, to 666.49. 

For the week, the Dow industrials rose 314.36, or 3.5%; the S&P 500 gained 40.24, or 3.4%; the Nasdaq Comp rose 78.90, or 3.8%; the Russell 2000 added 8.15, or 2.1%; TheStreet.com Internet Index gained 52.06, or 13.8%; the Dow transports rose 35.04, or 1.2%; the Dow utilities added 1.25, or 0.4%; and the Amex Composite climbed 15.24, or 2.3%. 

The 30-year Treasury bond, in which trading closed at 2 p.m. EST, was down 19/32 to 100 15/32, its yield rising to 5.22%. 

Elsewhere in North American equities today, the Toronto Stock Exchange 300 advanced 18.41 to 6465.40 and the Mexican Stock Exchange IPC Index leapt 71.06, or 1.8%, to 4001.35. For the week, the TSE 300 rose 112.08, or 1.8%, and the IPC gained 160.11, or 4.2%.
 
Thursday's Company Report 

By Heather Moore
Staff Reporter 

(Earnings estimates from First Call; new highs and lows on a closing basis unless otherwise specified. Earnings reported on a diluted basis unless otherwise specified.) 

On the day before Christmas, as noted earlier, those young, enthused Internet stocks continued to outlast just about everyone else, ready for a big meal, a few gifts and some major z's.
 
* CVF Technologies shot up 1 13/16, or 43.3%, to 6 on news of its Web site for the sale of nutritional and herbal supplements.
 
* Delia's, a clothing retailer for teens and young adults, soared 7 1/4, or 66.7%, to 18 1/8 on word of its new store on Yahoo!, which slipped 2 9/16 to 247 1/8.
 
* Multiple Zones gave back 26 1/4, or 46.8%, to 29 1/2 after yesterday's 396% rise on news the direct marketer of computer products will launch an online auction site.
 
* To be a Net play nowadays, you don't even have to say you're thinking of opening a business on the Web; you can actually say you're not thinking of opening a business on the Web. Just say something Weblike and you're good to go. Playboy (PLA:NYSE) took in 2, or 10.2%, to an all-time high of 21 5/8 on market chatter about a possible offering of the company's Internet unit even after Playboy executives said the company has no current plans for such a move.
 
* SkyMall vaulted 6 5/8, or 110%, to an all-time high of 12 9/16 after the company's Web potential was discussed on the Internet.
 
* Zapata (ZAP:NYSE) lost 1 7/8, or 13.2%, to 12 3/8 after yesterday's spike upward on news of the company's revived plans to open an Internet business.
 
* Ziff-Davis (ZD:NYSE) jumped 4 7/8, or 30.7%, to an all-time high of 20 3/4 after Tuesday saying it filed with regulators for an IPO for its ZDNet Internet business.
 
* Among those soaring for no reason other than being privileged enough to somehow be connected to the Internet were: PC Connection, an online software and computer products retailer, which hopped 8 3/4, or 64.8%, to 22 1/4; Internet America, an Internet service provider, which hopped 12 15/16, or 41.6%, to an all-time high of 44; Egghead.com (EGGS:Nasdaq), which hopped 1 1/16 to 23 3/4; and @Home, which hopped 9 1/16, or 12.6%, to an all-time high of 80 7/8.
 
Mergers, acquisitions and joint ventures 

Aames Financial (AAM:NYSE) added 1/16 to 2 9/16 after last night saying Capital Z Financial Services Fund agreed to make an equity investment of up to $100 million in the company. 

Adelphia Communications (ADLAC:Nasdaq) lifted 2 1/8, or 5%, to an all-time high of 44 1/2 after yesterday agreeing to buy Verto Communications and merge the company into a subsidiary. 

Borders (BGP:NYSE) scored 2 3/16, or 10.4%, to 23 3/16 after the Federal Trade Commission announced yesterday it's seeking more information on Borders competitor Barnes & Noble's (BKS:NYSE) $600 million proposed acquisition of book distributor Ingram Book Group. Barnes & Noble rose 1 1/16 to 35 1/2. 

Ford (F:NYSE) took in 1/2 to 58 7/8 on word from ING Baring Securities the automaker sold its 9% stake in South Korea's Kia Motors to J.P. Morgan for $11.3 million. ING Baring handled the transaction. 

Kevco (KVCO:Nasdaq) advanced 1 5/16, or 19.6%, to 8 3/8 on news privately held Wingate Partners II will acquire the company for $40 million in stock and warrants. Kevco also said it sees a fourth-quarter loss. The two-analyst forecast called for a breakeven quarter compared to the year-ago profit of 3 cents. 

Rutherford-Moran Oil (RMOC:Nasdaq) shot up 1 3/16, or 61.3%, to 3 1/8 after late yesterday Chevron (CHV:NYSE) agreed to acquire the company for $91 million in stock and the assumption of $302 million in debt. Chevron shed 5/16 to 84 11/16.
 
Earnings/revenue reports and previews 

Community First Bankshares (CFBX:Nasdaq) lowered 13/16 to 20 1/8 after saying late yesterday it will take a fourth-quarter charge of $10 million, or 14 cents a share, on the liquidation of its subprime lending units. 

Micron Technology fell 1 3/4 to 52 1/4 after the chip maker late yesterday announced a first-quarter loss of 19 cents a share vs. the year-ago profit of 3 cents. The loss did beat estimates for a loss of 28 cents. Today, Credit Suisse First Boston upped its 1999 estimates on Micron and raised the stock's price target to 70 from 65 a share. 

Northwest Natural Gas (NWNG:Nasdaq), a Portland, Ore.-based utility, tumbled 1 3/16 to 26 5/8 after warning its fourth-quarter profit will be 2 cents below the four-analyst view of 79 cents. In the year-ago period, the company made 78 cents.
 
Analyst actions 

Americal Online (AOL:NYSE), to be added to the S&P 500 on the last day of 1998, declined 1 3/8 to 136 5/8 after Credit Suisse First Boston cut it to buy from strong buy based on stock appreciation. 

Bindley Western Industries (BDY:NYSE) added 9/16 to 46 1/4 after Goldman Sachs started coverage with a market outperform. 

Dawson Geophysical (DWSN:Nasdaq) slid 3/16 to 7 7/16 after Raymond James dropped it to neutral from buy. 

Sotheby's (BID:NYSE) brought in 4 1/2, or 13.4%, to an all-time high of 38 after Merrill Lynch raised it to near-term accumulate from neutral, while maintaining its long-term buy, earlier this week. The auction house refused comment on its stock movement. 

Total Renal Care Holdings (TRL:NYSE) expanded 1 5/16, or 5.3%, to 26 1/8 after Hambrecht & Quist upgraded it to strong buy from buy.
 
Miscellany 

ValueVision (VVTV:Nasdaq) climbed 1/2, or 9.1%, to 6 after late yesterday settling a lawsuit filed by Time Warner (TWX:NYSE) and saying it will record a fourth-quarter charge of $4.3 million to cover the settlement. Time Warner rose 1 to an all-time high of 62 3/8.
