Brookings Institution Holds Discussion On Consumer Privacy

December 13, 2019 10:00 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

CENTER FOR TECHNOLOGY INNOVATION GOVERNANCE STUDIES FELLOW NICOL TURNER LEE

AT&T GLOBAL PUBLIC POLICY VICE PRESIDENT JEFF BRUEGGEMAN

CENTER FOR TECHNOLOGY INNOVATION GOVERNANCE STUDIES ANN R. AND ANDREW H. TISCH DISTINGUISHED VISITING FELLOW CAMERON F. KERRY

AMERICAN ENTERPRISE INSTITUTE VISITING SCHOLAR ROSLYN LAYTON

OFFICE OF SENATOR EDWARD J. MARKEY (D-MA) SENIOR POLICY ADVISOR JOSEPH WENDER

[*]TURNER LEE: We'll ask everybody to start to get settled because we are webcasting and to our webcasting audience, we will be starting in just a couple of seconds.

All righty, hello everybody. Good morning. I go to a black Baptist church and when the pastor says good morning, everybody says good morning, okay? So, we're going to act like we're in my church.

Good morning, everybody!

UNKNOWN: Good morning.

TURNER LEE: Okay, I knew you had enough coffee, it's almost eleven o'clock, okay.

My name is Dr. Nicol Turner Lee, I'm a Fellow in the Center for Technology Innovation and I'm excited to be hosting this panel.

It's always difficult as we get to the end of the decade to have a significant conversation, but we thought it was really well worth having this discussion because we're sort of in the sandwich period when it comes to privacy.

Let me tell you what the sandwich is. A little over a year ago we had something called the General Data Protection Regulation come through the EU that pretty much changed the nature of what privacy looked like.

That came in a perfect storm of Cambridge Analytica as well as other privacy infractions that had been mounting in terms of our credit and other institutions and then leading into January we'll have the California Consumer Privacy Act, the CCPA which will be the other part of the sandwich.

And in between that sandwich has been a lot of discussions and a few bills that are sort of making up the lettuce around privacy, and that would be the Wicker and Cantwell bills if you have not already seen them.

So, we thought, and I'm saying we as I'm referring to my dear friend and colleague Cam Kerry who has been working really hard on this series called the Privacy Debates. If you have not looked at it, I encourage you to go to the Brookings website and read some recent pieces that he's put together.

We thought this would be a really timely conversation because as these two parts of the bread have basically framed this dialogue on what data collection, use and sharing look like.

Where are we going to take some cues of that, leading towards national federal privacy framework, or will we diverge, right? Or will there be parts of it that will actually not be relevant to the discussion.

So, today's dialogue, I'm joined by some additional friends and I think some really important experts who are taking a look at these issues.

I will introduce them in just a moment, but I want to make sure you are all in the right place and affirm that you are in the right place in this particular dialogue.

So, we're actually going to start with the discussion and after we start with the discussion, we will actually lend itself to about ten minutes of Q&A.

A couple of other housekeeping notes, please Tweet any activity under what's called the privacy debate hashtag and we also have left on your seats an evaluation form. If you find this conversation informative and something useful, I ask you actually fill that out on your way out. Give it to one of our staff who will collect that.

So, thanks again for being here.

Today I'm joined by experts in this field who have actually dealt with this conversation and I'll start with my colleague Cam Kerry who is a fellow here at Brookings. Joey Wender who is in the office of Senator Ed Markey, Roslyn Layton who comes from next door from the American Enterprise Institute and Jeff Brueggeman who is at AT&T.

For disclosure purposes, AT&T is a donor here at Brookings.

With that, let's give them all a round of applause.

(APPLAUSE)

So, I want to jump right into this debate and Joey, I'm going to start with you, not like you all have anything else to talk about up on Capitol Hill.

So much has happened in the past 18 months and this has been a dialogue that's had starts and stops and we now have seen privacy bills come from both sides which is promising due to the bi-partisan nature. We've had multiple hearings on this as late as last week on it.

So what I'd like to talk to you about is just this conversation about privacy legislation and get this peek from you as somebody who sits on the Hill to where we were and where we're going general in the United States before we delve into the influences of, I like my metaphor of the sandwich. I'm sticking with it Joey, just telling you right now, okay?

(LAUGHTER)

WENDER: Well I'm hungry so--

(LAUGHTER)

So, thank you. I would say we've gone from a world--so three things have happened, right? GDPR, the California law and Cambridge Analytica, I would say those are the three drivers that have changed the course of this conversation over the last couple of years.

So, we've gone from a world of if we were going to pass comprehensive federal privacy legislation to when are we going to pass comprehensive federal privacy legislation.

That's the first shift. The second shift that we've seen in the last couple of years because of these three intervening events, is what is the scope of what that bill looks like?

A few years ago, it would have been a more simple notice and choice regime. People should have noticed their information has been collected or shared or used and they should have the right to say no to collection, sharing, use, sale, etcetera.

That debate has clearly shifted over the last few years and not only folks on the Hill and advocates, but also industry has recognized that notice and choice is simply not enough for giving consumers rights over their information.

Now we're having a conversation about use limitations, that there are certain things that are always going to be off the table whether they be discriminatory uses or what do we do with people's biometric information? What data minimization requirements we put in place as in you can't, you know collect that information in the first place.

So, it's both this if to when shift and what is the scope of what this likely bill will eventually look like, shifted pretty dramatically in the last couple of years.

TURNER LEE: Okay, I want to jump over to you then because as Joey's talking about we're actually seeing, I think in some of the new bills, the bill from Senator Cantwell and Senator Wicker, that actually is starting to look at some of those things.

What I'm particularly interested in, since this conversation is about GDPR and CCPA, the extent to which we are actually seeing these new bills, maybe talk about what these new bills are, for people who may not know. But if they are in any way influenced by either, on either side.

KERRY: Thanks, and I'd move to strike the last word.

(LAUGHTER)

So, you know they are as Joey said, they are certainly regular drivers of this legislation, but they are also benchmarks. So, we are dealing with first I think a set of expectations, that has been created by GDPR and more significantly by the CCPA.

So, as GDPR has been implemented, we've seen, you know, many companies that are subject to it's very broad territorial reach, adapt their privacy programs to the GDPR, so lots of companies in some cases like Microsoft is one example, have said we're going to apply GDPR to all of our services as really a positioning statement and for others it was just a much easier compliance. Might have said look, we're just going to have one program around the world and so now lots of Americans are subject to GDPR, then along comes CCPA which applies to the seventh largest economy in the world and really sets a standard that affects services across the United States.

On top of which, one quarter of the congressional delegation in the--of the democratic delegation in the house is from California, including the Speaker, including a number of other very influential members of congress who are saying, we are not going to let the federal government roll back protections that our citizens have. So, any bill is going to match up to CCPA.

So, that has really set a benchmark and we are seeing the adoption of almost I think is a given in legislation, individual rights of access of correction, deletion of data and portability of data that mirror both GDPR and CCPA.

The draft legislation, both the Wicker bills and the Cantwell bills go I think significantly beyond CCPA in terms of what Joey talked about, limitations on collection. On use and broader sharing limitations than CCPA and you know not exactly like GDPR but conceptually the same--the same principals. I think looking to have something that is not as prescriptive as GDPR is, not as process oriented but in some respects also goes beyond GDPR. What we're seeing, certainly very explicitly, in the Cantwell and others draft is provisions against the use of personal information in ways that--that are discriminatory.

That goes beyond GDPR and we're not as explicitly but certainly been an opening the door to discrimination issues in the Wicker bill as well.

You know this is a great start.

TURNER LEE: Yeah, before we go to Ros on compliance, I want to go back to the two of you for just a second and I want to be mindful of folks who have followed this debate closely and some who are just getting their feet wet in this debate.

Look at GDPR, this is an oversimplification I'm going to make and please correct me if I'm wrong.

I like what Cam said, right? This was about a process, a submission of processes around data use, data collection, data sharing.

GDPR--I mean CCPA seems to be something that's around enforcement, right?

And a much more granular look at what's on and off limits and how do we actually enforce that.

Would that be, can you give for the audience maybe a high-level view of what both categories, what each is trying to accomplish before we delve into compliance?

KERRY: Is that back to me?

TURNER LEE: Between the two of you.

KERRY: Well, CCPA is, you know as I see it first and foremost about providing more individual control and so it is those individual rights and you know it is a right to opt out of the sharing of your data but in some respects that is sort of doubling down on the problem that we have today.

Joe talked about the failures of notice and choice. The problem that we have with privacy today is that it really puts all of the burden on us as individuals, as consumers to protect our privacy and so what we are seeing is a, in GDPR, in both the Wicker and Cantwell bills, is a move towards putting more of the obligations on the companies that collect the data to manage that data, to handle that data, to process that data in ways that are consistent with our expectations, you know when we share the data.

WENDER: The only thing I would, I mean I agree with everything you said. The only thing I would add is that there is more and more of a recognition that there is an asymmetrical relationship in terms of power between consumers and these large companies.

That consumers, you can give them all the rights in the world, they don't really understand what these large companies are doing with their information, how ads and other services are being served to them and so that's why a lot of this conversation is being shifted to what affirmative obligations are we putting on these companies to help protect consumers.

Because an individual consumer, it's just simply not enough to give somebody a four-thousand-word privacy policy and say okay, read this, okay cool you've read it now you've consented to it, it's over.

Right, that's clearly just not enough in 2019 and the only thing I would add is it's not only just asymmetrical power relationship, it's that these companies themselves have become so much more powerful and so much pervasive in our society and they control so many aspects of our life.

So, it's not as simple as just oh, you're handing over your information to a store because you're buying a service. I mean we're on a whole other level where there is a, we can talk about opaqueness of algorithms.

There's a whole world in which people are being served news and products and services that you don't understand at all how that happened and so because of how powerful these entities have become in our society, it's incumbent on us to put more obligations on them in order to level the playing field between the consumer and the company.

KERRY: Some of these companies--

WENDER: You know listen, I will say this, one last thing I'll say is that's what makes this conversation so difficult is that Google, let's just say the words, Google and Facebook become--become the examples right, that everybody uses for the internet or for these companies.

But the truth is Google is not like Facebook, Facebook is not like Google and Google and Facebook are unlike the millions of other online companies.

So, the rules we put in place can't be for Google and Facebook. We have to do it in a way that recognizes there is a huge diversity of services and websites out there and frankly that's what makes a lot of this so challenging.

TURNER LEE: Well that's a nice shift, Roslyn, to you right? Because if the and thank you both for sort of answering that question because I think it's inherent to this conversation.

If there's a shift towards companies then there'll be a shift towards compliance, right? And I was picking up my great research assistant, Kaitlyn Chin (SP) helped me find a stat that I want to share with the group from the International Association of Privacy Professionals at Ernst and Young who estimated that Fortune 500 companies spend $8 billion on GDPR compliance and it's anticipated with CCPA compliance that their looking at about $55 billion.

So those are huge compliance costs, particularly you know, if we're shifting that burden to companies.

So, Roslyn, I'd like to find out from you, you know are these real and actualized costs? Are they areas that we should be paying attention to as we shift the regulatory burden? And you know, what impact does that have then on us you know, really creating a benchmark for privacy?

LAYTON: So, Nicol, first I want to start by saying thank you for this invitation and also to Cam and great to meet my new friend here, Joe and Jeff and just to say, I'm next door at AEI.

We've worked together, Brookings and AI for so many years, we like you so much we moved our office to be next to you.

(LAUGHTER)

TURNER LEE: I know that was kind of like, huh.

(LAUGHTER)

LAYTON: So, but I'm going to make some remarks today that are going to reflect my views.

AEI doesn't have a view on privacy itself and to keep with our idea about the sandwich, you know as a researcher, what I'm looking at is what's in the sandwich.

Is it made with Wonder Bread? Is it whole grain bread? You've got avocado in there. Is it a vegetarian sandwich? So, I'm actually interested in what is in the sandwich and when I look at you know.

And I also, I live most of the year in Copenhagen, I work at the university in Denmark at Aalborg University and my research is published there.

Where I'm looking at the outcome of the GDPR, 18 months after it's been in place and I'm comparing now what we have as CCPA and so I look at the differences of these two laws, for me it's about the numbers. I mean GDPR has 45 specific regulations around what the company has to do. CCPA has 77 so it's even more stringent and the challenge for me is there is a law put together in less than a month, no testing around the provisions that were adopted.

The folks who did this, they just made it up and said let's put an 800 number on the website. I mean they just pulled these things together. There's no testing associated with it.

But the early kind of data we have in terms of companies having to get ready for this is that it is between $1 million and--minimum and $100,000 to comply and $1 million and you know maybe in Europe it's been $9 to $10 billion for GDPR.

The CCPA is even more than that. We're talking on order of $55 billion, $70 billion. That's two percent of the GDP of California and the California Department of Justice itself has published a cost benefit analysis which is giving 14 to one cost over benefits.

Meaning that the cost to set this up, $55 billion initially, another $16 over ten to 15 years, compared to only $5 billion of documented benefit. So, that's not a great return on investment.

The other challenge there is that the 99 percent of the companies in California have less than 500 employees so $100,000 is more than the entire cost that a typical company spends on their entire IT system.

So, this is going to be extremely challenging for small, medium size companies and the other part that we've seen already with GDPR which I think policy makers need to wake up quickly is that it has been the reward for the largest companies.

We've seen in 18 months that Google, Facebook, Amazon they have increased their market share on European Union, they have increased their revenue. In fact, users continue to go to those platforms to the detriment to their competitors who have lost market share. They have lost the ability to track venture capital and we don't see small and medium sized companies growing.

So, if you look at the United States, we had 40,000 start ups last year. Still a wonderful place to innovate. Things are going great. I'm really concerned about we're going to kill the golden goose that laid this golden egg.

And if I could give you my wish here, I would go back in time to 2012 when Cam was at Department of Commerce, he was so brilliant.

TURNER LEE: I don't know if he wants to go back to the Department of Commerce.

(LAUGHTER)

LAYTON: He had this brilliant idea for a consumer--

KERRY: Depends on which administration.

(LAUGHTER)

LAYTON: So, but he, the actually--it's interesting the moral to the story, they had a very--a wonderful multi stakeholder-based standards--technical based solution. Consumer privacy bill of rights which was not at all controversial.

We weren't able to do it, but the Europeans saw it didn't happen, they came in with the GDPR and we missed this opportunity, so I hope we don't miss it again.

But you know the brains are here at the end of this panel in terms of getting the right solutions.

TURNER LEE: But I want to just before I leave from you on the compliance, what are these costs?

Are they the costs of manpower, are they cost of sort of recalibrating systems? You know, we hear costs, what are they?

LAYTON: The number one cost is the privacy consultant, so it is a wealth transfer from the companies themselves to the privacy lawyers or consultants. IAPP have doubled their membership globally.

So, the second highest cost is the IT costs but essentially you could say, well look those companies, could you spend a million dollars innovating your products and services, could you do different things with that money?

No, we're paying the privacy lawyers and the privacy bar, they're getting rich off of this.

TURNER LEE: So, Jeff, I want to go to you. I mean we have you up here, you know as I mentioned in the disclosure that AT&T does fund Brookings as well as a whole lot of other companies but I was really curious to get a company on the panel that would actually speak to how this was actually going to affect them.

So, Governor Brown, you know signed the California Consumer Privacy Act in July 2018. The press basically touted that industry was okay with it to a certain extent, right, in terms of those provisions.

And it gave some industry momentum, to sort of look at how they could either comply or get this done.

So, I'm just really curious. Does the CCPA change the way that AT&T or other companies will do business? Are you worried by these compliance costs? Or kind of going back to Joey's original comment, you know, do you see this as a way to sort of have that pressure placed on you to just do better.

You know, I'm really curious how you all are looking at this.

BRUEGGEMAN: Well first, I would say I echo thanks for hosting this event and all the work you and Cam are doing on privacy because I really do think there, we're at a moment in time where there is an opportunity here.

You know, AT&T has long supported federal privacy legislation, back to the excellent work Cam did in the Obama administration.

But California really crystallized this as an issue that's going to hit every type of company, right? From the dry cleaner to other retailers to any company that uses data. So, I think it did broaden perspective and broaden the industry engagement on privacy.

At the same time, just to unpack what California really--the process. It started as a ballot initiative in 2016, then the law was adopted that summer.

It is taking effect next year and then the state AG is now drafting regulations that will take effect some time next year so we're still filling in what the law is going to mean.

And then the ballot proponent is back with another initiative on privacy that he is putting--is going to try to put on the ballot next election that would take effect in 2023.

So, I think on the one hand it has helped a lot of companies get over that, okay I'm investing--as Roslyn laid out the numbers, we're investing in the systems to give consumers the tools to manage data to comply.

So, it's a lot easier to say, let's have privacy legislation. On the other hand, there is a lot of concern about, what about the next set of regulations in California itself. Or what about another state doing something different.

Given the amount and the cost of doing this, it is extremely concerning to businesses to then say, I may have to do it, you know, ten different ways going forward.

So, on the one hand, it's catalyzed interest in privacy, on the other it's made it easier I think for industry to get behind strong privacy regulation because you were already a third of the economy is now doing this for California.

TURNER LEE: I mean to all of you, when GDPR went into effect, started getting those pop-ups, it seems like common place now, you know you get them. Most people just sort of accept them, they keep moving on, but you know it seems like again on the compliance side you actually have to be able to comply and be able to institute those systems.

But I want to talk about consumers though, right cause at the heart of this, even though there may be more burden on industry, even though companies are sort of either going to be forced into sort of this state or not.

Do consumers actually benefit from any of this stuff, going forward?

I start with Roslyn, let's put them back in the conversation.

LAYTON: I think the best statistic on this, 18 months after GDPR, the consumer trust online for Europeans is at the lowest point it's ever been. In the 20 years that they have kept the statistics, Eurostat, you can look for yourself.

That's stunning to me because this is reflecting a long period of time the Europeans have tried to do more and more regulation.

But the challenge is because of the approach they've taken, only half of the companies comply so it's really a sense of set it, forget it. You get the pop-up in your face, but the people accept that there's not a culture of compliance.

So you may put all the regulations in the world but if it's so expensive that the companies just say we're not complying, remember the data protection authorities in EU, they don't have more funding, they don't have training so they can't enforce all of this. They have to pick and choose what they're going to enforce.

So, the consumers are really resigned and the other part about it is the small and medium sized companies don't grow and that was the real challenge that there's not a more robust eco-system as a result of this.

And something we need to think, what are we going to get if we go to California?

TURNER LEE: I--couldn't argument be--I wanted to jump in this, but couldn't argument also be made Roslyn that sometimes the consumers don't need access to content because companies can't comply.

Remember right after GDPR a lot of U.S. newspapers just fell off the grid--

LAYTON: Over a thousand--over a thousand U.S. firms no longer work in the EU.

Williams Sonoma, you can't even look at their recipes but there is a missing component in this policy is that we don't have a consumer education component which we could have a tremendous difference if we had, you know, digital competence training.

Or we had--we incentivized the companies to offer training for their users, for example. Because then people would feel empowered.

TURNER LEE: Cam, you want to respond to this?

KELLY: Yeah, I--you know I think we need to put GDPR a little bit in perspective. Like I agree with some of what you said, Ros, about the effects but I think--I think there are some things, you know, the extent of innovation, the venture market, the impact on SMEs in Europe.

I'm not sure you can necessarily lay that to GDPR. I think some of that is endemic to Europe and the European economy has not been that strong.

But I think the effects on the advertising market have been clear. I mean it's clear that both Google and Facebook have gained share. That data I think is pretty robust and I think that, that does raise competitive issues for how we deal with the sharing of information, the impact of legislation on the advertising markets.

So, we can't--I think we can fix competition issues with privacy legislation in the states, but we do need to understand intended or unintended consequences on competition from doing that. So that's--that's going to be a critical discussion going in--going forward.

I'm--I think GDPR has had one beneficial impact has been to force people to look at their data governance.

A lot of process involved but the process of saying, what are we collecting, why are we collecting and what are we doing with it, is an important step in the process.

I mean a little too--because of the regulatory requirements, it's too focused on making lots of records of what you're doing. We need a more flexible approach but those pop-ups, I mean GDPR is not all about consent.

In fact, it sort of moves things away from consent but it certainly doubles down on consent where it's used.

TURNER LEE: Joey did you--or Jeff? Both of you come in.

WENDER: A lot of people lamented when California, excuse me, when Europe went first. That somehow the Europeans were now leading the world on privacy and a lot of Americans here said, "oh, my God, how did we let this happen".

Now, but there's a huge benefit to that though and the benefit is they've gone first, now we learn from their mistakes.

And beyond Europe, the states are the guinea pigs, right? They're the ones that are--California is gone, and other states are to go, as well. So, what Congress is doing right now is not only looking at what's happening in Europe and what's happened in California, but they're also looking at all the other states that--and state legislatures that are now proposing legislation. So, the hope is, and I make no guarantees about the ability or wisdom of 535 members of Congress to pass a perfect bill, but the hope is, the hope is, that somehow, we will learn from all of these intended or unintended consequences of Europe and the state bills to pass something great.

TURNER LEE: (OFF-MIC) Jeff, do you want to jump in?

BRUEGGEMAN: Yeah, I would second that. I think there's a real opportunity to let's learn from both California and the GDPR. Let's take the best of what is there. As I said, companies have already invested heavily to comply, so there's a strong foundation, but then let's avoid some of the mistakes. And I would go back to the point that Jerry made earlier, I think of we're successful here, things should get easier for consumers not more frustrating or more complicated and I think that should be one of the lessons from GDPR that, you know, to the extent that we can identify either types of data or uses of data that really concerned consumers and put strong restrictions on those, then let's not put everything into that basket and--and complicate their lives for just routine transactions on the Internet.

And--and let's also make sure we're avoiding the unintended consequences about, for example, if you--if you restrict sharing but not using data that you end up helping certain companies and not other companies. So, I think--and I think the frameworks that we've seen introduced, you know, there's a lot of similarity and a lot of overlap in the thinking that I think shows there's a lot of consensus-building on some of these issues that, you know--but we should always think about the consumer as--as--when we're trying to serve.

And I guess one last point is, I--I think sometimes, particularly in Europe, it's viewed as privacy is a trade-off for other things. And--and, you know, consumers benefit from whether it's a free ad-supported website or a new use of data that helps, you know, make a--a product better, so we need to give them both, right? We need to give them strong privacy and security productions, and all of the great things that can happen from using their data. And we really shouldn't view it as--as a trade-off if we do this right.

TURNER LEE: (OFF-MIC) Yeah, go ahead, Roslyn.

LAYTON: Yeah, I just wanted to make one last point there. I think part of this process of learning from the different approaches is I actually think we'll come again to appreciate the American privacy tradition. Brookings Institution Holds Discussion On Data Privacy Legislation

September 16, 2019 03:30 P.M.

SPEAKERS:

CENTER FOR TECHNOLOGY INNOVATION GOVERNANCE STUDIES FELLOW NICOL TURNER LEE

CONSUMER TECHNOLOGY ASSOCIATION GOVERNMENT AFFAIRS VICE PRESIDENT JAMIE BOONE

APP ASSOCIATION ACT PRESIDENT MORGAN REED

SILICON FLATIRONS EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR AMIE STEPANOVICH

[*]LEE: Okay, perfect. Thank you. Let me get my notes out. Good afternoon, everyone. Oh, I need a little bit more than that. You've had about five cups of coffee before you got here. So I'll say one more time. Good afternoon, everyone.

UNKNOWN: Good afternoon.

LEE: Thank you. I'm so happy to actually see everybody here once again at Brookings. I know that we have some of you who are new to a Brookings session. I won't ask you to raise your hand, but I would say welcome to you. And I know we got some repeat visitors that come to many Brookings sessions, so I would say welcome back. I don't know the last time that you were here, and I actually don't know if you were here last week for a privacy conversation. But if you were, you're going to get a little bit more privacy today. I'm excited for this particular conversation for a variety of reasons. How many of you have heard that we are trying to pass federal privacy legislation in the United States? How many heard that about a year ago?

(LAUGHTER)

How many of you heard about six month ago? And you're going to hear about it today. And I say that because, despite all of the perfect storm that sort of converged when privacy legislation was actually, you know, restarted, we're still at this place where we haven't come up with what we think is really good comprehensive privacy legislation. And in my role, and I'm going to introduce the panelists, I'm Nicol Turner Lee, I work in the Center for Technology Innovation as a fellow.

And I basically have three buckets of work that I actually spend a lot of my time on. The first one is around regulatory and legislative policy. I see some friends out here. I've been doing this for quite some time. In fact, I'm not going to date myself because I have this young hairstyle so I'm trying to look like my daughter. But when we started talking about privacy in the Obama administration, to be back in 2008, 2009, many of us were in that conversation. My colleague Cam Kerry, who was at Commerce at the time, brought many of us together to talk about online consumer privacy. Back then we were just dealing with the Internet of Things. And some of you may remember that.

I also work on issues related to the digital divide. And yes, I'm going to give a shameless plug. I have a book coming out next year on the U.S. digital divide and I've completed a seven city tour of the United States on how people are accessing digital resources. So that will come out soon. And then finally, I work on issues related to artificial intelligence, particularly algorithmic bias. So that ties into the privacy conversation and we'll see how long we have. I've got a feisty group, just wait, in terms of the discussion. If we get there in terms of other spooks that are under the privacy umbrella, we'll talk about that.

So why did I decide I want to have this outside of being somebody who focuses in that first bucket? There have been a lot of privacy conversations going on. And in those conversations, we edge one inch closer, as all of us showed by raising her hand, and one inch backwards. And so what I'm really interested in and I think the panelists appear will help us clean this out and unpack this a little bit, is one, why we haven't made a lot of progress in the last six months, and then two, when we look at federal privacy legislation as this umbrella, what are the spokes that are sort of being debated right now? So all of us have really talked about the principles. Cam Kerry and I sort of have tag teamed on this in terms of the need for some either comprehensive or baseline or whatever you want to talk--call it in terms of the framework.

But then if you think about an umbrella, there are these little pieces that keep the umbrella solid. And under that, maybe some of the issues that we'll talk about today, which are cloud computing applications, healthcare applications, et cetera. But we've got to unpack why we even have not even opened the umbrella wide enough to figure out how to get the type of bipartisan support. So with me today are three folks that I consider to be just wonderful people, generally. I have known them for most of my life here in DC, but also, they've got something to say and I want them to share it from the Brookings stage.

So I'm going to start at the bottom. She's not an unfamiliar face here at Brookings and she's got a new job. Amie Stepanovich is now the executive director at Silicon Flatirons where she is a nationally recognized expert before then and now in domestic surveillance, cybersecurity and privacy law. Before that, she was the U.S. policy manager and global policy counsel to Access Now. And now in Boulder where she has a much better view than those of us in DC--you know, I had to ask her. Look how relaxed she looks compared to all of us. Right? She's actually moving that forward in terms of privacy, and we'll hear more about her in this new role in a few minutes. Let's give her a round of applause.

(APPLAUSE)

Morgan is another friend, and he's somebody that I used to see often at the oil change place.

(LAUGHTER)

Because we live in the same neighborhood. He's the president of the act--the act--of act, the App Association, where he represents more than 5000 app makers and connected devices in the mobile economy. He leads the organization's advocacy and strategy on behalf of small to medium-size businesses on policy issues such as privacy, intellectual property, competition, and small business innovation. Let's give him a round of applause.

(APPLAUSE)

And Jamie. And we've actually had the opportunity to sit on a panel together as well. Another friend. She began her career at CTA as a director of government affairs in 2014 and was promoted to senior director in 2017. Her current scope includes policy expertise on self-driving vehicles, transportation innovation, and privacy. And before that, she served in the Washington DC office of Representative Bill Schuster, representative from Pennsylvania and the then chairman of the House Transportation Infrastructure Committee. Let's give her a round of applause.

(APPLAUSE)

David Young, there's a seat for you up here.

(LAUGHTER)

Call him out since we have no ushers. It's not like church. So let me jump into this first question. I told you there a feisty group starting with myself, okay?

UNKNOWN: (OFF-MIC)

LEE: Yeah, right. No collection. We will not have a collection plate at Brookings. So it may start this first question with this panel. Why has this dialogue sort of been extended since I think many people in this room probably heard about the need for privacy legislation following the perfect storm of Cambridge Analytica, right? But prior to that, there's been discussions. But why has it been so long, and really for this audience, who is probably following this, how has the debate changed over the last six months? You know, what are the--what are the stakes now compared to six month ago? Amie, why don't we start with you. And let people know, again, a little bit more about your organization.

STEPANOVICH: Sure. So six months ago I was actually still in DC working on the privacy legislation conversations. That changed about three months ago. I moved to Boulder, Colorado and took over Silicon Flatirons, which is--I'm going to be a little bit biased here, probably one of the preeminent tech think tanks at a law school in the country. We worked on tech policy convening's, student development, and entrepreneurship outreach. And so I have been leading some of the work that we've been doing outside of Silicon Flatirons.

But previous to that, I was deeply involved in some of the conversations that are happening in DC around privacy. And if I were to answer Nicol's question about why that has stalled out, I think one of the reasons is we never got a vehicle. People were waiting for--there were so many laws. I can count on two hands the number of privacy proposals or bills or principles that I saw. But there is this promise of a bipartisan draft law that everybody thought was going to be the one that everybody kind of bought into and tried to make better and was going to move forward. And we never got the language on that. And I think one of the reasons for that is people--the privacy issue continues to evolve. The CCPA is now concrete.

LEE: Yeah, and for those of you--that's the California Privacy Act.

STEPANOVICH: The California--yes.

LEE: That's pending.

STEPANOVICH: The California consumer privacy act is kind of moving into implementation at the beginning of next year. The news stories around privacy keep coming out and people keep realizing that it impacts different communities and different categories of people and different ways. And every time that story develops, a new member of Congress decides that they have to be involved in these conversations and be included in the room, which means you have to wrap in their staff and get them up to speed and get them to buy in to what's being produced, and that takes a lot of time.

I will say I don't think it's that thing that we are at this point. It means that we are listening to more people. We're taking in more perspectives. It does mean that people may not be happy with the fact that the California law is going to go into effect. But again, I personally don't think that's a bad thing, having more protections, having companies look into how to apply those protections in the United States. So I think the conversation continues to move. People continue to show that they are interested and involved, and we will eventually see a federal privacy law. Is it going to be next year in an election year? Probably not. But the--it's to be continued. It's not stopped.

LEE: Yeah. Morgan, let me run to you and ask you that question.

REED: So I think one of the fascinating parts, you said six months, but I see Aaron Burstein (PH) sitting here in the audience and I remember when he was 12 years--10 years ago working on the green paper, which was a comprehensive privacy legislation. And then you ended up at the FTC for a while, again, pushing comprehensive privacy legislation. And there's a well-known think tank/advocate advocacy group here in DC where I think they must've had a swear jar in their office that you put money in every time you didn't mention the word conference of privacy legislation. I think we all know which group I'm talking about. Three letters.

(LAUGHTER)

So it's not as though this topic hasn't been at the forefront for more than a decade. The underlying--a lot of the underlying problem comes down to what happens in most of these cases that, depending on how the language is crafted, there will be winners and losers. And so there is a sense that legislation that puts its thumb on one side of the scale or the other is going to meet fierce opposition. Amie was mentioning something that we've all lived through where you get close to a draft and then some and he comes in the room at the last minute. And she can tell that story better that I can later, but comes in at the last minute and says oh, I just have three words. You know, and the reality is with comprehensive privacy legislation, I think we all have to be clear eyed about that reality.

I think the reason you said the six months is I think consumers are becoming a bit more clear eyed about the value of their information and where they sit in the marketplace. And I think that with the GDPR, that's the European version of conference a privacy legislation, with California, with the attempt in Washington state with facial recognition, I think it's--it's the consumer now that is in a different position, and I think. And I think, before I handed over, I think one of the last parts is for the first time we are now seeing market competition around privacy. I don't think anyone can deny that Apple has made a decision to market on privacy. Their CEO has sent letters. They've put that statement out there that we are betting our purchasers of our products want this message.

So I'd say one, winners and losers are going to make some decisions different. Two, I think the consumers have a better sense of the value of their product. And three, I think you see companies making an active decision to speak to consumers about their privacy and why it has value. So I think that's why the conversation has changing, and will get to a little bit more on CCP afterwards.

LEE: Yeah. Yeah.

REED: But that's what I'd go with.

LEE: Jamie, what do you think?

BOONE: Sure, yeah. Morgan and Amie both made really, really good points that I generally agree with. You know, last year we started really having this conversation on why we needed federal privacy legislation between GDPR and then CCPA moving. There was a lot of pressure and a lot of pressure not just from consumers, but also from industry for that clarity at the federal level. You know, it comes to an election, you have, you know, a flip in the House, you have a lot of new staff, you have--and Senate Commerce, you have new chairman and a new ranking member, all staff that needs to get, you know, engaged in a conversation. In the House you have a flip, you know, and all of the leadership and you have to wait for people to get staffed up. So you know, that takes six months just to get people caught up in making sure that they're having all of the right meetings with the right people and getting that input.

I think another thing that is happened is that we've seen in the last, you know, last couple months there's been this pushback on tech in general and looking at liability with Section 230 and now antitrust and competition. I think privacy is maybe getting a little bit lost in that shuffle where we have all these really big topics and big issues all relating to tech. And while I'd argue most--a lot of them have to do with a lot more than just tech and especially privacy impacts a lot more than just tech companies, I think a lot of those things are getting kind of conflated and it just gets messier, especially when you have a lot of committees with overlapping or fighting over jurisdiction of who gets to do what and who needs to be in the room when it gets very messy, which it makes it harder.

LEE: Yeah, you know, I want to actually stay on that for just a second, if you don't mind, and maybe get some reaction from Morgan and Amie. I mean, are we seeing, like, this blurred line or this fuzziness now? Because it does appear like in the last six months there has been a lot of press towards, you know, big tech shakeup in these--you know, the presidential campaigns have sort of made it their business. Interestingly enough, do not just necessarily just take privacy, but take a whole range of tech issues and sort of put them in the same bucket. How do we sort of un-tease out of that or unpack out of those discussions that privacy is still pretty important?

STEPANOVICH: You want to just--

(LAUGHTER)

Why don't you start?

REED: So--

LEE: --You need this, probably, to start.

REED: Right, well, no--

STEPANOVICH: --I get to play cleanup--

LEE: --Collaboration.

REED: So I think one of the problems is, and I--and I think it's a bit of laziness, we tend to lump tech into one phrase. But the reality is is that retail is tech. In fact, we'll talk about it on CCPA a little bit. I mean, retail has affinity cards and they have huge quantity of data. And so retail is tech. And there's this interesting divide. There's a tendency to lump Facebook, Google, Apple, all of them together, but it was interesting on the--I testified before the House Judiciary Committee, Subcommittee on Antitrust, and we were all on the panel. It was Amazon and Apple and Facebook and Google and--and I was there, and Tim Wu and we all went down the line and it was funny.

By the end of the hearing, it was--I think it was Senator--Congressman Armstrong who was like oh, Apple. Yeah, we'll ask you some questions, but you haven't been really part of the discussion, because they were focused on some of these privacy questions that were coming up. And it was interesting how what was happening as they were asking these privacy questions, they were asking questions about well, what are you doing with data?

LEE: Right.

REED: And the Apple person was like well, we don't really use it. And then other, you know, so each person had kind of had their own niche. So I think one of it is there's a tendency to lump everybody together and I think that's a mistake. That's a mistake in terms of how we talk about it. And two, I think that to tease it out gets to the key factor, which is look, we're talking about your information and your personal assessment of what its value is both to you and in the marketplace. What are you willing to provide to somebody who collects data in exchange for a service?

And I think that's--that's the tease out. Are you good with that exchange? And then I know you deal with this too, which is do you think people understand what that exchange is? The privacy policies even--look, you were talking about earlier about reading them. I don't know the privacy policies are the methodology to get--to help people understand that exchange, sometimes.

STEPANOVICH: I mean, I think privacy policies have been written over time in a way that takes the power away from people being able to--I think the we could get there and there's been a lot of, particularly academic conversations about what a privacy policy needs to entail and what it needs to be shown and--

LEE: --Right. Right--

STEPANOVICH: --But I don't think that they are written now in a way that allow people to have any idea what information they are turning over, what it could be used for, how long it's going to be held. It's just as a sophisticated user of technology, I have no idea half the time. So I--people who don't spend their days--their day jobs reading privacy policies, I have no hope for. And I, like--

LEE: --It's true--

STEPANOVICH: --And it's not on their fault.

LEE: Right. Right.

STEPANOVICH: It's just everything is stacked against them. To your point though, I think a lot of these conversations stem from common feelings. I've been manipulated, I've been abused, I have had my either information or interacted with a company or store or platform that has taken advantage of me. And so all of these tech conversations kind of stem out of common feelings, and maybe we do need to separate them back out. But in a way, this is going to be a very unpopular point of view, this is like a slight pitch, we maybe need to bring them together a little bit because there's a little bit of the solution in each of these conversations toward the overall issue of manipulation on the Internet. And once we start pulling that in, like when you talk about the "fake news or misinformation" situation, that's a societal problem.

LEE: Right.

STEPANOVICH: It's not really a tech problem. And so we have to kind of pull out and think what are the little things that we can do that move us forward across the space. Now, those each have their own incredibly nuanced conversations, but pulling out might actually help a little bit in this.

LEE: Yeah. Yeah, I mean that's why I've been using this analogy of the umbrella with the spokes, right? Because I think part of what's happened in this conversation for me in the last six months is that the spokes are becoming more defined. And since there are so many of them, everybody sort of pitching and what they think this spoke should be on it, and it's gone beyond the traditional conversations we had about consent framework and, you know, data metallization mitigation, it's--it's going to bias and discrimination and this and that. But I do have a question because none of you have actually set it in the first 10 minutes of this panel, which is the word preemption. And so I'm curious to see if that conversation has gotten better or worse in the last six months, before we go into more details on how we actually get to some type of federal privacy legislation.

BOONE: Yeah, I don't know that it's moved a whole lot. I think that, you know, everyone has kind of got there--kind of in their corners as we were talking about earlier on the preemption question. I think this just happens. It's not unique to privacy. It happens in--

LEE: --Everything, right--

BOONE: --A lot of things especially everything. Give me an issue that--and I'll find some way to relate preemption to it. But we are now looking in California, right, and they've just closed out their legislative session. We'll start to see, you know, what the AG does with it in the next year what implementation looks like. I think that makes this whole conversation harder that we've gotten so far down the road with California by itself because you've got, you know, just looking at the politics of it, you've got the speaker of the House, California, you've got huge delegation from California, primarily, that you know, our Democrats and generally will want to support their state and their state's law. How do you reconcile that in the House and get it--something through the House that preempts California but doesn't, in a way.

LEE: Right.

BOONE: Right? And then that same thing then get through a Republican Senate. I think the politics on that are really hard. So you know, we were just discussing how you--how do you move toward each other in the preemption question? And I don't know how you do that without us seeing something to react to on paper--

LEE: --Yeah--

BOONE: To get people to come to the table--

LEE: --Go ahead, one more reaction to this because we've got 20 plus states.

STEPANOVICH: Sure. So for those of you who don't know, and this is DC, I'm not going to forget that I'm back in DC, but preemption is the conversation around the degree of federal laws going to write over state law. And the reason that is really unhelpful that people have kind of gone into their corners is because broad preemption, which a lot of people say, like, we just need preemption, we need to preempt all the state laws, could impact so much broader than that see CPA. It could go after civil rights law, it could go after abortion law, it could go after anything that kind of comes into the realm of privacy. And so you--even the people who I think really want broad preemption don't necessarily want the broadest of preemption.

On the other side, you could have no preemption at all, which could allow people to pass laws that conflict outright at the state and the federal level. So even on the side, nobody goes all the way to the end. I think they at least want basic conflict preemption. They want a federal law that, to the extent that it conflicts with state law, one standard will take over. And then between those two layers, there are 50,000 other options and nobody has dug in to figure out where they need to be. And we were talking--you've heard many illusions. We had a really in-depth conversation about preemption before we came out here--

LEE: --I know. I was like please save some of this for the panel.

(LAUGHTER)

STEPANOVICH: But unless we start talking about what a real problems preemption is needed to solve and have really honest conversations, that conversation won't go any further. And getting back to my first point, that won't probably happen until we have a vehicle with actual language that allows people to dig into those issues and feel like they're not giving up on their position. And until then, it's going to be hard core digging into the ground and just waiting to see what happens.

LEE: Right. But I mean, I--I've got to just--as you answer, Morgan, I mean, we knew about California before California became California. We knew this law was coming and I think I had a coin toss with some friends in the EU who talked about they said do you think we're going to have federal privacy legislation before California? I thought I was going to win, but I'm not, right? Clearly. So--

REED: Yeah, I--I--I always have to remember that nobody does anything until basically, you know, you're waking up and looking at the rope in the morning, right? it's--it's that kind of instinct that lives in DC of oh, we'll put it off and put it off, we'll put it off. I think though, there are two things. One of the things that came out of GDPR that still to this day is a bit of a problem and CCPA, and one of the reasons why preemption is important is even when there's areas that are true conflict, you can have overlapping requirements or overlapping build outs. And those favor larger institutions with larger collections of lawyers.

When you have a conversation, you know, working in the health space, which is what I lot of what I do on the health privacy space, it's very easy for large institutions to say well, first, you need to do DPO and then you need to have all of this documentation on how you're doing privacy by design on your health product, and then you need to do a complete six-month survey of your--of your data handling on--on--on health records. And mind you, this is before you ever stricken a single line of code, before you've written any part of your product, you have to--your first hire is not a programmer, it's a lawyer.

And that works in a large institution where it may be your health product is a skunk works project and you are borrowing from your--you're going to go to your general counsel and say hey, I need a--an FTE to work on this. But you are--if a five man start up who's making a product that a, it's a figures out a way to solve diabetic retinopathy, you probably got five MD PhD's focused on the problem and their first hire is not a doctor. So in some cases, the preemption question is not--is not strictly about aisle, you know, shoveling off liability risk, which I think some people do, they use preemption to push that off, but it's also, even when the law isn't truly conflicting where it creates multiple requirements. I often find that my larger company of friends are much more comfortable with that event my smaller company members who started as a hold on, what all do I have to do? So I think Amie's point about everybody coming to the table, and I think there's probably two elements to this, we talked preemption, the other one is private right of action.

LEE: Yeah.

REED: And those two things are the anchor points of this fight where I don't think you're going to have a lot of people coming to the table. We talked about this earlier, all of us, about the fact that we all know in DC one of the things that happens is you don't want to give something up that you might want to give up later in the negotiation process. So preemption and private right of action are the ace cards, the--the--whatever you call it, the card that you're holding onto that you're not--

STEPANOVICH: --Trump card--

REED: --Trump card really, yeah.

LEE: He said he wasn't going to say it.

(LAUGHTER)

And I understand your point about using the--the value framework, but I don't think that I, as a white guy, should tell people who aren't like me how they should make determinations. And I want to be very careful of not being too diminishing.

LEE: So I'll help you--I'll help you because I'm a black woman.

REED: That's right. That's why I'm like--

LEE: --(INAUDIBLE) and I'm going to tell you why. I think--so Morgan, I think you're outnumbered on this one.

REED: That's fine. I'll lose. Like I said, I'm trying to be careful.

LEE: Let me--let me just--I'll share--but I'll give you a little bit of credit on something. So I think the question, and I'll wrap it up with this. I think the question is well-intentioned, right, because I think at the end of the day, the fundamental framework around any privacy conversations around the good stewardship on both the receiver and the recipient in this ecology, right, I want to know when I give my data it's done for good purpose, much like when we go to a bank and we give our money to the teller, we want to know that it's going into the vault and not into their pocket, right?

But when you talk about the valuation of data that what I, particularly among disparate groups or different types of people, you do run the risk of exploitation. And it already happens. I mean Henrietta Lacks, who some of you know about, gave up her information for a long time, helped to serve a lot of curable diseases and was never paid for it and died an indigent. And that's partly because we don't have in the society, it kind of goes back to what Amie said, the values that operate on the principle that all data is created equal and we don't have a system, which is why we're talking about privacy legislation that not only is all data created equal, but in some respects, all data carries a currency that is valuable to the person and not something that should be used and exploited and manipulated for other purposes.

And that's where I would leave it, Morgan. I think that even though people are on smart phones even though, for health reasons, they should be paid $0.10 for, you know, blood pressure prick in their arm doesn't mean that we want them walking around with 10,000 pricks in their arm just because somebody took advantage of them because they were going to be paid $0.50. Not having food is being hungry, and that's another issue that should not be solved by our ability to evaluate people's data. There's no currency in that. So with that, you can see why this is a difficult conversation to have, but one that we need to have, right? I want to thank the panelists. Let's give them a round of applause.

(APPLAUSE)

I hope that all of you take away from this that this is not the last privacy panel that you're going to go to, and I also hope that you take away from this that the issues, again, of the umbrella that we're dealing with have many spokes, and we will soon get there. Let's thank Amie for coming all the way from Boulder to visit us.

(APPLAUSE)

Thank you again, everyone.
