Brookings Institution Holds Discussion On Digital Technology In The Age Of Artificial Intelligence

March 29, 2019 10:30 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

BROOKINGS INSTITUTION PROJECT ON INTERNATIONAL ORDER AND STRATEGY SENIOR FELLOW TED PICCONE

HAGUE DEPUTY MAYOR SASKIA BRUINES

DELFT UNIVERSITY OF TECHNOLOGY ETHICS AND TECHNOLOGY PROFESSOR JEROEN VAN DEN HOVEN

BROOKINGS INSTITUTION ANN R. AND ANDREW H. TISCH DISTINGUISHED VISITING FELLOW CAMERON KERRY

ELECTRONIC PRIVACY INFORMATION CENTER FELLOW-IN-RESIDENCE BILYANA PETKOVA

CENTER FOR TECHNOLOGY INNOVATION GOVERNANCE STUDIES FELLOW NICOL TURNER LEE

[*]PICCONE: Good morning, everyone. Am I on, can you hear me okay? Great. My name is Ted Piccone. I'm a Senior Fellow in the Foreign Policy Program. I work on international order and strategy issues, among other things.

And a warm welcome to everyone here and to all of those who are watching us via our live webcast online for our sixth annual Justice Stephen Breyer Lecture on International Law. This series of transatlantic dialogue tackles cutting edge issues at the intersection of international law, security and increasingly, technology.

Over the last few years, we've used this occasion to examine such issues as cross-border data sharing for law enforcement and the role of international law in governing new tools of warfare, such as autonomous weapons. And all of that material is on our website.

We want to thank, first of all, the Municipality of the Hague, and The Embassy of the Netherlands for their steadfast support and partnership for this work and to Justice Breyer for his steady and thoughtful leadership on matters of international and comparative law. He is occupied with court business today.

For this year's lecture, we've chosen to examine an issue that really lacks an international normative standard or a multilateral process. And that is the protection of one's data and privacy online, an issue that directly affects anyone with an Email account, a Facebook profile or smart phone.

The timing for this discussion could not be better. The European Union is coming upon the one-year anniversary of its general data protection regulation, otherwise known as GDPR. This new rule requires any organization that holds or controls the personal data of E.U. residence to obtain clear customer consent and to build privacy by design as the default option for their organizations. And companies face large penalties for any serious breaches. And we'll hear a lot more about how GDPR implementation is going, this morning.

On the U.S. side, we are hearing much greater public discussion and congressional debate over the adoption of privacy and data protection legislation. These include proposals to grant greater authority to the Federal Trade Commission, to protect consumers from unfair or deceptive practices which, of course, includes upholding their promises to protect our personal information.

As these debates, and we've seen a number of big data breaches in the past couple of years, as these continue, some states in the U.S. are not waiting for federal action. California, for example has adopted a consumer privacy act that gives residents the right to know what personal data is collected, how it is handled and to say "no" to its sale to others.

Of course, this is a big issue elsewhere outside of the United States. Other countries such as Brazil, Australia, India, Russia and China are considering their own protocols for data protection, many of which will not be so friendly to U.S. interest and our values and freedom of expression, the right to access information and protection of national security.

Meanwhile, technology doesn't sleep. Companies and researchers are racing ahead with the development of artificial intelligence and machine learning, the Internet of things, for example, that is already opening new frontiers in the way our personal data is collected and marketed to others.

So, one of the key questions we hope to consider today, is how society should proactively govern the onslaught of these new digital technologies as they collect and process and repurpose our personal data and whether this can and should be done at the international level or be left to national authorities to sort out their own choices and, of course, we might end up with a very smorgasbord of options that start conflicting and clashing with one another.

To help us understand these complex and fast-moving developments, we've invited a top-notch panel of European and American experts from the world of ethics, law, international relations and sociology, for today's discussion.

Our keynote lecture will be given by Professor Jeroen Van Den Hoven from the Netherlands. Dr. Van Den Hoven is University Professor of Ethics and Technology at Delft University of Technology and Editor in Chief of the Journal Ethics and Information Technology. Among his many titles and awards, Professor Van Den Hoven was the program chair of the Dutch Research Program on Responsible Innovation and is currently a permanent member of the Ethics and New Technology Advisory Group for the President of the European Commission.

After his remarks, he will be joined for a panel discussion with three leading experts to share a comparative perspective on different U.S. and European approaches to data protection and privacy.

Cameron Kerry, a distinguished Fellow here at the Brookings Governance Program is the former General Counsel and Acting Secretary of the U.S. Department of Commerce.

Bilyana Petkova is a visiting Fellow at the Electronic Privacy Information Center here in Washington and Assistant Professor with the Department of International and European Law at Maastricht University of Law in the Netherlands.

And our moderator, Dr. Nicol Turner Lee, is a fellow in the Governance Studies Program here, Center for Technology Innovation, and a leading voice in promoting equal opportunity and civil rights in the digital technology and telecommunications industries.

You have more information from their impressive bios in your handout. We encourage you to tweet your own thoughts, using the hashtag Breyer Lecture, and look forward to your questions to the panel later, in the program.

Before we hear from Jeroen, I would like to invite Saskia Bruines, the Deputy Mayor of The Hague to make some introductory remarks. After many years as Deputy Mayor for culture and information technology in Amsterdam, she now leads the city of Hague's work on education, the knowledge economy and international affairs.

Thank you.

BRUINES: Good morning ladies and gentlemen. It's great to be here. Thank you very well, thank you very much for well, for inviting me to be here. And it's my pleasure to welcome you also on the behalf of the city of The Hague.

You may be familiar with The Hague as a city of peace and justice. And I'm delighted to represent our city here today, and share our ideas on a vastly important subject. Let me use a short quote to explain why this is so important. It's a quote from 2017 and it is by a very famous state leader and he said, "Artificial intelligence is the future for all mankind. Whoever becomes the leader in this sphere will become the ruler of the world." His name, Vladimir Putin, President of Russian Federation.

This world leadership to which Putin referred is, obviously, an extremely appealing prospect, not just for Russia, but equally for China, the United States, for example. And besides, this geopolitical game, we have to reckon with the enormous influence from companies like Huawei, Cisco, Facebook and many others. Companies that are able to launch brilliant invasions innovations on the markets but which, also, have daily access to privacy sensitive information.

Using this information companies can influence the lives of their customers and governments can influence the lives of their residents every day. And the question we face is whether the rights of all those customers and citizens are properly protected.

Isn't it time for fair global, ethical and legal rules regarding the use of data and AI? Rules that allow us to protect individual rights and freedom and that allow us to more effectively apply AI for the greater good. For example, in achieving the global sustainable development goals or in smart city programs, to provide better services to citizens in growing citizens like in Washington, D.C. and The Hague.

Or applying data analysis to provide emergency aid more effectively and cheaply and thus, reach even more people in the wake of natural disasters. And by making the source of violent conflicts visible through the use of data thus promoting peace and justice, worldwide.

You might wonder why the city of The Hague is addressing such issues. This is because The Hague has embraced the development of international law for over a hundred years. Our peace palace is a wonderful icon in that respect. In a way, it is the very heart of our city. And of course, there are many, many more cities that contribute daily to creating a better world.

But we'd like to use our position as a city of peace and justice to stimulate the further developments of law. So that together, we can work towards creating equal rights and equal opportunities, also online.

In my own country, the national government will present a comprehensive strategy for the use of data and AI later this year. And the European Union is also focusing on this, also thanks to the efforts of committed tough leaders like Jeroen Van Den Hoven.

And the wake of these developments the Netherlands aims to become the European hotspot for AI development in Europe. As a result, more and more parties are being attracted to our city. For example, for many years we have been home to NATO's communications and information agency.

The U.N. Interregional Crime and Justice Research Institute made a conscious choice to base its Centre for Artificial Intelligence and Robotics, called CAIR, in The Hague.

And I'm happy to announce that here, that the umbrella organization of over 7,000 European AI researchers called CLAIRE, will soon be basing its head office in our city.

As a city of peace and justice, we see a role for ourselves as an honest broker. A city where many people work together to develop the law and encourage the peaceful responsible use of data, AI and robotics.

In our city, The Hague, more than 2,000 institutes, universities, think-tanks, NGOs and companies work together for market leader to startups and to take a science initiative, for example, we combine tough issues facing organizations with the smart knowledge of startups and which always produce applicable answers.

The Hague, therefore, welcomes you and everyone who is working on this topic with open arms to join us in further developing the law and working to what's fair, just and peaceful societies.

Thank you very much.

(APPLAUSE)

VAN DEN HOVEN: Good morning. It's a great pleasure to be here and to be able to address you with some introductory remarks on global governance and ethics of artificial intelligence and it's great to be part of that wonderful operation in The Hague. And I shall come back and forth between The Hague and Delft in the middle and then, to Brussels and I'm the permanent member of this committee advises the European commission on innovation and new technologies.

And we've produced this report. But I will be speaking as a private person, as an academic not as a member of that group, today. So, I will need some 25 minutes and I hope that the chairman grants me those 25 minutes.

I think we're all on the same page whether it's from the corporate world or from the public world. So, the commission has said the stakes couldn't be higher. The way we approach AI will define the world we live in. And I think that's a very important theme to bear in mind that we are going to use this technology to express our ideals, and to express our values and that will come back to shape us again. I will come back to that topic.

But you know when something really special is happening when Henry Kissinger is actually thinking about these things and even from an ethical and philosophical perspective, he said, "Philosophically-intellectually in every way, human society is unprepared for the rise of artificial intelligence," in a paper called How the Enlightenment Ends.

Well, how does AI accomplish all of that? First, we started out in the '50s and then, '70s, to think that the expertise of thinking and understanding and cognition was in rules. So, we started to make explicit and write down all the rules of all the medical experts and the chemical experts. You see an example there, and this is an example from health care, from medicine., Only to find out it's not located in hundred, not even in thousand rules. It's somewhere else. new it's an evanescent quality and, if we talk about AI now, we talk about these kind of architectures, completely different architectures, not rule based, not following logic. It's subsymbolic. It's not put in concepts, neat concepts and in logical rules but it's in something like our brain, right.

And it learns like our brain. It adjusts itself on the basis of inputs to produce particular outputs and we can train it up as we train up a baby.

The interesting thing to note is, here, these things are very complex and they are even so complex, and I'll come back to that because it has ethical consequences, so complex that the people who craft them and make them don't understand them, actually.

So, this is all wonderful. You can do great things with it. You know, it can help you to distinguish your dog from a muffin.

(LAUGHTER)

So, that's wonderful, it can also help you to become a GO: World Champion. That's a formidable very impressive experience and Google DeepMind has done that.

So, what is at stake with this extremely powerful technology that gobbles up and uses all the data to learn about patterns, structures, to optimize to make processes more efficient. It can do that with satellite images, with nautical images. It can do it in industry context. It can do it in hospital context. It can do it, look for vulnerabilities in cyber security systems, etc.

So, it's a quite generic technology. What's at stake? Well, as the Deputy Mayor already pointed out, some people have started to appreciate this and not always in ways that we appreciate it. But I mean, I'll leave that to you or to the panel discussion.

This is what's happening and we know that there is a battle going on between China, Russia and the United States and I will come back to others, as well. And we know what China is doing. It's applying all of this stuff to better face recognition, to more efficient and effective surveillance technologies. It's using citizen scores to keep tabs on their populations and is also doing the same thing in the new digital scramble for Africa. It's rolling out software there and it's also sucking up a lot of data there.

We know what the Americans have been doing, what you and we have all been doing and we have and Europe have been benefiting from, also, to a certain extent. And there is not only a big tech development, there's also a little bit of a tech, a big tech lash, you know, so were now starting to criticize and question all the data that we have freely given to those big companies to serve us for all kinds of wonderful conveniences that were very happy to buy but now, you know, we have some second thoughts about that. And we'll come back to it.

So, the big question is, where is Europe going in all of this? It's clear what the Chinese picture is. It's clear what the U.S. picture is. It's clear what the Russia picture is. I don't know how to qualify that more but, in any case, the question is what is Europe doing? Is Europe to be the Museum of the world at some time, as suggested, or is it perhaps the cradle of new enlightenment and enlightenment 2.0?

It's interesting to look at what was said in a press release of this European plan is the biggest plan, also an investment plan. For the E.U., it's not so much a question of winning or losing a race between the U.S.A and China but of finding the way of embracing the opportunities offered by AI in a way that is human centered, ethical, secure and true to our core values.

So, it seems that there is a third way, you know, this is not Chinese way this is U.S. American way which is driven by Silicon Valley but also by the Pentagon so it's working on two cylinders, right.

And there could be a third way. And Macron has already experimented with this two years ago when he released his big plan with a couple of billion of euros, real money. He's putting his money where his mouth is. It was spearheaded by a top mathematician Fields winner, Cedric Villani, and he referred to it as AI for humanity.

So, the third way could be AI for humanity. But it's interesting to bear in mind that images of man and models of society get expressed in your AI technology and again, once that has been done, it will come back and shape us, again.

And we know that pattern. And this is a very interesting book. It's about Oriental Despotism a Comparative Study of Total Power, Karl Wittfogel, '57, 1957. And he shows how civil engineering and water management were the basis of the power of many of the ancient oriental empires and it dictated and suggested how their society should be run, namely top-down, centralistic. Otherwise, you could never do this. You would have large-scale forced labor, etc.

So, that's a very interesting way. It's now, not longer about hydraulic empires, it's about digital empire building.

You could do it in very simple ways. You know, this is more efficient. If you don't want people to sleep on those benches in the park, it's more efficient to do it this way than to have hundred people running around and chasing people away. But there is also the more, you know, digital version of this.

And this is algorithms. Algorithms shape our behavior as the steel rods on the benches in the parks do. It's very true, and I've already said it in a couple of ways, we shape our buildings and, thereafter, our buildings shape us. We shape our digital societies and then our digital societies start to shape us.

So, in the case of China, what gets expressed? It's called socialism with Chinese characteristics. It's autocracy and party rule. It's ubiquitous surveillance, filtering and firewalls instead of investing in deliberative tools, of deliberative democracy, privacy enhancing technology. It's working with citizen scores. It's working with the idea of social harmony instead of the human rights discourse.

And already in the Human Rights Council, there are attempts to replace those terms of human rights by the idea, conveniently vague as it is, of social harmony.

So, the model of man that is lying underneath that is a kind of a strange mixture of behaviorism, you know, sticks and carrots and keeping tabs on what people do by means of big data and machine learning and actually punishing and rewarding people, in order to make them behave in the right way. So that's AI for control.

In the USA, it's Silicon Valley in the driver seat, innovative in the grey zone, move fast, break things first, apologize later.

(LAUGHTER)

Regulatory aloofness when it comes to the governance of technology, Chicago school economics, austere individualism, libertarian values, and the model of man is Homo Economicus AI for profit.

And then, we have Europe which takes its start from the European charter of fundamental rights and the European convention of human rights, open liberal democracies and rule of law, multilateralism and the focus on international legal order and global justice., Opportunities for AI to reach the U.N. sustainable development goals, Rhineland model of corporate governance, strong regulation by competition law and data protection, the model of man being a Kantian enlightenment conception of the moral of the person and Homo Socialis. AI for humanity. We still have a couple of seats in Europe available so, if you interested, you can join us.

But a recent document in the E.U., External Action Service, referred to China as a systemic rival whose engagement with the world of norms, rules and multilateral organizations is selective, at best. But bear in mind that we're all systemic rivals in this sense. We are using comprehensive ideas of what the good life is for our citizens, what is--what is the best way to arrange our societies and expressing it in digital technology. And AI is functioning as this huge systems integrator. It's making a lot of those ambitions possible.

Think of, in the case of China, the global financial system and think of the renminbi as the reserve currency or the new silk route or the military buildup or the science and technology programs or the industrial program, made in China 2025.

And then this final piece, replacing human rights discourse by the idea of social harmony. You could get nowhere with these large ambitions if you wouldn't have top notch digital technology with AI. You could simply not do that.

So, it looks as if we're moving to a multipolar interregnum, where we have competing conceptions of what the good life is, what a society should look like and what man is and work from that. So, what is that, what are the building blocks for this third way, from this European perspective? I am going to share some--some thoughts that I have, also as a result of being a lot in Brussels and talking to people of the commission. Again, I'm not representing the commission but I'm just sharing those thoughts with you.

The first building block is this ethics by design that is becoming more and more important. No longer getting a book from the shelf in your library and read Kant and Aristotle and John Stuart Mill. It is looking at the technology and expressing your ideas and your values in it.

The top legal advisor of the European Commission said, in order to protect and strengthen Western liberal democracies in the age of AI, and the core Trinitarian idea of human rights, rule of law and democracy, we need and I quote "a new culture of technology and business development which we call human rights, rule of law and democracy by design."

He is the single handedly responsible or, at least, has had a major influence in the drafting of the GDPR.

Same for Buttarelli, who is the European Data Protection Supervisor, recently organized the mother of all privacy conferences and European Parliament in Brussels. Again, putting centerstage digital ethics by design.

So, we will have to deal with a lot of this, right, a lot of technologies on the left-hand side, a lot of values on the right-hand side and we have to bring those together. We would have to be able to think, in quite some detail, about deep learning and human dignity, about a block chain and sustainability.

So, we have to bring together those worlds of the social sciences, the humanities and engineering. These are the examples.

So, this is the key problem of what we call value sensitive design on the left-hand side, we have all of those values that we think are very important and on the right-hand side, we have the world of engineering and technology and we want to express our ideas in those technologies and be able to explain what that was a good idea and that we did a good job.

So, I think that the coming back to the geopolitics of it is what I see how is that there are new arguments to look for a deeper kind of trans-Atlantic relationship on the basis of which we can become a little bit more pragmatic--

TURNER LEE: --Yes, yes.

VAN DEN HOVEN: -- about, you know, the nitty-gritty details of how we deal with these things because we--it turns out we have, perhaps, more in common than we have these agreements, although these agreements are real. But there's, perhaps, a higher purpose. And mutatis mutandis that could apply actually everyone on the. But so, we could, perhaps, start here.

So, that--that's one thing I would say. And I've always found people at the (UNTRANSLATED) of the European data protection supervisor very, you know, very reasonable in this respect, open to--to debates also with--with the U.S. don't forget, they're really thinking about the next move after the GDPR.

So, this conference they had in European Parliament, this the mother of all privacy conferences was already thinking about digital ethics, you know, because the ink is hardly dry on the GDPR. And they're already thinking about, okay, what's wrong with it? How can we improve it? I think we will see a paradigm shift in the long run where we have to give up on some of the core concepts of GDPR, by private opinion, but it's, for example, you know, informed consent purpose specification, use limitation.

Even the notion of a personal data. You know, all of these can--the key concepts may--may be the wrong way and not be sustainable for the rest of remainder of the 21st century. So, we have to, without giving up on the protection of individuals, that--that remains a big concern.

So, the other thing I wanted to say response to you was that actually I very much like this idea that your--your suggestion there is just a lot of democratic local experimentation going on as a source of innovation. And so, so we have people here trying to come to grips with a particular problem. They do it in their own way. They--they draw upon resources that are not accessible to others.

TURNER LEE: Right.

VAN DEN HOVEN: And they may come up with really interesting suggestions that could be leveraged in and used on a federal or on a--on a higher level. So, that is something that you don't want to lose, I would say. That's a very interesting, you know, set resources that--that a system may have.

TURNER LEE: So, Cam, I want to just, real quick to just jump to you though on that concept because the U.S. is actually trying to develop a federal umbrella. And if we look at the state of California as an experiment, there is a conversation on whether or not that experiment should impact what federal legislation looks like or vice versa, right.

And so, the question I have for you is, you know, are we going to see--you know, what is the effect of states like California implementing their own privacy legislation. There's already 50 states that have it. But, speak to us in the context of the U.S.

KERRY: Sure. Well, both GDPR and the California law--

TURNER LEE: --Yeah--

KERRY: -- are sort of powerful drivers for federal legislation for, I think, practically variety of reasons. I mean, certainly the drive to have federal preemption, a single standard, as the E.U. did with the GDPR and make a single market out of the U.S. is certainly there. But I think--I think the things that go beyond, as--I think a recognition that there is a trust gap that needs to be addressed and, you know, having a set of standards that level the playing field in terms of individual expectations would be a kind of seal of approval on--on company practices in--in handling data.

And--and I think, you know, as well as sort of for the U.S., you know, we, right now, we have no answer to the GDPR. And I think there's a recognition that, you know, we can't sort of go out into the discussion in the world and--and, you know, without a horse to--to ride, so to speak.

TURNER LEE: Right.

KERRY: And I think you know, also recognition alongside this that we do need to engage more. I mean, it's unfortunate T-TIP to translate Trade and Investment Partnership fell by the wayside because that was a vehicle to address, I think, a lot of the common digital economy issues and some of the regulatory barriers that could present Balkanization threats.

Unfortunately, you know, we see some of that, I think the new copyright directive may have some impacts towards that. We've seen some people make the decision that whatever business they had in the E.U. was not worth the regulatory cost of GDPR compliance. So, they've pulled out.

But, you know, we can, I think, get to common standards. And, you know, I think that that is part of the drive in--in federal legislation. And, you know, Bilyana quoted Heather Gerken talking about sort of state experimentation arriving in a point where it can be adopted as a national standard. Maybe California is that point.

TURNER LEE: Right, right. So, Bilyana, I want to go back to you just as we wrap up this part of it. And in a few minutes, I'm actually going to take Q and A from the audience, we'll have time for one or two questions. Again, remember to tweet if we don't get to your question, put it out there and the Twitter verse. We'll try to answer it.

So, looking ahead and looking globally given that these are out there, are there opportunities to do this sort of multilateral harmonization of these rules, in your view? Is this a conversation--we've heard some starting points, maybe there's something to be gleaned from GDPR, as well as, with the state of California? But is there something else we should be looking to get to that harmonization?

PETKOVA: Right. Well, certainly at first sight on the global level, one can observe a certain convergence that data prize these standards. To go back to Jeroen's point also about bridging these two worlds, the E.U. and the U.S., what Cam was saying.

So, this is triggered by adequacy requirement the pre-existing E.U. directive and now also in the GDPR. And Australia's (INAUDIBLE) Graham Greenleaf has found that there 20--120 countries right now that have enacted E.U. style data privacy laws, and 30 more are considering such bills.

So, as also Ted was mentioning more recently, Brazil enacted a statute called the general data protection regulation, and a comprehensive privacy statute that has looked for inspiration at the E.U. model is well on the way to the logistic process in India, after two court decisions there challenging massive national biometric identification system.

So, also Japan delete assigned adequacy decision on data protection with the E.U. commission, and in almost one year long negotiation process. So, finally also, we see also some privacy protections for the private sector in that country.

So, on the one hand, we see these convergence, however, the title is in the detail and it seems that there remain lot of divergencies in the concrete measures to be taken by the different countries that use the GDPR as a starting point, but still they are not replicating it. Each country is coming up with its own model.

So, I think aspirations for a global single standard will still face a lot of hurdles, essentially, someone needs to make it their lifelong project to work on that kind of standard. So, what are we left with in the immediate future?

So, one way forward could be that we see an attempt to extend the interoperability standard of what the privacy shield is, this framework for data exchanges is between the E.U. and U.S. an example of voluntary adheres to principles by companies and governments on a larger scale.

At the same time, we might also see some attempts for concretizing the interoperability and existing legal frameworks to joint enforcement actions. So, the GDPR, for example, explicitly favors this approach by giving what is known as the European data protection board, this body that is comprised of the data protection authorities of the cute 28 member states with the task of promoting exchange of knowledge and documentation with supervisory authorities worldwide.

So, that might be also one venue. And then, in addition, we see in the field of AI, for example, OECD, the organizations for--the Organization for Economic Corporation and Development basing parties that will come up in May with guidelines on AI. So, EPIC for example, has been heavily involved in that softball effort, which is important as it can serve for candidacy national legislation. So, civil society groups like the Electronic Information Privacy Center has also have weighed in in that process.

TURNER LEE: Yeah. So, this is so tough for me because those of you who know I moderate, I want more time because I think we have to really go into enforcement. But before I open up to, again one or two questions, I do have to sort of end my part of moderating privilege on this discussion of AI and emerging technologies, right.

So, we sort of talked about the framing of privacy, how we could potentially get to some level of harmonization. What are some starting points? Where do we differ? But AI seems to be a different animal, right, because you're looking at this combination of risk space assessments combined with some harmed space approaches because at the center of it, I love the way that you frame it, are humans.

The work that I do, we have a paper coming out on algorithmic bias. These are real concerns that are going to, I think, affect the way that we see the evolution of technology and sort of getting to that gray area where there are human ethical concerns. What does a framework look like under those cases?

You've pointed out differences everyone around countries. Are we going to find ourselves in the same debate in terms of, you know, multilateral agreements around this, use cases? How do we ensure that these technologies are not weaponized?

VAN DEN HOVEN: Very hard questions very, relevant questions.

TURNER LEE: I know, and we only have a few more minutes for Q and A, but please, take your time.

VAN DEN HOVEN: So, what do you see if you--if you--if you look at the landscape of all these kind of white papers and all these manifestoes and all these list of principles that are produced. There's a lot of convergence. If you look at, I triple E, for example, here, based here in the U.S., this is ethically aligned design.

So, they came and visit us in Delft, and we had conversations and we are providing input to their sets of principles, you have the Asilomar principles. And so, so everyone seems to be identifying all of those concerns, and also making those kind of distinctions that you were making.

And I think that people also realize that we've had this difficult trajectory and that it's very similar to--to it. And, of course, it is related because there is so much kind of overlaps. So, and everyone is realizing that there are great benefits to be had from this technology. So, I--I am fairly optimistic. I'm receiving treatment for that, but it's--

(LAUGHTER)

Okay, I think--we have a of a chance, for example, the clear initiative that Deputy Mayor mentioned that is setting up its headquarters and the Hague that is 7,000 AI researchers in Europe. I received just yesterday, I talked to the one that is heading this up from Stanford to have a collaboration going.

So, the same initiatives that Henry Kissinger attended, I think it was last week, it's kind of a launcher to kick off a huge initiative, I think these things--and we need to foster that, of course. I mean, you don't leave these people to their own devices but, you know, foster those kind of--of debates and dialogues that would be, I think, wise thing to do. And there's no better way to predict where the world is going than just create then make it vented.

TURNER LEE: And, will Cam, will privacy legislation address the concerns of AI?

KERRY: No. I think only in small ways. A lot of--a lot of the issues are--are different. I mean, I think they've certainly addressed some of the ways that personal data is used in AI, but I don't think that privacy legislation can or should try to address some of the fundamental crosscutting issues that have been identified.

And I guess I come out a little bit where bit at the end here like you said let a thousand flowers bloom in terms of developing the codes and approaches. And somewhat, my take, but I think the principal that has also has been articulated, vigilance certainly needs to be an important part of the discussion.

TURNER LEE: That's right. And when you said that a flower--let a thousand flowers bloom though, I don't want the baby in the carriage to be hid, okay, I just want to be real clear. We got to be careful about that. But let me close with you Bilyana in terms of the whole concept then of GDPR and AI. Will that framework--were coming up on the one-year anniversary, will that framework at least begin to inform us on what we should be looking at around AI and emerging technologies?

PETKOVA: Right, while also, tough question. One year is, I think, still not enough to be able to assess appropriate statute, given its complexity and comprehensiveness. And also, European commission is under no obligation, unlike what the privacy shield to publish these annual assessments that we see for that other framework.

So, that's on the foremost of things. Now, I think that gives a lot of space for independent external evaluators to step in. So, hopefully we'll see more in the future. Of course, the GDPR answer to the is through article 22 which imposes some requirements for explicit consent when the data subject, the individual is affected either legally or by decisions that significantly affect the individual.

So, you can think about where you are targeting in that sense, for example, and many other areas so that there are some protections also their decision can be also contested or can be appealed. Now, how this is going to play out, whether there is going to be always human in the loop or sometimes we might see also that the decision is contested, for example, by checking with another algorithm. I think that would also be--it will vary a from area to area, so total.

TURNER LEE: That's with explain ability issues will come into effect. Okay, so, I'm going to try something a little different because I'm just going to take five minutes for questions and answers. That's all we have. So, I'm going to ask for a question, but I'm going--if more than two hands raise, I'm going to take two questions at one time and I'm going to throw it to the panel as part of their closing. Is that okay, Ted? Just to make sure we answer a couple of questions.

So, just raise your hand if you have a question and I'm going to tell you--I'm going to pick one from this side and this side, I'm going to do it the way we do in the US. I'm going to close my eyes and put my hand out, and if your hand is the one in the direction of my finger, you're going to have your question to ask. And certainly, let's continue the conversation on twitter.

Okay, so, on this side going to put my hands on my eyes and I'm going to pick this gentleman right there is the first question. And let me do the second question on this side, and I'll ask that you keep your question brief so that we can actually have the panelist answer. And I will do young lady with the black on, okay, as a second question. So, let's do one question, say your name and if you all can just write that question down and I will have them answered both at the same time.

QUESTION: Thank you very much. I'll try to be very brief. Michael Tuador (PH) from the European Parliament Liaison Office. So, how do we balance out your comments about and cause for increased harmonization in terms of global governance for the Internet with the reality of the normative landscape, which most of the times is predicated on unilateral extra territorialism?

And we've seen that on the U.S. side, for example, with the Cloud Act. We've seen that on the E.U. side, for example, with the GDPR, I'm thinking of the Senate scope of article 3 and also the coming, possibly E.U. evidence proposal and other commission proposals. Thank you.

TURNER LEE: Okay. You all have that. Just hold just for a moment. It was question there, but okay now let's go--I don't know my exercise will work. Okay, and second question.

QUESTION: Thank you so much. I'm Marina Fezel (PH), an Afghan-American journalist. And I would like to ask you to address this on a couple of fronts, one is the international front. I mean, I heard you speak about President Putin being quite a leader in this arena. We are still in the midst of sorting through the results of what sort of meddling was done here.

In the length of time that it takes to go through those issues, by the time we know what were the consequences and the modalities, bear results for us to see the Mueller report, etc. is there a risk of damage to democracy? How do you view the time frame that it takes?

You're all talking about a longer trajectory of how policies can be formed to a fact international entities vis-a-vis to this, but in the meantime, what do we, global citizens do when our phones are taken by ghost operators, for example, whether we're journalist, whether we are business executives, whoever we are? Are there entities being formed already to deal with these things to inform the citizens to cope with the consequences and do the best they can?

TURNER LEE: So, okay good. I think I got question. I want to make sure we have enough time. Okay, so there are two questions. You can take both, you can take one. Let's end with her question and let's go to this whole question around unilateral concerns and the fact that there are competing approaches even in the distribution of power, right, around some of these areas, and we never get to harmonization.

KERRY: Sure. Well, I think we need to be mindful in terms of the E.U. U.S. discussion that if we have some very powerful common interest, it's economic interest in what is the world's largest trade relationship, strategic interest. And I don't believe that the AI and technology discussion should be turned into an arms race.

But is the threat that I think we have common interest, being on the same side if--if that does happen. And certainly, overarching this is, you know, common political interests to protect democracy, to ensure that AI technologies are not turned into the instrument of authoritarianism that Jeroen described. And I think, you know, those are enormously powerful common interest. And I think it behooves us to work for ways to harmonize--we're not going to--we are not going to be identical.

So, I was very interested in Jeroen's comments about where things may go with--with the GDPR. But we need to be having that discussion, be pursuing it to actively--at all levels, not just a governmental discussion, but across all sectors.

TURNER LEE: Um-hmm. You want to go into it?

PETKOVA: I'll just jump and quickly. I largely agree with what Cam was saying. So, I think that there are more common interest than the divergencies. So, also with both Europeans and Americans are, I think, deeply concerned with the Chinese scoring system, credit scoring system, and the roll out the technologies on that scale.

And so, we should start with, perhaps, the commonalities. And here, think of a secret scoring of travelers and police, and proprietary techniques also in the community law justices, Jeroen was saying. So, there are common interest there, I think that we can use as starting points. And it's also where civil society groups are playing a role on both sides of the Atlantic for exposing some of these mechanisms to the sort of public and pushing back against them. So, perhaps you want to.

VAN DEN HOVEN: Yeah.

TURNER LEE: So, I'm going to have you actually end up on that last question.

VAN DEN HOVEN: Yeah, yeah.

TURNER LEE: So, jump in if you want to say something, but end up on that last question, yeah.

VAN DEN HOVEN: With both of these. Yeah, to your question, which is a very pertinent and very relevant one is to say that in Europe we are thinking about those institutions that could surveille monitors kind of democracy observatories. For example, Macron has asked in his letter, which was ridiculed a little bit, so, he wrote to (UNTRANSLATED) or citizens of Europe calling for digital re-nations.

And he drew attention to this also looking forward to the European elections. And there is a lot of anxiety around how, you know, certain parties will meddle and will try to influence that. And indeed, I think your point is very, very relevant. How can we, you know, investigate and look at these things, assure ourselves of the fact of these things have been done properly and--and in accordance with the rule of law.

So, that is something that we have to create new institutions. We have to invent them. So, we are thinking also in the Netherlands about setting up the unit or an agency that would, you know, over--oversee elections and especially this--this online vigilance of seeing how, you know, maybe we're trying to manipulate and influence unjustifiably the--the voters. So, yeah.

TURNER LEE: Yeah. So, I can say this as we continue to close. I mean, obviously this conversation today from the beginning to this, now end, really points to the fact that technology continues to outpace policymaking.

Whatever front that you're on that were going to continue to be, in I think this race to ensure that we actually harmonize, you know, not only distinct approaches distribution power, you know, where civil society fits in with regards to freedom of expression.

And I think the most important thing is we have this race where people fit in to this equation where they are not hurt in the process of technologies evolution. I just want to say thank you today's panelist. Please join me in thanking them.

(APPLAUSE)

Before we leave, please join me in thanking the Deputy Mayor for actually addressing us.

(APPLAUSE)

And I want to say to all of you that you already probably know the Brookings continues to work on these issues in our foreign policy program as well as our other programs in which Cam and are associated. Continue to follow our discussions. Continue the conversation on twitter. And enjoy the rest of your day. Thank you.
