urn:contentItem:60J1-0DK1-JDG9-Y176-00000-00Brown Opening Statement at Banking Committee Executive Session2020-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:25ZLexisNexisBrown Opening Statement at Banking Committee Executive Session

Washington: Office of the Senator Sherrod Brown has issued the following news release:

U.S Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-OH) – ranking member of the U.S Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs – delivered the following opening statement at today’s Executive Session.

Sen. Brown’s remarks, as prepared for delivery, follow:

Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

I would like to thank Chairman Crapo for scheduling this markup and advancing the Committee’s nominees.

As I stated last week, leadership matters. Since then, almost 20,000 Americans have died from the coronavirus, sending the total to nearly 160,000. This Administration has abandoned its duty to the American people with tragic consequences.

The three nominees we are considering today must show the leadership the president has lacked, and commit to working for a financial system that protects working families, instead of taking advantage of them. Their job is to put the people we serve first – not only during this time of financial and economic stress, but all the time.

If Commissioner Peirce and Ms. Crenshaw are confirmed, the public will trust them to always keep in mind whose side they are on, and to understand how hard Americans are working to save and invest for retirement, to send their kids to college, or to buy a home. We want our markets to be fair and available to everyone, but that doesn’t mean rolling back important safeguards. As Commissioners, if they don’t put those families first, who will? Not Wall Street banks, we know that.

I will support the SEC nominees, but call on them to stay grounded in the struggles workers and families face and to put those families first.

Mr. Hauptman has been nominated to serve as a member of the NCUA Board, but I am concerned about Mr. Hauptman’s experience and qualifications to be one of the top regulators of credit unions in this country.

If confirmed, Mr. Hauptman would oversee over 5,000 credit unions that serve 121 million members. They are often community-based institutions, serving customers that banks and other financial institutions leave behind, like middle-income and low-income workers, women, and Black and brown communities.

His testimony and answers to questions at the hearing and for the record do not provide any details on what types of policies he will advocate for to actually help the credit union members he would serve. He says technology can help people who have been left behind by our banking system, but has failed to provide any examples of how that should be accomplished.

Instead of laying out specific ideas to help credit unions and their members, Mr. Hauptman praises Netflix as an example of the benefits of innovation – calling it the ultimate solution to Blockbuster’s late fees and market dominance. I wonder if he’s aware of reports of a toxic work culture at Netflix, or if he just doesn’t care.

And Big Tech companies dominate the market in a way that Blockbuster could never dream of, driving smaller companies out of business and amassing huge amounts of personal data, exploiting our privacy and our civil rights for financial gain. He fails to recognize that “innovation” is often just a shiny new way to exploit workers and target consumers with the same predatory products and services.

If his previous work and positions are any indication, he will be another advocate for rolling back important financial safeguards – another voice for the powerful and the privileged, who have more than their share of influence already.

We need public servants who will actually serve the public, especially now. If confirmed, I expect all of the nominees to make sure this public health crisis doesn’t turn into a financial crisis. It’s your responsibility to make sure we have a fair financial system that works for everyone.

Thank you, Chairman Crapo.

If Commissioner Peirce and Ms. Crenshaw are confirmed, the public will trust them to always keep in mind whose side they are on, and to understand how hard Americans are working to save and invest for retirement, to send their kids to college, or to buy a home. We want our markets to be fair and available to everyone, but that doesn't mean rolling back important safeguards. As Commissioners, if they don't put those families first, who will? Not Wall Street banks, we know that.

I will support the SEC nominees, but call on them to stay grounded in the struggles workers and families face and to put those families first.

Mr. Hauptman has been nominated to serve as a member of the NCUA Board, but I am concerned about Mr. Hauptman's experience and qualifications to be one of the top regulators of credit unions in this country.

If confirmed, Mr. Hauptman would oversee over 5,000 credit unions that serve 121 million members. They are often community-based institutions, serving customers that banks and other financial institutions leave behind, like middle-income and low-income workers, women, and Black and brown communities.

His testimony and answers to questions at the hearing and for the record do not provide any details on what types of policies he will advocate for to actually help the credit union members he would serve. He says technology can help people who have been left behind by our banking system, but has failed to provide any examples of how that should be accomplished.

Instead of laying out specific ideas to help credit unions and their members, Mr. Hauptman praises Netflix as an example of the benefits of innovation - calling it the ultimate solution to Blockbuster's late fees and market dominance. I wonder if he's aware of reports of a toxic work culture at Netflix, or if he just doesn't care.

And Big Tech companies dominate the market in a way that Blockbuster could never dream of, driving smaller companies out of business and amassing huge amounts of personal data, exploiting our privacy and our civil rights for financial gain. He fails to recognize that "innovation" is often just a shiny new way to exploit workers and target consumers with the same predatory products and services.

If his previous work and positions are any indication, he will be another advocate for rolling back important financial safeguards - another voice for the powerful and the privileged, who have more than their share of influence already.

We need public servants who will actually serve the public, especially now. If confirmed, I expect all of the nominees to make sure this public health crisis doesn't turn into a financial crisis. It's your responsibility to make sure we have a fair financial system that works for everyone.

Thank you, Chairman Crapo.

urn:contentItem:5WPM-MF21-JDG9-Y2Y3-00000-00Brown Opening Statement at Hearing on Regulatory Frameworks for Digital Currencies and Blockchain2019-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:24ZLexisNexisBrown Opening Statement at Hearing on Regulatory Frameworks for Digital Currencies and Blockchain

Washington: Office of the Senator Sherrod Brown has issued the following news release:

U.S Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-OH) – ranking member of the U.S Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs – delivered the following opening statement at today’s hearing entitled ‘Examining Regulatory Frameworks for Digital Currencies and Blockchain.’

Sen. Brown’s remarks, as prepared for delivery, follow:

Thank you Chairman Crapo, and welcome to our witnesses.

At this committee’s hearing earlier this month, many of us of both parties voiced serious concerns about Facebook’s plan to run its own currency out of a Swiss bank account.

And by and large, we mostly heard deflections and dodging. It’s exactly what we mean when we say Facebook doesn’t understand accountability.

Facebook has proven over and over, through scandal after scandal, that it can’t be trusted.

But they don’t care.

They move fast and break things – things like our political discourse, journalism, relationships, privacy. Now they want to break our currency and payment systems, hiding behind the phrase “innovation.”

They want to “innovate” Americans right out of their hard-earned paychecks.

Look around at what happens with big corporations say they want to “innovate.”

Before they blew up the economy in 2008, bankers were pitching an “innovative” new product called subprime mortgages.

Just like Facebook – which claims its new currency will help the unbanked and underbanked – these mortgages were supposed to help people who never had access to credit achieve the American dream of homeownership.

In reality, those mortgages ripped off millions of families who ended up losing their homes, they wrecked the economy, and they made the staggering inequality in this country even worse.

The only innovative thing about the financial crisis was how the banks managed to stick everyone else with the bill – not exactly the kind of innovation we were hoping for.

So I am all for innovation – especially if that innovation delivers on its promises of improving people’s lives. But big tech companies and Wall Street banks are hiding behind innovation as an excuse to take over important public services that we all benefit from, and should all have a say in.

There are some things – like our currency, our payments system, and the protection of our savings accounts – that everyone in the country has a stake in. We should not be handing those kinds of public resources over to wealthy special interests, so they can squeeze more profits out of ordinary Americans.

Think about how hard it is to get quality service from Comcast, or about how much of your personal data was leaked by Equifax, or how your privacy was invaded by Facebook. And, we just learned in the last 24 hours, Capital One. Who’s next? We don’t know.

So we should be a little suspicious when someone tells us that only big corporations can be trusted to provide critical public services.

I recently moved into a new office – it was John Glenn’s office when he served Ohio in the Senate. I moved there because he and Annie are longtime friends. We’ve known each other for 30 years. John Glenn spoke at my Eagle Scout dinner in Mansfield, Ohio 50 years ago. But I moved into that office primarily because he was an innovator – he was the first American to orbit the Earth as part of the Mercury Project, which would be followed by the Gemini and Apollo Missions that would eventually put Americans on the moon. Many of us joined in the celebrations of the fiftieth anniversary of Apollo 11 just this month.

None of the astronauts did it alone – it took the hard work of thousands of innovating scientists and engineers, people like famed mathematician Katherine Johnson or immigrants like engineer Miguel Hernandez. These Americans didn’t do it for the profits. They did it to serve their country, and their successes were shared by every American who saw “U-S-A” emblazoned on the side of Apollo 11.

It’s a reminder that some infrastructure works better as a public good, and we shouldn’t let Big Banks or Big Tech get their hands on it.

The Federal Reserve and other watchdogs need to continue to be leaders in banking innovation.

And if we don’t move quickly to improve important infrastructure – not just roads and bridges, and highways and water sewer systems, but our payments systems, too. If we don’t move quickly to improve it, we’ll end up with big corporations that have broken our trust again and again and again, and frankly I don’t think that makes any sense.

I look forward to hearing from our witnesses today about which of these technologies might actually help regular Americans.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

urn:contentItem:5WJK-7DY1-JDG9-Y3VH-00000-00Brown Opening Statement at Hearing on the Semi-Annual Monetary Policy Report to Congress2019-07-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:25ZLexisNexisBrown Opening Statement at Hearing on the Semi-Annual Monetary Policy Report to Congress

Washington: Office of the Senator Sherrod Brown has issued the following news release:

U.S Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-OH) – ranking member of the U.S Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs – delivered the following opening statement at today’s hearing entitled “The Semiannual Monetary Policy Report to the Congress”.

Sen. Brown’s remarks, as prepared for delivery, follow:

Mr. Chairman, welcome.

The stock market is soaring – but most American families get their money from a paycheck, not an account statement from their stock broker.

A critical part of your job is measuring and evaluating the economy, and those measurements need to take into account workers, not just wealth. Talk to workers who haven’t had a meaningful raise in years, who have seen their retirement cut, who watch their health care premiums rise, who have seen the cost of child care and college and paying off their own student loans go up and up.

To those workers – to most Americans – the idea that a stock market rally means more money in their pockets is laughable.

As the Fed’s own data reveals, the recovery hasn’t helped most Americans—corporate profits go up and up, but workers don’t share in the growth they create. The top one percent have an average net worth of almost 24 million dollars, while the bottom half of all Americans have only about 20 thousand dollars. That’s less than one one-thousandth of their wealthiest neighbors. Meanwhile the share of workers who have been unemployed for over 26 weeks continues to climb.

Mitch McConnell and Donald Trump responded by giving the wealthiest Americans and multinational corporations a two trillion dollar bonus. And those corporations turned around and funneled the money back to their executives through record stock buybacks.

We are in the midst of the longest economic expansion in modern times and interest rates are low, and yet it’s worrying that interest rate-sensitive sectors of the economy that provide good-paying jobs, like the auto industry, are not doing better. Employment in auto manufacturing – which is critical to Ohio – continued to fall in June.

The Fed’s policies should ensure that everyone who contributes to our economy also shares in growth they create. All work has dignity, and we need an economy that rewards work, not just wealth.

Some of the challenges facing our economy can only be addressed by Congress. Millions of Americans struggle to pay for prescription drugs, which are increasing at five times the rate of inflation. And too many feel the squeeze of rising housing costs, with more than a quarter of renters spending over half their income on housing.

The Fed can’t fix all of these issues on its own.

But there are things that you can and should do to help the economy work for the vast majority of Americans, through careful monetary policy and doing your job of policing Wall Street.

I appreciate your recent recognition that this expansion has the potential to benefit communities that have missed out on prior economic expansions. And I hope your comments expressing frustration that wages haven’t increased as much as you expected means you will take action. I urge you to continue with policies that both lower unemployment while increasing wages.

In previous hearings, I have raised my concerns about threats to the financial system, including the Fed’s steps to weaken the rules on the largest banks, the failure to activate the Countercyclical Capital Buffer to prepare for the next financial crisis, and the lack of action to address risks posed by leveraged lending. And just this week, Deutsche Bank announced a significant restructuring, overhauling several businesses and cutting 18,000 jobs—almost 20% of its workforce. After several failed turnarounds in recent years, Deutsche Bank’s latest effort shows it is too large and complex and has been mismanaged and under-regulated. And it isn’t the only megabank in that situation.

I continue to be concerned that the Fed and other banking regulators are not doing enough. Today I can add a new worry to the list – private corporations, Facebook in this case, that have gotten carried away with their own power and are now attempting to ape the role of government, creating their own currencies, monetary policy, and payment systems.

So now, in addition to complex and risky Wall Street banks, we face new risks from unregulated, giant tech companies – armed with vast amounts of personal data – with the intent, as far as I can tell, of conducting monetary policy on their own terms.

You and I have a duty to serve the American people, but these private corporations have no duty to the broader economy or consumers. They’re motivated by one thing: their own bottom lines. Allowing big tech companies to take over the payments system or position themselves to influence monetary policy would be a huge mistake, and threatens to undermine our democracy.

Too many times, when the stock market is soaring and banks are making money hand over fist, regulators have been complacent. But as we have seen in the past, bank profitability is not a reliable indicator of a bank’s true health, and the stock market is not a reliable indicator of the real economy’s performance.

I hope this is not another example of the Fed taking a pass from its responsibilities to protect Americans from corporations taking big risks with our entire financial system. It is your responsibility to use your tools over monetary policy, the payment system, and prudential regulation to protect the financial system and make our economy work for all Americans, not just wealthy stockholders and huge corporations.

Thank you Chairman Powell for being here, and I look forward to hearing your testimony.

So now, in addition to complex and risky Wall Street banks, we face new risks from unregulated, giant tech companies armed with vast amounts of personal data with the intent, as far as I can tell, of conducting monetary policy on their own terms.

You and I have a duty to serve the American people, but these private corporations have no duty to the broader economy or consumers. They're motivated by one thing: their own bottom lines. Allowing big tech companies to take over the payments system or position themselves to influence monetary policy would be a huge mistake, and threatens to undermine our democracy.

Too many times, when the stock market is soaring and banks are making money hand over fist, regulators have been complacent. But as we have seen in the past, bank profitability is not a reliable indicator of a bank's true health, and the stock market is not a reliable indicator of the real economy's performance.

I hope this is not another example of the Fed taking a pass from its responsibilities to protect Americans from corporations taking big risks with our entire financial system. It is your responsibility to use your tools over monetary policy, the payment system, and prudential regulation to protect the financial system and make our economy work for all Americans, not just wealthy stockholders and huge corporations.

Thank you Chairman Powell for being here, and I look forward to hearing your testimony.

Sherrod Brown (D-OH) News Release2019-07-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:24ZLexisNexisU.S. SENATE DOCUMENTSBrown Opening Statement at Hearing on the Semi-Annual Monetary Policy Report to CongressSen. Sherrod Brown (D-OH) News Release

WASHINGTON, D.C. -- U.S. Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-OH) - ranking member of the U.S. Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs - delivered the following opening statement at today's hearing entitled "The Semiannual Monetary Policy Report to the Congress".

Sen. Brown's remarks, as prepared for delivery, follow:

Mr. Chairman, welcome.

The stock market is soaring - but most American families get their money from a paycheck, not an account statement from their stock broker.

A critical part of your job is measuring and evaluating the economy, and those measurements need to take into account workers, not just wealth. Talk to workers who haven't had a meaningful raise in years, who have seen their retirement cut, who watch their health care premiums rise, who have seen the cost of child care and college and paying off their own student loans go up and up.

To those workers - to most Americans - the idea that a stock market rally means more money in their pockets is laughable.

As the Fed's own data reveals, the recovery hasn't helped most Americans--corporate profits go up and up, but workers don't share in the growth they create. The top one percent have an average net worth of almost 24 million dollars, while the bottom half of all Americans have only about 20 thousand dollars. That's less than one one-thousandth of their wealthiest neighbors. Meanwhile the share of workers who have been unemployed for over 26 weeks continues to climb.

Mitch McConnell and Donald Trump responded by giving the wealthiest Americans and multinational corporations a two trillion dollar bonus. And those corporations turned around and funneled the money back to their executives through record stock buybacks.

We are in the midst of the longest economic expansion in modern times and interest rates are low, and yet it's worrying that interest rate-sensitive sectors of the economy that provide good-paying jobs, like the auto industry, are not doing better. Employment in auto manufacturing - which is critical to Ohio - continued to fall in June.

The Fed's policies should ensure that everyone who contributes to our economy also shares in growth they create. All work has dignity, and we need an economy that rewards work, not just wealth.

Some of the challenges facing our economy can only be addressed by Congress. Millions of Americans struggle to pay for prescription drugs, which are increasing at five times the rate of inflation. And too many feel the squeeze of rising housing costs, with more than a quarter of renters spending over half their income on housing.

The Fed can't fix all of these issues on its own.

But there are things that you can and should do to help the economy work for the vast majority of Americans, through careful monetary policy and doing your job of policing Wall Street.

I appreciate your recent recognition that this expansion has the potential to benefit communities that have missed out on prior economic expansions. And I hope your comments expressing frustration that wages haven't increased as much as you expected means you will take action. I urge you to continue with policies that both lower unemployment while increasing wages.

In previous hearings, I have raised my concerns about threats to the financial system, including the Fed's steps to weaken the rules on the largest banks, the failure to activate the Countercyclical Capital Buffer to prepare for the next financial crisis, and the lack of action to address risks posed by leveraged lending. And just this week, Deutsche Bank announced a significant restructuring, overhauling several businesses and cutting 18,000 jobs--almost 20% of its workforce. After several failed turnarounds in recent years, Deutsche Bank's latest effort shows it is too large and complex and has been mismanaged and under-regulated. And it isn't the only megabank in that situation.

I continue to be concerned that the Fed and other banking regulators are not doing enough. Today I can add a new worry to the list - private corporations, Facebook in this case, that have gotten carried away with their own power and are now attempting to ape the role of government, creating their own currencies, monetary policy, and payment systems.

So now, in addition to complex and risky Wall Street banks, we face new risks from unregulated, giant tech companies - armed with vast amounts of personal data - with the intent, as far as I can tell, of conducting monetary policy on their own terms.

You and I have a duty to serve the American people, but these private corporations have no duty to the broader economy or consumers. They're motivated by one thing: their own bottom lines. Allowing big tech companies to take over the payments system or position themselves to influence monetary policy would be a huge mistake, and threatens to undermine our democracy.

Too many times, when the stock market is soaring and banks are making money hand over fist, regulators have been complacent. But as we have seen in the past, bank profitability is not a reliable indicator of a bank's true health, and the stock market is not a reliable indicator of the real economy's performance.

I hope this is not another example of the Fed taking a pass from its responsibilities to protect Americans from corporations taking big risks with our entire financial system. It is your responsibility to use your tools over monetary policy, the payment system, and prudential regulation to protect the financial system and make our economy work for all Americans, not just wealthy stockholders and huge corporations.

Thank you Chairman Powell for being here, and I look forward to hearing your testimony.

urn:contentItem:605R-6P41-F0YC-N154-00000-00Brown Releases New Proposal That Would Protect Consumers’ Privacy from Bad Actors2020-06-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:25ZLexisNexisBrown Releases New Proposal That Would Protect Consumers’ Privacy from Bad Actors

Washington: Office of the Senator Sherrod Brown has issued the following news release:

U.S Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-OH) – ranking member of the U.S Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs, today released a draft privacy bill, the Data Accountability and Transparency Act of 2020. Brown’s proposal creates a new framework that would give Americans the power to hold corporations, big tech, and the government responsible for how they collect and protect personal data. The bill rejects the current, ineffective “consent” model for privacy, and instead places strict limits on the collection, use, and sharing of Americans’ personal data. The bill contains strong civil rights protections to ensure personal information is not used for discriminatory purposes, as well as a ban on the use of facial recognition technology. Brown’s proposal also establishes a new independent agency dedicated to protecting Americans’ privacy rights.

“Right now, we do not protect people’s privacy – that means we don’t protect their civil rights. We need legislation now more than ever that empowers Americans to control their personal information. No person should have to worry about being spied on, just like no one should worry about their information being bought and sold or stolen,” said Senator Brown. “My proposal would change the fundamental framework of privacy in this country. This is long overdue, Americans need and deserve to know that their personal information is safe now and in the future.”

Specifically, the Data Accountability and Transparency Act of 2020 would:

Ban the collection, use or sharing of personal data unless specifically allowed by law Ban the use of facial recognition technology Prohibits the use of personal data to discriminate in housing, employment, credit, insurance, and public accommodations; Requires anyone using decision-making algorithms to provide new accountability reports Creates a new, independent agency that is dedicated to protecting individuals’ privacy and the implementation of DATA 2020. The new agency will have rulemaking, supervisory, and enforcement authority, the ability to issue civil penalties for violations of the Act, and a dedicated Office of Civil Rights to protect individuals from discrimination The proposal empowers individuals and state attorneys general to enforce privacy protections and does not preempt more protective state laws Finally, the proposal would require CEO certification of compliance with the Act and contains potential criminal and civil penalties for CEO and Board of Directors

More information about the legislation can be found here. Senator Brown worked with a diverse group of privacy experts as well as civil rights and consumer organizations. A selection of statements from these organizations appear below, and more can be viewed here.

“This bill sets a bold new agenda for privacy. If it becomes law, consumers can breathe a sigh of relief: rather than being expected to wade through a sea of unreadable terms of service and misleading corporate 'privacy policies,' we can rely on a Data Accountability and Transparency Agency to protect us from scams, discrimination, and surveillance. The bill puts the burden of privacy policy where it always should have been: on regulators to protect us from increasingly irresponsible, insecure, and invasive data collection. The bill's sponsors deserve enormous credit for their visionary data policy. This bill is now the gold standard for privacy reform: any future efforts here need to be measured against it,” Frank Pasquale, Professor of Law, University of Maryland Carey School of Law.

“The Data Accountability and Transparency Act of 2020 sets a strong standard for data protection. Collection of personal data has expanded dramatically over the last ten years, yet we have no comprehensive federal data protection standards. Data breaches, identity theft, hacking, and data misuse are on the rise. Senator Brown’s bill creates enforceable privacy rights and limits the amount of data companies can collect and keep about us. Critically, it creates a data protection agency to ensure that these rules are followed. EPIC strongly supports Data Accountability and Transparency Act of 2020,” Caitriona Fitzgerald, Interim Associate Director and Policy Director, Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC).

“Senator Brown's draft Data Accountability and Transparency Act rejects the notice and consent regime that serves data collectors well, but fails consumers. Instead of that system, which counts on consumers to surrender their data for vague down-stream uses, Senator Brown proposes a new and welcome paradigm: it limits data collection to certain permitted uses, and those alone,” Ed Mierzwinski, Senior Director, Federal Consumer Program, U.S PIRG.

“Senator Brown’s privacy bill is among the strongest and most comprehensive put forward in Congress. It contains strong prohibitions on unfair and discriminatory data practices, protects civil rights, has robust rulemaking authority for a new privacy agency and ensures that people can enforce their rights in court. Making the kinds of big changes to the data ecosystem we need, Senator Brown’s bill would help end some of the abusive practices that have made commercial surveillance so pervasive and profitable,” Free Press Action.

Senator Brown has long fought to protect consumer’s data. He recently sent a letter to the Trump Administration expressing concern about the use of facial recognition technology to gather information on those Americans who joined in protest of systemic racial injustice. He also sent letters to Zoom Video Communications, Inc. and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) about the company’s virtual meeting technology, and expressed concerns regarding Zoom’s deceptive practices by inaccurately advertising end-to-end encryption of its virtual meetings. He also joined his colleagues Sens. Bob Menendez (D-N.J ) Kamala Harris (D-Calif.), Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.), and Cory Booker (D-N.J ) in questioning information regarding Verily’s screening platform. Finally, Senator Brown joined members of the House and Senate in asking the U.S Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to review policies regarding the use of facial recognition technologies in federally assisted housing.

The following information was released by Ohio Senator Sherrod Brown:

U.S. Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-OH) ranking member of the U.S. Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs, today released a draft privacy bill, the Data Accountability and Transparency Act of 2020. Brown's proposal creates a new framework that would give Americans the power to hold corporations, big tech, and the government responsible for how they collect and protect personal data. The bill rejects the current, ineffective "consent" model for privacy, and instead places strict limits on the collection, use, and sharing of Americans' personal data. The bill contains strong civil rights protections to ensure personal information is not used for discriminatory purposes, as well as a ban on the use of facial recognition technology. Brown's proposal also establishes a new independent agency dedicated to protecting Americans' privacy rights.

"Right now, we do not protect people's privacy that means we don't protect their civil rights. We need legislation now more than ever that empowers Americans to control their personal information. No person should have to worry about being spied on, just like no one should worry about their information being bought and sold or stolen," said Senator Brown . "My proposal would change the fundamental framework of privacy in this country. This is long overdue, Americans need and deserve to know that their personal information is safe now and in the future."

Specifically, the Data Accountability and Transparency Act of 2020 would:

Ban the collection, use or sharing of personal data unless specifically allowed by law

Ban the use of facial recognition technology

Prohibits the use of personal data to discriminate in housing, employment, credit, insurance, and public accommodations;

Requires anyone using decision-making algorithms to provide new accountability reports

Creates a new, independent agency that is dedicated to protecting individuals' privacy and the implementation of DATA 2020. The new agency will have rulemaking, supervisory, and enforcement authority, the ability to issue civil penalties for violations of the Act, and a dedicated Office of Civil Rights to protect individuals from discrimination

The proposal empowers individuals and state attorneys general to enforce privacy protections and does not preempt more protective state laws

Finally, the proposal would require CEO certification of compliance with the Act and contains potential criminal and civil penalties for CEO and Board of Directors

More information about the legislation can be found here. Senator Brown worked with a diverse group of privacy experts as well as civil rights and consumer organizations. A selection of statements from these organizations appear below, and more can be viewed here.

"This bill sets a bold new agenda for privacy. If it becomes law, consumers can breathe a sigh of relief: rather than being expected to wade through a sea of unreadable terms of service and misleading corporate "privacy policies," we can rely on a Data Accountability and Transparency Agency to protect us from scams, discrimination, and surveillance. The bill puts the burden of privacy policy where it always should have been: on regulators to protect us from increasingly irresponsible, insecure, and invasive data collection. The bill's sponsors deserve enormous credit for their visionary data policy. This bill is now the gold standard for privacy reform: any future efforts here need to be measured against it," Frank Pasquale, Professor of Law, University of Maryland Carey School of Law.

"The Data Accountability and Transparency Act of 2020 sets a strong standard for data protection. Collection of personal data has expanded dramatically over the last ten years, yet we have no comprehensive federal data protection standards. Data breaches, identity theft, hacking, and data misuse are on the rise. Senator Brown's bill creates enforceable privacy rights and limits the amount of data companies can collect and keep about us. Critically, it creates a data protection agency to ensure that these rules are followed. EPIC strongly supports Data Accountability and Transparency Act of 2020," Caitriona Fitzgerald, Interim Associate Director and Policy Director, Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC).

"Senator Brown's draft Data Accountability and Transparency Act rejects the notice and consent regime that serves data collectors well, but fails consumers. Instead of that system, which counts on consumers to surrender their data for vague down-stream uses, Senator Brown proposes a new and welcome paradigm: it limits data collection to certain permitted uses, and those alone," Ed Mierzwinski, Senior Director, Federal Consumer Program, U.S. PIRG.

"Senator Brown's privacy bill is among the strongest and most comprehensive put forward in Congress. It contains strong prohibitions on unfair and discriminatory data practices, protects civil rights, has robust rulemaking authority for a new privacy agency and ensures that people can enforce their rights in court. Making the kinds of big changes to the data ecosystem we need, Senator Brown's bill would help end some of the abusive practices that have made commercial surveillance so pervasive and profitable," Free Press Action .

Senator Brown has long fought to protect consumer's data. He recently sent a letter to the Trump Administration expressing concern about the use of facial recognition technology to gather information on those Americans who joined in protest of systemic racial injustice. He also sent letters to Zoom Video Communications, Inc. and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) about the company's virtual meeting technology, and expressed concerns regarding Zoom's deceptive practices by inaccurately advertising end-to-end encryption of its virtual meetings. He also joined his colleagues Sens. Bob Menendez (D-N.J.) Kamala Harris (D-Calif.), Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.), and Cory Booker (D-N.J.) in questioning information regarding Verily's screening platform. Finally, Senator Brown joined members of the House and Senate in asking the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to review policies regarding the use of facial recognition technologies in federally assisted housing.

The bill contains strong civil rights protections to ensure personal information is not used for discriminatory purposes, as well as a ban on the use of facial recognition technology. Brown's proposal also establishes a new independent agency dedicated to protecting Americans' privacy rights.

"Right now, we do not protect people's privacy - that means we don't protect their civil rights. We need legislation now more than ever that empowers Americans to control their personal information. No person should have to worry about being spied on, just like no one should worry about their information being bought and sold or stolen," said Senator Brown. "My proposal would change the fundamental framework of privacy in this country. This is long overdue, Americans need and deserve to know that their personal information is safe now and in the future."

Specifically, the Data Accountability and Transparency Act of 2020 would:

* Ban the collection, use or sharing of personal data unless specifically allowed by law

* Ban the use of facial recognition technology

* Prohibits the use of personal data to discriminate in housing, employment, credit, insurance, and public accommodations;

* Requires anyone using decision-making algorithms to provide new accountability reports

* Creates a new, independent agency that is dedicated to protecting individuals' privacy and the implementation of DATA 2020. The new agency will have rulemaking, supervisory, and enforcement authority, the ability to issue civil penalties for violations of the Act, and a dedicated Office of Civil Rights to protect individuals from discrimination

* The proposal empowers individuals and state attorneys general to enforce privacy protections and does not preempt more protective state laws

* Finally, the proposal would require CEO certification of compliance with the Act and contains potential criminal and civil penalties for CEO and Board of Directors

More information about the legislation can be found here https://www.banking.senate.gov/download/one-pager-the_data-accountability-and-transparency-act-of-2020. Senator Brown worked with a diverse group of privacy experts as well as civil rights and consumer organizations. A selection of statements from these organizations appear below, and more can be viewed here   https://www.banking.senate.gov/download/statement-of-support.

"This bill sets a bold new agenda for privacy. If it becomes law, consumers can breathe a sigh of relief: rather than being expected to wade through a sea of unreadable terms of service and misleading corporate "privacy policies," we can rely on a Data Accountability and Transparency Agency to protect us from scams, discrimination, and surveillance. The bill puts the burden of privacy policy where it always should have been: on regulators to protect us from increasingly irresponsible, insecure, and invasive data collection. The bill's sponsors deserve enormous credit for their visionary data policy. This bill is now the gold standard for privacy reform: any future efforts here need to be measured against it," Frank Pasquale, Professor of Law, University of Maryland Carey School of Law.

"The Data Accountability and Transparency Act of 2020 sets a strong standard for data protection. Collection of personal data has expanded dramatically over the last ten years, yet we have no comprehensive federal data protection standards. Data breaches, identity theft, hacking, and data misuse are on the rise. Senator Brown's bill creates enforceable privacy rights and limits the amount of data companies can collect and keep about us. Critically, it creates a data protection agency to ensure that these rules are followed. EPIC strongly supports Data Accountability and Transparency Act of 2020," Caitriona Fitzgerald, Interim Associate Director and Policy Director, Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC).

"Senator Brown's draft Data Accountability and Transparency Act rejects the notice and consent regime that serves data collectors well, but fails consumers. Instead of that system, which counts on consumers to surrender their data for vague down-stream uses, Senator Brown proposes a new and welcome paradigm: it limits data collection to certain permitted uses, and those alone," Ed Mierzwinski, Senior Director, Federal Consumer Program, U.S. PIRG.

"Senator Brown's privacy bill is among the strongest and most comprehensive put forward in Congress. It contains strong prohibitions on unfair and discriminatory data practices, protects civil rights, has robust rulemaking authority for a new privacy agency and ensures that people can enforce their rights in court. Making the kinds of big changes to the data ecosystem we need, Senator Brown's bill would help end some of the abusive practices that have made commercial surveillance so pervasive and profitable," Free Press Action.

Senator Brown has long fought to protect consumer's data. He recently sent a letter to the Trump Administration expressing concern about the use of facial recognition technology to gather information on those Americans who joined in protest of systemic racial injustice. He also sent letters to Zoom Video Communications, Inc. and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) about the company's virtual meeting technology, and expressed concerns regarding Zoom's deceptive practices by inaccurately advertising end-to-end encryption of its virtual meetings. He also joined his colleagues Sens. Bob Menendez (D-N.J.) Kamala Harris (D-Calif.), Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.), and Cory Booker (D-N.J.) in questioning information regarding Verily's screening platform. Finally, Senator Brown joined members of the House and Senate in asking the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to review policies regarding the use of facial recognition technologies in federally assisted housing.

urn:contentItem:5T7D-TM71-JCPJ-W0FY-00000-00Brown signs bill that mandates 100 percent clean energy by 2045 as tech companies ramp up investments in renewables2018-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:25ZLexisNexisBrown signs bill that mandates 100 percent clean energy by 2045 as tech companies ramp up investments in renewablesHannah Norman

The newly minted Salesforce Tower ascends well above the San Francisco cityscape. Also sky-high are the clean energy plans of its anchor tenant, the software giant for which the LEED-certified office tower is named.

Late last month, San Francisco-based Salesforce.com Inc. said the company had invested in its largest renewable energy agreement to date - an 80-megawatt wind energy project in Illinois - en route to reaching 100 percent renewable energy by 2022. The project, owned and to be operated by Spain-based EDP Renewables, is expected to light up more than 27,000 homes each year.

"For us, renewable energy done the right way means bringing new renewable energy onto the grid, focusing on grids where new renewable energy is needed," said Patrick Flynn, Salesforce's vice president of sustainability. "Some of the dirtier grids in the country, some of the geographies with less progressive climate policies."

As Bay Area tech giants like Salesforce are increasing their commitment to renewables, so too are state lawmakers. On Monday, California Governor Jerry Brown signed a bill to eliminate carbon emissions from the state's electricity by 2045. The move comes just days before San Francisco hosts the Global Climate Action Summit - where Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff will be speaking.

"California is committed to doing whatever is necessary to meet the existential threat of climate change," Brown said in a statement. "This bill, and others I will sign this week, help us go in that direction. But have no illusions, California and the rest of the world have miles to go before we achieve zero-carbon emissions."

Senate Bill 100 expedites the state's elimination of fossil fuels and is Brown's latest jab at the Trump administration. The administration withdrew from the Paris Agreement on climate change last year and has rolled back fuel economy standards and regulations on coal-fired power plants. Just weeks ago, California   released a state climate assessment that projected a two-thirds decline in water supply from snowpack by 2050, as well as a 77 percent uptick in average area burned by wildfires by 2100.

Yet many companies have been accelerating their own clean power ambitions for years without legislative prompting. In the United States, corporations have collectively added almost four gigawatts of clean energy to the grid in 2018 so far, more than in any of the past five years, according to the Business Renewables Center. Since 2013, corporate renewable deals total more than 13 gigawatts.  

Big tech is certainly leading the charge, in large part countering the massive amount of energy drawn to power data centers across the industry. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, the United States is home to about 3 million data centers, which consume more than 2 percent of the nation's electricity.

Both Apple and Google are already powered by 100 percent renewables; in February, Las Vegas-based Switch said it was partnering with investor Capital Dynamics to build the nation's largest solar project - with a capacity of 1 gigabyte in a single plot. Facebook, too, says that it has collectively invested in   over 3 gigawatts of new solar and wind energy, including more than 2,500 megawatts in the past year alone.

Earlier this year, biotech giant Genentech unveiled a 6.4-megawatt, 16,000 solar panel installation atop its South San Francisco headquarters. The system adds to the biotech firm's solar arsenal, which already includes a 8.9-megawatt system in Vacaville with 29,000 panels, completed in 2017.

"We believe that this has a profound impact on our local communities: as the Bay Area continues to grow at an exponential rate, our panels will provide much-needed relief to the power grid," Genentech spokesperson Rebecca Phillips wrote in an email.

Beyond a positive impact, Salesforce sees its sustainability efforts as good for business - from cutting down energy costs via efficiency measures to satisfying customers, employees and investors alike, according to Flynn. The wind project's location in Southern Illinois is also strategic. It's near some of Salesforce's larger data centers in Chicago, as well as Indianapolis, one of the tech company's major hubs.

Last year, the company signed onto the Task Force for Climate-related Financial Disclosures, a framework that guides businesses to deliver investors sustainability-specific information. Salesforce also had the company's major environmental claims reviewed by its audit firm, Ernst & Young.

"The changes that are happening in the investor community with regards to sustainability are so inspiring," Flynn said. "The investor community, as we see it, is really responding and is very interested in what companies are doing around environmental and social issues."

Sustainability scorecards like Greenpeace's "Clicking Clean" (which in 2017 gave Salesforce a 'B' grade overall, though ranked its renewable energy commitment as an 'A') have also pushed companies to be more transparent, according to Priya Barua, manager of strategic partnerships at think tank World Resources Institute's energy program.

WRI co-runs the Renewable Energy Buyers Alliance, which helps make buying renewable energy easier for companies like Salesforce. About 140 companies are members worldwide, in some ways even prompting peer pressure across corporate America to become more sustainable, Barua said.   

"The cost of the technologies and renewable energy have come down tremendously over the past few years, so it makes economic sense," Barua said.

She also points to the long-term predictability that power purchase agreements can provide - relief from the volatile nature of a utility's fluctuating energy rates. Salesforce's wind investment in Illinois, for instance, is for a 15-year contract.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

BRUCE KASMAN, MANAGING DIRECTOR OF GLOBAL RESEARCH, JP MORGAN; AND CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CIO, GABELLI FUNDS; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BB SURVEILLACNE

JULY 30, 2018

SPEAKERS: BRUCE KASMAN, MANAGING DIRECTOR OF GLOBAL RESEARCH, JP MORGAN

CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CIO, GABELLI FUNDS

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Bruce Kasman with us of JP Morgan on a Friday boom economy. The President took a huge victory lap. Did he deserve to take it?

BRUCE KASMAN, MANAGING DIRECTOR OF GLOBAL RESEARCH, JP MORGAN: Well not because I think the GDP report is the reflection of his policies, but I think we should feel good about what it tell us about the U.S. economy, looking through the headline number which is distorted by a couple of things, particularly trade. We have as a nice private sector recovery in demand. We have balanced income growth. We're starting the second half of these lean inventories and we've got a fiscal stimulus coming through. It all suggests the economy solid and will continue to grow at a solid base here.

KEENE: The President with the tenth Tweet. I think he was going to do with the 11th Twee this week. And the 11th Tweet, Mr. President, would have been perfect. And that's the idea of the fiscal stimulus. How much is that fiscal stimulus going to be? 0.5% of GDP? Do you have a number?

KASMAN: Well, we think in 2018 and '19, fiscal stimulus is adding about 0.5% per year. There's a little bit of it in the GDP report for the second quarter both on spending --

KEENE: But a lot more to come?

KASMAN: But there's a lot more to come, particularly if the spending side really does reach its peak if our estimates are right as we turn into 2019. So we think the economy can probably hold growth at around 3% pace, something we haven't done during this expansion for much time. And I think that's a really good back draft in the sense that so far we haven't seen late cycle pressure build, we haven't seen the fed move in any kind of aggressive way. So there's nothing really preventing us from continuing to January solid growth here at least for a little while.

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Yes. Bruce, what do you worry about? Do you worry about the fed having to like tight rates much more than expected in 2019 or do you worry about something else?

KASMAN: Well, I think the fed and late cycle dynamics in terms of the wage pressure starting to put downward pressure on corporate margins is the central risk of the expansion. I think the good news is it's moving very slowly. On the immediate side, I think we do have to worry about whether this trade war turns into war on trade. I mean, obviously we step back from that last week with the E.U. meeting. But my concern would be that what's happening here gives businesses a feeling that supply chain's broader trade patterns are going to be affected permanently and begin to respond to that in terms of sentiment in their spending.

LACQUA: Okay. What do you wait to see whether that it can be at 3%? Is there a danger that actually the U.S. economy is overheated? Are we there again or we just not analyzing what some of the trade and tariffs could do?

KASMAN: Well, I think for the next six to nine months, the amount that trade in tariffs is going to do to add to inflation is a pretty small amount. I think the bigger question there is sentiment, whether it hurts sentiment in a negative way. More broadly, I think we have tight labor markets. I think we have in our future an overheated economy. I don't' think it's there yet. I don't think the inflation number and the wage numbers are pointing to that, and that's suggest this is going to move pretty slowly. KEENE: I've got a controversial chart here. I want to bring it up and, Bruce, this is about linking politics into your world of GDP forecasting, which I think is baloney yet we do it every day. So what we've got here, I'm going to make this bright red so you can see it, really, all. I'll get this out on Bloomberg out on Twitter. This is the 20-year average here at 3.2%, the world's great. And then with the huge contraction that we had early, Obama, you come in here down, and the President in this early years has brought it up just a little bit as well. Within all of your experience, I mean this President is off labors, boy, do they run and hide when it's bad and they love to come out when it's good. But can you really link GDP growth in the public policy?

KASMAN: Look, there is a fiscal stimulus working through this system and if we want to champion that. And I wouldn't champion that at this point in the cycle, it's adding to demand and it's supporting growth. But the broader story that's improving growth here, which has a global dimension to it and a domestic dimension, is something that has been growing for two to three years as we're getting the benefits of very supportive monetary policy as we're finally getting the healing in the post-financial crisis period come through the system. So I think it would be a mistake at any point in time to tie near term economic performance to immediate policy changes.

KEENE: We're thrilled to have you here at the start of the week with JP Morgan, Bruce Kasman. He'll continue with us through the hour.

With us is Bruce Kasman of JP Morgan, and we're thrilled to bring you a timely discussion and conversation with Chris Marangi. He is with the Gabelli Funds, of course, on media and on all the infrastructure and things that hold it together. I must touch on and Mr. Moonves' fate this week, it is a cross all of the headlines, particularly here in New York City. How important is Mr. Moonves to CBS for shareholders and investors?

CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CIO, GABELLI FUNDS: Yes. Well, one of the interview questions I give is do you buy asset or management given a choice. We had a great situation at CBS where we had both. But ultimately, we want to buy the asset and the assets are the same. Les has done a great job and he is important to the story though.

KEENE: What do you do with CBS right now? Do you just wait out the soap opera?

MARANGI: Well, yes, I think (inaudible) and we think about it as a 2x2 matrix. CBS, what's the value of CBS with Moonves without him, what's the value of the combination of CBS and Viacom with Moonves, without him. The answer is that CBS is worth more in all those cases, but the market has increased a probability that we're going to be without Moonves.

KEENE: After what we've been through with Fox, Disney in all, there's been all sorts of discussions of CBS combining almost on distribution reasons with other networks, CNN mention and others as well. Is that they're future, they've just got to find distribution?

MARANGI: Well, scale is critical in this business. You saw obviously Comcast trying to achieve bigger scale with five since he's doing that with. So I think eventually you'll see CBS a somebody else. I don't know who will be that.

KEENE: You don't know how to be right, you don't want to inform us on a Monday how many it would affect. Inform us on what that occurred last week. We see a real dominance, a separation in technology of Google and Amazon and others, Facebook and Twitter, disappointing shareholders? What's yours and Mario's observation of that?

MARANGI: Well, what we learned last week is the fangs just don't go up all the time. So, listen, Facebook said two bad words on their call. They talked about deceleration and margin compression, and growth investors don't want to see that. I think long-term is probably doing the right thing for the stock. And The stock is basically back to where it was at the beginning of the year. So we're not terribly distressed by it.

LACQUA: All right. But, Chris, overall, and good morning from London, what's your biggest concern when it comes to fanged stocks? Anyway, we're not really leaving the bubble bursting in the year 2000, right? This is different, and yet there are fault line.

MARANGI: It's clearly different than the late 90's early 2000's. Valuation are rich. I don't think they're overly stretched for most member of the fang. There are differences obviously between members of the fang. And as Tom mentioned, we are seeing a little bit of a decoupling. I think, frankly, Facebook's results make Google results look although much more better because they did a terrific job of navigating some of the changes in regulation and the concerns over privacy.

LACQUA: All right. But what do you do with the snap? What do you do with Twitter?

KASMAN: I think those are -- those don't quite have a scale. Obviously, Twitter has been quite a platform. They helped the President quite a bit. And their stocks have done well but obviously a lot of change there.

LACQUA: Okay. Chris, overall, I know we're also expecting Apple. I mean, how do you take advantage of A.I.? If you look at the big trend in the next 5, 10, 15 years, do you go just for chipmakers in, for example, Asian markets or do you go after some of these big tech stocks?

MARANGI: Well, I think one of the things that we like are recurring revenue businesses. And the services business at Apple is growing a very attractive part of that business. They have a global platform for music and entertainment. So we like that aspect of stock. Obviously, it's cheap. You've got Warren Buffet buying it.

KEENE: Here are the (inaudible), Bruce Kasman. The backdrop is Kasman's optimism of JP Morgan economy. When you filter through earnings, which is part of economics, when the corporate might get out there, what do you see 12 months more (ph)? Are you going to tell Marangi to shut up and load the boat here on a Monday?

KASMAN: Well, I think what you're seeing a pretty healthy upturn in corporate profits that's supported the macro fundamentals. I think what's nice right now is we have a reasonably balanced income dynamic in the U.S. and globally with employment growing close to a decade high and corporate profits continuing to grow. We worry tight labor market will eventually upset the apple cart by start to create a wedge between wages and productivity, compressed margins, it's going to happen but it's not happening now. KEENE: But to the savings revisions we saw in the GDP report, which to me were the biggest thing in the report, Chris, people have the disposable income to do media, don't they?

MARANGI: They do, but they're saving money by -- some are by are cutting the cord and putting more -- keeping more money in their pockets.

KEENE: But the money they're utting accord is going to -- I would say, suggest, it's going to other media sources, right?

MARANGI: Well, it's going to broad band, for example. Which is why we like -- still like the cable stocks. Broad band plays as oppose to the view.

KEENE: So Comcast now has a screening value after the collapse since the merge?

MARANGI: It was and it is even more valued today as a starter.

LACQUA: (Inaudible ) overall, if you look at consolidation, I don't know whether this is domestic, so it's U.S. or whether you lost possibility of an outsider coming and buying some of the domestic players?

MARANGI: Yes. So you've got obviously sprints which is still backed Softbank and T-Mobile backed by Deutsche Telecom, trying to come together. If that happens, I think it will be -- a lot of sense for them to buy an infrastructure provider like charter, which will be the one for sale. I don't think Comcast is for sales. So those would be two, if I had in the past talk about LTs, of course, based on Europe has a business I the U.S., (inaudible) U.S. also being a consolidator. But they are, at the moment, financially stressed and probably can't do anything.

LACQUA: Bruce How are a lot of these deals going to be financed if they come back to fruition? If it's almost the end of the era of cheap money, does it impact actually cross border consolidation?

KASMAN: Well, I think right now, it's the end of the era of emergency priced money. But if we look at U.S. policy rates being just at the rate of inflation, if we look at an ECB that still has negative interest rates and we have a BOJ which is isn't going to be moving the short rate any time soon, I think it will be a mistake to say that we're having an issue here with high interest rates and access to credit. I think we're at still a pretty favorable environment for credit. And in fact, I think it's improving in Europe and in the emerging markets compared to where we were for most of the last three or four years. And I don't think credit and interest rates are an obstacle here for deals or for the global economy to move forward.

LACQUA: All right. Bruce, thank you so much. Bruce Kasman there of JP Morgan and Chris Marangi of Gabelli funds both stay with us.

KEENE: Let me go to something Bruce Kasman has got his eye on and sort of tangential. But on a Monday, we're struggling to find things to talk about. I'm kidding. We've got Turkish lira up. We're doing this for a quick clear off (ph) and in today chart in the Bloomberg, another leg up on the 24th of July. And, again, it was just -- it's another EM (inaudible), Bruce Kasman. And whether it's Turkish lira, Brazilian real, on and on, they're all idiosyncratic until they're not. And you and I remember the third week of August 1998 when we got to until they're not. How close are we until they're not?

KASMAN: Well, I think the point you're making is an important one, which is we don't actually always see these interactions take place. But as we're looking at the world right now, we don't see the big rise in global interest rates. We see a big backdrop on growth that's pretty solid. We can recognize that the Turkish story and the Brazilian story and the Argentine story have very idiosyncratic elements to it. So we don't think this is going to spill over. But I do think any time we're seeing the fed tightening, any time we're seeing some stress points here, we have to worry that there could be spillovers that were not appreciated.

KEENE: Is your call strong dollar? Does John Norman (ph) say, strong dollar up?

KASMAN: No. Actually our call is that the dollar strength, given that the trade story doesn't intensify that the dollar is actually going to weaken a little bit in the second half of the year as we feel better about global growth, particularly global growth outside the U.S. And we begin to see some modest weakening in the dollar off of that.

LACQUA: Bruce, do you worry about the fact that despite tariffs and despite trade, there seems to be a need (ph) from central banks to start normalizing. Is it the right time worldwide in the economy to do so?

KASMAN: Well, again, I want to emphasize, the ECB is not going to be raising rates for a year. The BOJ, even if it makes a tweak to a deal controlled target today is not moving policy rates up. The amount of tightening we're getting in global central banks is extremely small and coming from very easy levels. I think the real question we're asking right now is the fed that's moving steadily and is pushing up dollar interest rates in a world in which dollar funding is very important, whether there's a stress point on that, not whether not we're getting tight or it's really mid (inaudible) tightening in financial conditions because of what central banks are doing.

LACQUA: Yes. But on the fed's -- Secretary Mnuchin suggested yesterday that it's fine for the Federal Reserve to raise rates even if President Trump attacks him. I mean, this is like a central bank's worst nightmare.

KASMAN: Well, there's definitely, I think, an issue around the independence of the fed. But I think the fed is pretty insulated here and understands what its role is. So we don't think the fed is going to be responding to political pressure. We think the fed is a force and motion that's going to move a quarter a percent each quarter here for a while. It's still got another two or three moves at least to get back to neutral.

KEENE: Well, you've talked about the political forces that out there. And, of course, Bruce Kasman, I know Chairman Powell is an enemy of the people. Let's cover this with Chris Marangi right now of Gabelli Funds. The President had a massive Tweet storm this weekend on the press. And, of course, he went after the newspapers, Amazon, Washington Post in that. But in your area, Chris, it's really about the power of cable news and the whole dynamic that all of us are living every day. I mean, I've got my own axe (ph) to grind in all that. But how do you, as an investors, perceive the power of cable news into the election and particularly into the presidential election of 2020?

MARANGI: Well, cable news is very powerful. It's a very valuable asset for and very profitable asset for Fox, as well as for Comcast. Actually, Comcast called out MSNBC, shows the other side of the spectrum is being a strong driver for growth in a bad company. So they're gathering eyeballs (ph) perhaps to the detriment of other forms of entertainment. We saw that in the last election cycle. Maybe see it again now. But, again, very profitable for those networks, very profitable for the broadcasters as well.

KEENE: Can you find any value imprint? I mean, we see the uproar of the Los Angeles Times. Remember (inaudible) used to be with Bloomberg. I should mention, folks, going now to assist in that effort. But is there any value for GAMCO (ph) and Gabelli in traditional print?

MARANGI: Well, it's very difficult to find (inaudible) companies these days. So we have a pretty exposure with the Wall Street Journal with News Corp (ph). And I think the Wall Street Journal is somewhat unique and having -- been able to make the transition in part at least to digital.

LACQUA: Bruce, I don't know whether we're -- it's difficult, right, for markets to understand the deep shifts that we're seeing culturally and in our society. This feels like a big question that could be theoretical, theological, whatever you want to call it, but how does it play out in the markets five to ten years from now?

KASMAN: I think that's a really hard question to get our hands around. But I think the point you're making is right. There are certain things happening now, which are reflected in trade policy, reflected in political outcomes. We're seeing reflected in events like Brexit which do, I think, come out of accumulation of pressure points building over the last five or ten years. And they're going to play out over the next five or ten years. I don't have a clear crystal ball on how these things play out but we have a demographic issue, we have slow underlying supply side performance. I think there are pressure points here that are going to continue to build. And the political implications of this are hard to see but they are, I think, worrisome.

KEENE: Bruce Kasman with us and Chris Marangi as well, lots more to talk about here in the hour.

LACQUA: Now, still with us, Bruce Kasman of JP Morgan and Chris Marangi of Gabelli Funds. Chris, when you look at, I guess, some of the big names out there, I don't whether we're at the point where we say some of the just won't survive, whether if you look at Snap or other ones and say, we don't know how it creates values in four to five years, or do you assume that they'll bought, repackaged and morph into something else?

MARANGI: Yes. I'm not sure if they'll be standalone entities. Scale, as I mentioned this earlier, it is important to the media industry, it's important to the internet industry as well. These companies thrive on data. Data is contentious (ph). So I think John -- I would agree with John that the cost of complying with privacy laws will go up, which will further drive scale and probably consolidation in that industry.

LACQUA: Chris, what does that -- yes. Chris, again, what does that mean for actually the end consumer? What does it mean for regulation? Are you assuming just more and more of it?

MARANGI: Yes. I think -- as I think one of the reasons that Facebook is investing in the experience is, in fact, to head off or try to head off or delay regulation because they have had -- companies like Facebook and Twitter have had such a big impact on the political discourse in this country and around the world.

KEENE: With our single best chart right now, Chris Marangi can weigh in on this inflation just in real ten-year JGB in Japan. No, Bruce Kasman is going to help us out. Chris, dive in here if you want. I'm fascinated by the idea of you go from deflation to disinflation to actual tangible in Japan, and one (inaudible) real rate. Here's the chart, down we go with a long-term real rate decline in Japan. And we get some real improvement with deflation. But then inflation comes in. And even if the yield comes up a little, that inflation squeezes that real rate. What does that mean to the people of Japan and to the banks?

KASMAN: Well, I want to be careful here because all of the inflation that we've seen in the last year in Japan is energy prices. If you strip that out and you look at the core really --

KEENE: And your real rate is better than it is?

KASMAN: Yes. And I think what is very troubling in Japan right now is that we have strong growth, we have a BOJ that's thinking about beginning to make an adjustment away from a GL (ph) controlled policy. But underlying inflation hasn't moved really anywhere closer to the BOJ's target and market measures of inflation expectation are reflecting some loss or credibility in the BOJ.

KEENE: Except that comment sounds a lot like Governor Carney a year ago, nine months or whatever. And I understand the skills and amplitude are different. But it seems like all of these central banks as we get the same problem, they're rationalizing a higher space. And you're talking about enthusiasm of GDP. But reality, Bruce, is the inflation just is not there, is it?

KASMAN: Well, I think when you look at the inflation profile, there is a modest but very modest upward trajectory that you see in most of the developed world. I think what's unique about Japan is Japan is trying to dig itself out of over two decades of deflationary psychology. And that puts it in a very different place than what we're talking about the Bank of England or the fed.

KEENE: And what you just said that is brilliant, I'm going to steal the word from you all this week, is inflation profile, because inflation makeup of each country, each culture is different. I mean, in almost -- Chris, every industry has a different inflation profile. I mean, this is not a cookie cutter central bank. There're some real nuances in these three meetings, right?

MARANGI: Well, there is no doubt. And I think while the fed has an easy (ph) meeting this week and the Bank of England has a tough call, which we think they're going to take the step to tighten, the BOJ is by far, I think, the most interesting one. Because what the BOJ is really struggling with is actually missing its inflation objective and actually the last reading is coming in low with a concern about financial stability of what is you're doing in terms of squeezing out bank profitability

LACQUA: Bruce, when you look at BOE, a lot of people are saying, look, they may hike. But actually, when would you hike when the uncertainty of Brexit is looming large, you have no idea of what kind of trade they'll do and you don't have any idea at this point whether the U.K. will crash out of the E.U. So why hike now? Is it a problem of credibility?

KASMAN: I think your point is a good one. You have all the Brexit uncertainty still hanging over your head. But as a central bank, what you're seeing is growth start to rebound after a hit over the last year. You're seeing wages move higher. And you're really being frustrated by what is still a very weak supply side productivity. Your policy rates are less than 1%. So I think you're kind of balancing risks and leaning against it. What the Bank of England is not doing is suggesting us that we've got a significant rate hike path ahead but they are looking like they're willing to take the step.

LACQUA: What is the single biggest mistake that a central bank can do now? Is it tightening too soon or tightening too late?

KASMAN: Well, I think the biggest mistake would be for the BOJ to tighten right now because I think its credibility is at risk here. And we do have, I think, the deep hole we're digging ourselves out of in terms of trying to get the psychology right. I think if you look at the Bank of England, the fed, these are issues which are right now more on the margin. Obviously, there will be big issues down the road at some point.

KEENE: Chris Marangi with us right now. Compared (ph) to your research notice or bargain, there're bargains out there, what shares, what sector of shares can you acquire this morning?

MARANGI: Well, also we like the (inaudible). We talked about cable. The cable stocks are around sale after Comcast's ill-fated bid for Fox

KEENE: And your cash flows are still persistent.

MARANGI: Cash flows are still terrific. It's all about broad band and the shift on video to broad band. And that, I think, is finally being recognized as the driver for that.

KEENE: Is the iPhone Bryan Roberts friend?

MARANGI: Well, long-term, 5G wireless will get more competitive with the wire broad band product. But that's not something I worry about today. And kind of just thinking about it, they're getting to the wireless business themselves. I would think Netflix, contrary to some people's opinion, is actually Comcast's friend because it drives broad band uptake (ph).

KEENE: Yes. Is YouTube TV of value?

MARANGI: YouTube TV is cheaper than the big bundle. You don't get quite as much as you do in the big bundle. I think if you look at it on the breadth of choice and the Claudia (ph) content, the bundle is still probably your best bet if you've got a big family.

KEENE: Great. Chris, thank you so much for the briefing, particularly on the (inaudible). Bruce Kasman, thank you. As always, I greatly appreciate the Friday memo.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
