urn:contentItem:5SXS-GBV1-F15W-H187-00000-00BRUCE KASMAN, JP MORGAN; AND CHRIS MARANGI, GABELLI FUNDS; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE2018-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:25ZLexisNexisBRUCE KASMAN, JP MORGAN; AND CHRIS MARANGI, GABELLI FUNDS; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE

July 30, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

BRUCE KASMAN, MANAGING DIRECTOR OF GLOBAL RESEARCH, JP MORGAN; AND CHRIS MARANGI, CO-CIO, GABELLI FUNDS

KEENE: Bruce Kasman with us of JP Morgan on a Friday boom economy. The President took a huge victory lap. Did he deserve to take it?

KASMAN: Well not because I think the GDP report is the reflection of his policies, but I think we should feel good about what it tell us about the U.S. economy, looking through the headline number which is distorted by a couple of things, particularly trade. We have as a nice private sector recovery in demand. We have balanced income growth. We're starting the second half of these lean inventories and we've got a fiscal stimulus coming through. It all suggests the economy solid and will continue to grow at a solid base here.

KEENE: The President with the tenth Tweet. I think he was going to do with the 11th Twee this week. And the 11th Tweet, Mr. President, would have been perfect. And that's the idea of the fiscal stimulus. How much is that fiscal stimulus going to be? 0.5% of GDP? Do you have a number?

KASMAN: Well, we think in 2018 and '19, fiscal stimulus is adding about 0.5% per year. There's a little bit of it in the GDP report for the second quarter both on spending --

KEENE: But a lot more to come?

KASMAN: But there's a lot more to come, particularly if the spending side really does reach its peak if our estimates are right as we turn into 2019. So we think the economy can probably hold growth at around 3% pace, something we haven't done during this expansion for much time. And I think that's a really good back draft in the sense that so far we haven't seen late cycle pressure build, we haven't seen the fed move in any kind of aggressive way. So there's nothing really preventing us from continuing to January solid growth here at least for a little while.

LACQUA: Yes. Bruce, what do you worry about? Do you worry about the fed having to like tight rates much more than expected in 2019 or do you worry about something else?

KASMAN: Well, I think the fed and late cycle dynamics in terms of the wage pressure starting to put downward pressure on corporate margins is the central risk of the expansion. I think the good news is it's moving very slowly. On the immediate side, I think we do have to worry about whether this trade war turns into war on trade. I mean, obviously we step back from that last week with the E.U. meeting. But my concern would be that what's happening here gives businesses a feeling that supply chain's broader trade patterns are going to be affected permanently and begin to respond to that in terms of sentiment in their spending.

LACQUA: Okay. What do you wait to see whether that it can be at 3%? Is there a danger that actually the U.S. economy is overheated? Are we there again or we just not analyzing what some of the trade and tariffs could do?

KASMAN: Well, I think for the next six to nine months, the amount that trade in tariffs is going to do to add to inflation is a pretty small amount. I think the bigger question there is sentiment, whether it hurts sentiment in a negative way. More broadly, I think we have tight labor markets. I think we have in our future an overheated economy. I don't' think it's there yet. I don't think the inflation number and the wage numbers are pointing to that, and that's suggest this is going to move pretty slowly.

KEENE: I've got a controversial chart here. I want to bring it up and, Bruce, this is about linking politics into your world of GDP forecasting, which I think is baloney yet we do it every day. So what we've got here, I'm going to make this bright red so you can see it, really, all. I'll get this out on Bloomberg out on Twitter. This is the 20-year average here at 3.2%, the world's great. And then with the huge contraction that we had early, Obama, you come in here down, and the President in this early years has brought it up just a little bit as well. Within all of your experience, I mean this President is off labors, boy, do they run and hide when it's bad and they love to come out when it's good. But can you really link GDP growth in the public policy?

KASMAN: Look, there is a fiscal stimulus working through this system and if we want to champion that. And I wouldn't champion that at this point in the cycle, it's adding to demand and it's supporting growth. But the broader story that's improving growth here, which has a global dimension to it and a domestic dimension, is something that has been growing for two to three years as we're getting the benefits of very supportive monetary policy as we're finally getting the healing in the post-financial crisis period come through the system. So I think it would be a mistake at any point in time to tie near term economic performance to immediate policy changes.

KEENE: We're thrilled to have you here at the start of the week with JP Morgan, Bruce Kasman. He'll continue with us through the hour.

With us is Bruce Kasman of JP Morgan, and we're thrilled to bring you a timely discussion and conversation with Chris Marangi. He is with the Gabelli Funds, of course, on media and on all the infrastructure and things that hold it together. I must touch on and Mr. Moonves' fate this week, it is a cross all of the headlines, particularly here in New York City. How important is Mr. Moonves to CBS for shareholders and investors?

MARANGI: Yes. Well, one of the interview questions I give is do you buy asset or management given a choice. We had a great situation at CBS where we had both. But ultimately, we want to buy the asset and the assets are the same. Les has done a great job and he is important to the story though.

KEENE: What do you do with CBS right now? Do you just wait out the soap opera?

MARANGI: Well, yes, I think (inaudible) and we think about it as a 2x2 matrix. CBS, what's the value of CBS with Moonves without him, what's the value of the combination of CBS and Viacom with Moonves, without him. The answer is that CBS is worth more in all those cases, but the market has increased a probability that we're going to be without Moonves.

KEENE: After what we've been through with Fox, Disney in all, there's been all sorts of discussions of CBS combining almost on distribution reasons with other networks, CNN mention and others as well. Is that they're future, they've just got to find distribution?

MARANGI: Well, scale is critical in this business. You saw obviously Comcast trying to achieve bigger scale with five since he's doing that with. So I think eventually you'll see CBS a somebody else. I don't know who will be that.

KEENE: You don't know how to be right, you don't want to inform us on a Monday how many it would affect. Inform us on what that occurred last week. We see a real dominance, a separation in technology of Google and Amazon and others, Facebook and Twitter, disappointing shareholders? What's yours and Mario's observation of that?

MARANGI: Well, what we learned last week is the fangs just don't go up all the time. So, listen, Facebook said two bad words on their call. They talked about deceleration and margin compression, and growth investors don't want to see that. I think long-term is probably doing the right thing for the stock. And The stock is basically back to where it was at the beginning of the year. So we're not terribly distressed by it.

LACQUA: All right. But, Chris, overall, and good morning from London, what's your biggest concern when it comes to fanged stocks? Anyway, we're not really leaving the bubble bursting in the year 2000, right? This is different, and yet there are fault line.

MARANGI: It's clearly different than the late 90's early 2000's. Valuation are rich. I don't think they're overly stretched for most member of the fang. There are differences obviously between members of the fang. And as Tom mentioned, we are seeing a little bit of a decoupling. I think, frankly, Facebook's results make Google results look although much more better because they did a terrific job of navigating some of the changes in regulation and the concerns over privacy.

LACQUA: All right. But what do you do with the snap? What do you do with Twitter?

KASMAN: I think those are -- those don't quite have a scale. Obviously, Twitter has been quite a platform. They helped the President quite a bit. And their stocks have done well but obviously a lot of change there.

LACQUA: Okay. Chris, overall, I know we're also expecting Apple. I mean, how do you take advantage of A.I.? If you look at the big trend in the next 5, 10, 15 years, do you go just for chipmakers in, for example, Asian markets or do you go after some of these big tech stocks?

MARANGI: Well, I think one of the things that we like are recurring revenue businesses. And the services business at Apple is growing a very attractive part of that business. They have a global platform for music and entertainment. So we like that aspect of stock. Obviously, it's cheap. You've got Warren Buffet buying it.

KEENE: Here are the (inaudible), Bruce Kasman. The backdrop is Kasman's optimism of JP Morgan economy. When you filter through earnings, which is part of economics, when the corporate might get out there, what do you see 12 months more (ph)? Are you going to tell Marangi to shut up and load the boat here on a Monday?

KASMAN: Well, I think what you're seeing a pretty healthy upturn in corporate profits that's supported the macro fundamentals. I think what's nice right now is we have a reasonably balanced income dynamic in the U.S. and globally with employment growing close to a decade high and corporate profits continuing to grow. We worry tight labor market will eventually upset the apple cart by start to create a wedge between wages and productivity, compressed margins, it's going to happen but it's not happening now.

KEENE: But to the savings revisions we saw in the GDP report, which to me were the biggest thing in the report, Chris, people have the disposable income to do media, don't they?

MARANGI: They do, but they're saving money by -- some are by are cutting the cord and putting more -- keeping more money in their pockets.

KEENE: But the money they're utting accord is going to -- I would say, suggest, it's going to other media sources, right?

MARANGI: Well, it's going to broad band, for example. Which is why we like -- still like the cable stocks. Broad band plays as oppose to the view.

KEENE: So Comcast now has a screening value after the collapse since the merge?

MARANGI: It was and it is even more valued today as a starter.

LACQUA: (Inaudible ) overall, if you look at consolidation, I don't know whether this is domestic, so it's U.S. or whether you lost possibility of an outsider coming and buying some of the domestic players?

MARANGI: Yes. So you've got obviously sprints which is still backed Softbank and T-Mobile backed by Deutsche Telecom, trying to come together. If that happens, I think it will be -- a lot of sense for them to buy an infrastructure provider like charter, which will be the one for sale. I don't think Comcast is for sales. So those would be two, if I had in the past talk about LTs, of course, based on Europe has a business I the U.S., (inaudible) U.S. also being a consolidator. But they are, at the moment, financially stressed and probably can't do anything.

LACQUA: Bruce How are a lot of these deals going to be financed if they come back to fruition? If it's almost the end of the era of cheap money, does it impact actually cross border consolidation?

KASMAN: Well, I think right now, it's the end of the era of emergency priced money. But if we look at U.S. policy rates being just at the rate of inflation, if we look at an ECB that still has negative interest rates and we have a BOJ which is isn't going to be moving the short rate any time soon, I think it will be a mistake to say that we're having an issue here with high interest rates and access to credit. I think we're at still a pretty favorable environment for credit. And in fact, I think it's improving in Europe and in the emerging markets compared to where we were for most of the last three or four years. And I don't think credit and interest rates are an obstacle here for deals or for the global economy to move forward.

LACQUA: All right. Bruce, thank you so much. Bruce Kasman there of JP Morgan and Chris Marangi of Gabelli funds both stay with us.

KEENE: Let me go to something Bruce Kasman has got his eye on and sort of tangential. But on a Monday, we're struggling to find things to talk about. I'm kidding. We've got Turkish lira up. We're doing this for a quick clear off (ph) and in today chart in the Bloomberg, another leg up on the 24th of July. And, again, it was just -- it's another EM (inaudible), Bruce Kasman. And whether it's Turkish lira, Brazilian real, on and on, they're all idiosyncratic until they're not. And you and I remember the third week of August 1998 when we got to until they're not. How close are we until they're not?

KASMAN: Well, I think the point you're making is an important one, which is we don't actually always see these interactions take place. But as we're looking at the world right now, we don't see the big rise in global interest rates. We see a big backdrop on growth that's pretty solid. We can recognize that the Turkish story and the Brazilian story and the Argentine story have very idiosyncratic elements to it. So we don't think this is going to spill over. But I do think any time we're seeing the fed tightening, any time we're seeing some stress points here, we have to worry that there could be spillovers that were not appreciated.

KEENE: Is your call strong dollar? Does John Norman (ph) say, strong dollar up?

KASMAN: No. Actually our call is that the dollar strength, given that the trade story doesn't intensify that the dollar is actually going to weaken a little bit in the second half of the year as we feel better about global growth, particularly global growth outside the U.S. And we begin to see some modest weakening in the dollar off of that.

LACQUA: Bruce, do you worry about the fact that despite tariffs and despite trade, there seems to be a need (ph) from central banks to start normalizing. Is it the right time worldwide in the economy to do so?

KASMAN: Well, again, I want to emphasize, the ECB is not going to be raising rates for a year. The BOJ, even if it makes a tweak to a deal controlled target today is not moving policy rates up. The amount of tightening we're getting in global central banks is extremely small and coming from very easy levels. I think the real question we're asking right now is the fed that's moving steadily and is pushing up dollar interest rates in a world in which dollar funding is very important, whether there's a stress point on that, not whether not we're getting tight or it's really mid (inaudible) tightening in financial conditions because of what central banks are doing.

LACQUA: Yes. But on the fed's -- Secretary Mnuchin suggested yesterday that it's fine for the Federal Reserve to raise rates even if President Trump attacks him. I mean, this is like a central bank's worst nightmare.

KASMAN: Well, there's definitely, I think, an issue around the independence of the fed. But I think the fed is pretty insulated here and understands what its role is. So we don't think the fed is going to be responding to political pressure. We think the fed is a force and motion that's going to move a quarter a percent each quarter here for a while. It's still got another two or three moves at least to get back to neutral.

KEENE: Well, you've talked about the political forces that out there. And, of course, Bruce Kasman, I know Chairman Powell is an enemy of the people. Let's cover this with Chris Marangi right now of Gabelli Funds. The President had a massive Tweet storm this weekend on the press. And, of course, he went after the newspapers, Amazon, Washington Post in that. But in your area, Chris, it's really about the power of cable news and the whole dynamic that all of us are living every day. I mean, I've got my own axe (ph) to grind in all that. But how do you, as an investors, perceive the power of cable news into the election and particularly into the presidential election of 2020?

MARANGI: Well, cable news is very powerful. It's a very valuable asset for and very profitable asset for Fox, as well as for Comcast. Actually, Comcast called out MSNBC, shows the other side of the spectrum is being a strong driver for growth in a bad company. So they're gathering eyeballs (ph) perhaps to the detriment of other forms of entertainment. We saw that in the last election cycle. Maybe see it again now. But, again, very profitable for those networks, very profitable for the broadcasters as well.

KEENE: Can you find any value imprint? I mean, we see the uproar of the Los Angeles Times. Remember (inaudible) used to be with Bloomberg. I should mention, folks, going now to assist in that effort. But is there any value for GAMCO (ph) and Gabelli in traditional print?

MARANGI: Well, it's very difficult to find (inaudible) companies these days. So we have a pretty exposure with the Wall Street Journal with News Corp (ph). And I think the Wall Street Journal is somewhat unique and having -- been able to make the transition in part at least to digital.

LACQUA: Bruce, I don't know whether we're -- it's difficult, right, for markets to understand the deep shifts that we're seeing culturally and in our society. This feels like a big question that could be theoretical, theological, whatever you want to call it, but how does it play out in the markets five to ten years from now?

KASMAN: I think that's a really hard question to get our hands around. But I think the point you're making is right. There are certain things happening now, which are reflected in trade policy, reflected in political outcomes. We're seeing reflected in events like Brexit which do, I think, come out of accumulation of pressure points building over the last five or ten years. And they're going to play out over the next five or ten years. I don't have a clear crystal ball on how these things play out but we have a demographic issue, we have slow underlying supply side performance. I think there are pressure points here that are going to continue to build. And the political implications of this are hard to see but they are, I think, worrisome.

KEENE: Bruce Kasman with us and Chris Marangi as well, lots more to talk about here in the hour.

LACQUA: Now, still with us, Bruce Kasman of JP Morgan and Chris Marangi of Gabelli Funds. Chris, when you look at, I guess, some of the big names out there, I don't whether we're at the point where we say some of the just won't survive, whether if you look at Snap or other ones and say, we don't know how it creates values in four to five years, or do you assume that they'll bought, repackaged and morph into something else?

MARANGI: Yes. I'm not sure if they'll be standalone entities. Scale, as I mentioned this earlier, it is important to the media industry, it's important to the internet industry as well. These companies thrive on data. Data is contentious (ph). So I think John -- I would agree with John that the cost of complying with privacy laws will go up, which will further drive scale and probably consolidation in that industry.

LACQUA: Chris, what does that -- yes. Chris, again, what does that mean for actually the end consumer? What does it mean for regulation? Are you assuming just more and more of it?

MARANGI: Yes. I think -- as I think one of the reasons that Facebook is investing in the experience is, in fact, to head off or try to head off or delay regulation because they have had -- companies like Facebook and Twitter have had such a big impact on the political discourse in this country and around the world.

KEENE: With our single best chart right now, Chris Marangi can weigh in on this inflation just in real ten-year JGB in Japan. No, Bruce Kasman is going to help us out. Chris, dive in here if you want. I'm fascinated by the idea of you go from deflation to disinflation to actual tangible in Japan, and one (inaudible) real rate. Here's the chart, down we go with a long-term real rate decline in Japan. And we get some real improvement with deflation. But then inflation comes in. And even if the yield comes up a little, that inflation squeezes that real rate. What does that mean to the people of Japan and to the banks?

KASMAN: Well, I want to be careful here because all of the inflation that we've seen in the last year in Japan is energy prices. If you strip that out and you look at the core really --

KEENE: And your real rate is better than it is?

KASMAN: Yes. And I think what is very troubling in Japan right now is that we have strong growth, we have a BOJ that's thinking about beginning to make an adjustment away from a GL (ph) controlled policy. But underlying inflation hasn't moved really anywhere closer to the BOJ's target and market measures of inflation expectation are reflecting some loss or credibility in the BOJ.

KEENE: Except that comment sounds a lot like Governor Carney a year ago, nine months or whatever. And I understand the skills and amplitude are different. But it seems like all of these central banks as we get the same problem, they're rationalizing a higher space. And you're talking about enthusiasm of GDP. But reality, Bruce, is the inflation just is not there, is it?

KASMAN: Well, I think when you look at the inflation profile, there is a modest but very modest upward trajectory that you see in most of the developed world. I think what's unique about Japan is Japan is trying to dig itself out of over two decades of deflationary psychology. And that puts it in a very different place than what we're talking about the Bank of England or the fed.

KEENE: And what you just said that is brilliant, I'm going to steal the word from you all this week, is inflation profile, because inflation makeup of each country, each culture is different. I mean, in almost -- Chris, every industry has a different inflation profile. I mean, this is not a cookie cutter central bank. There're some real nuances in these three meetings, right?

MARANGI: Well, there is no doubt. And I think while the fed has an easy (ph) meeting this week and the Bank of England has a tough call, which we think they're going to take the step to tighten, the BOJ is by far, I think, the most interesting one. Because what the BOJ is really struggling with is actually missing its inflation objective and actually the last reading is coming in low with a concern about financial stability of what is you're doing in terms of squeezing out bank profitability

LACQUA: Bruce, when you look at BOE, a lot of people are saying, look, they may hike. But actually, when would you hike when the uncertainty of Brexit is looming large, you have no idea of what kind of trade they'll do and you don't have any idea at this point whether the U.K. will crash out of the E.U. So why hike now? Is it a problem of credibility?

KASMAN: I think your point is a good one. You have all the Brexit uncertainty still hanging over your head. But as a central bank, what you're seeing is growth start to rebound after a hit over the last year. You're seeing wages move higher. And you're really being frustrated by what is still a very weak supply side productivity. Your policy rates are less than 1%. So I think you're kind of balancing risks and leaning against it. What the Bank of England is not doing is suggesting us that we've got a significant rate hike path ahead but they are looking like they're willing to take the step.

LACQUA: What is the single biggest mistake that a central bank can do now? Is it tightening too soon or tightening too late?

KASMAN: Well, I think the biggest mistake would be for the BOJ to tighten right now because I think its credibility is at risk here. And we do have, I think, the deep hole we're digging ourselves out of in terms of trying to get the psychology right. I think if you look at the Bank of England, the fed, these are issues which are right now more on the margin. Obviously, there will be big issues down the road at some point.

KEENE: Chris Marangi with us right now. Compared (ph) to your research notice or bargain, there're bargains out there, what shares, what sector of shares can you acquire this morning?

MARANGI: Well, also we like the (inaudible). We talked about cable. The cable stocks are around sale after Comcast's ill-fated bid for Fox

KEENE: And your cash flows are still persistent.

MARANGI: Cash flows are still terrific. It's all about broad band and the shift on video to broad band. And that, I think, is finally being recognized as the driver for that.

KEENE: Is the iPhone Bryan Roberts friend?

MARANGI: Well, long-term, 5G wireless will get more competitive with the wire broad band product. But that's not something I worry about today. And kind of just thinking about it, they're getting to the wireless business themselves. I would think Netflix, contrary to some people's opinion, is actually Comcast's friend because it drives broad band uptake (ph).

KEENE: Yes. Is YouTube TV of value?

MARANGI: YouTube TV is cheaper than the big bundle. You don't get quite as much as you do in the big bundle. I think if you look at it on the breadth of choice and the Claudia (ph) content, the bundle is still probably your best bet if you've got a big family.

KEENE: Great. Chris, thank you so much for the briefing, particularly on the (inaudible). Bruce Kasman, thank you. As always, I greatly appreciate the Friday memo.

END

Bruce Rauner, Chairman, GTCR, J.B. Pritzker, Founder, New World Ventures, Are Interviewed At Bloomberg Tv

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

BRUCE RAUNER, CHAIRMAN, GTCR, JAY PRITZKER, FOUNDER, NEW WORLD VENTURES, ARE INTERVIEWED AT BLOOMBERG TV

JUNE 30, 2011

SPEAKERS: BETTY LIU, BLOOMBERG NEWS ANCHOR

BRUCE RAUNER, CHAIRMAN, GTCR

J.B. PRITZKER, FOUNDER, NEW WORLD VENTURES

09:14

BETTY LIU, BLOOMBERG NEWS ANCHOR: I want to bring in two houses in the investment world here with me. Bruce Rauner is the Chairman and also Principal at GTCR, which just closed a new $3.25 billion buyout fund called Fund X (ph).

Also with me J.B. Pritzker, who is the Founder of New World Ventures, which invests mostly in young technology companies here in Chicago. One big tech company that we know about, of course, is Groupon, which we'll talk about in a moment.

Now, for you, two, and by the way, thanks so much for joining us here.

BRUCE RAUNER, CHAIRMAN, GTCR: Thank (ph) you.

LIU: For the both of you, has it gotten a lot harder to find companies to put your money in?

RAUNER: The answer is, yes. The markets are more and more efficient every year in the private equity, in the venture capital world, more competitive. But the reality is innovation and entrepreneurship is alive and thriving in the United States.

And there are a lot of good opportunities.

J.B. PRITZKER, FOUNDER, NEW WORLD VENTURES: Strangely, some of the best companies in the startup world are created in recessions. Google's a great example of that. Groupon is a good example of that.

And so at least in the venture capital world, there has been quite a lot of activity. It's booming. You see that in the IPO market now.

LIU: Right.

PRITZKER: And companies that were just created a few years ago.

LIU: So are you finding more startup investments?

PRITZKER: We are. There are an awful lot more people that are interested in looking at investing in startups even at the earliest stages.

LIU: Valuations?

PRITZKER: Well, they're lofty. And I think that's true across the entire spectrum of private equity and venture capital.

And I can't really explain why there are probably macroeconomic reasons why there's certainly a lot of lending that's available to private equity firms going in and buying companies and stable (ph) financings.

But in the venture world, I think there's a desire to look for, you know, risk reward that makes sense. And in the venture world, you can see these outsize returns at this point in the cycle. So I think people are diving in head first.

LIU: At this point.

Bruce, what about valuations in some of the deals that you're looking at? I mean, you know, we've been hearing, for instance, that some of the stellar, they just want too much in this environment and you wonder why.

RAUNER: Well, the answer to the question is there's plenty of capital out there. There is a surprising amount of equity capital available across the entire stage of investment. And private equity world, the venture capital world is relatively flush with money.

And that competition to that money creates is driving valuations high.

LIU: But what's going on here? Why is that exactly?

RAUNER: There is a demographic trend where pension funds are very flush with capital...

LIU: OK.

RAUNER: ...across corporate America and in state governments. And all that potential (ph) capital is looking for a high rate of return. They can't find it in bond markets. They can't really find it very well in public markets, in the stock market.

But they've been able to find it historically in venture capital and then private equity. And it's driven into our industry in large amounts.

LIU: Bruce, you know, looking through when I was doing some research, I mean, you've been actually pretty quite open about saying that the Obama administration, the White House has been hostile to business.

Why does that matter to you?

RAUNER: Well, I think the federal government sets a tone and a standard for economic growth. And I think you can't be pro-jobs and pro- economic growth and be anti-business. You can't be about regulation, taxes, coming up with ways to make it more expensive for employees to be hired.

And unfortunately, in recent years, the federal government has been on that track.

LIU: And you heard that even more, I mean, he's digging his heels in yesterday when he was talking about private jetsetters and all that sort of stuff in his comments yesterday. What did you make of that?

RAUNER: Oh, I don't know. I think we are on a bad track today in our attitude between the federal government and business community. And we've got to change that.

LIU: What about for you?

PRITZKER: Well, you know, in the startup world, we'll talk about that. You know, a lot of that discussion doesn't really impact it. You're talking about, you know, at the earliest stages, one, two, three-person companies. They aren't affected by the discussion about regulation, unions, et cetera.

And so what they are affected by is capital availability. And right now, in the venture world, there's a lot of capital available. It's not always the case. The problem really is in companies that aren't venture-capital ready.

And you know, folks who just want to start a restaurants start a small business, a barbershop in their neighborhood, that capital is not available. And the banks aren't loaning.

LIU: Right. And although we had Rick Waddell earlier who said the banks do want to lend but they are just not finding quality borrowers, essentially, so this debate can go on and on, I know.

RAUNER: That's true.

LIU: Bruce, thank you so much.

And actually, I want you both to hang on because we're going to talk more about the money management world. We're going to be back with Bruce Rauner and J.B. Pritzker in just a few moments, live here from Chicago.

09:18

(BREAK)

09:23

LIU: We are back with our two guests here, Bruce Rauner, the Chairman and Principal at GTCR, the private equity firm, also J.B. Pritzker with us as well, the Founder of New World Ventures.

I want to stay with technology for a moment, J.B. Did you invest in Groupon? You did invest, right?

PRITZKER: We did not.

LIU: OK. Are you picking yourself for not investing?

PRITZKER: Well, look, it's a great company. And the guys who created it are - they're operators. So they did a great job of putting together. It's a very young company. But it is, you know, a rocket to the stars...

LIU: But did they approach you at some point?

PRITZKER: Yes, later on when they were in their later stages. We're an early stage IT investment firm.

LIU: OK.

PRITZKER: So we weren't interested in kind of the multi-billion dollar valuations. But look, it's going to be a terrific IPO and a great thing for Chicago.

LIU: Well, I was going to say, I mean, the fame that Groupon has generated, you know, for the social media companies, you know, in the coupon space, how has that changed? Or has that been a game changer at all here in Chicago?

PRITZKER: It has. Look, I think Groupon is a symptom of something going on in Chicago right now which is we've created the foundation here for an unbelievably, you know, elaborate and well put together underpinning for a technology ecosystem.

So entrepreneurs that are starting businesses here had capital available to them. They've got talent available to them at our terrific institutions UFI (ph). You have seen Northwestern and IIT (ph).

So Chicago is really going to end up a center of technology. And Groupon is, again, it's going to be a great IPO. But just behind that are companies like GrubHub and Sittercity and other big companies that you're going to hear about.

LIU: Are those some of your companies?

PRITZKER: Yes, Sittercity is one.

LIU: OK.

Bruce, talking about IPOs, we've seen quite a few private equity firms come out into the public market. Would you ever consider that?

RAUNER: I don't think it would be right for our firm. And in general, I think private equity or venture capital firms that are focused on a particular strategy aren't very good public companies. They're too volatile and too unpredictable. The firms that have...

LIU: Well, you know a lot of these talks go (ph) down. I mean, it works it (ph) down with 70 percent.

RAUNER: We're in a very, very cyclical business in private equity investing. And the reality is the firms that have gone public, we'll see how their stocks do. But they've very much change and diversified. They're broad-asset management firms.

They're in mezzanine. They're in real estate. They're in M&A advisory works. So they have very diversified financial services.

LIU: But if you stay private, are you going to have any trouble retaining talent at all?

RAUNER: Not at all. Frankly, I think it's easier to retain talent as a private firm because we can be flexible on the compensations with our people.

LIU: Bruce, J.B., thank you so much. Really appreciate you staying with us and talking about...

PRITZKER (ph): Thank you.

LIU: ...all things technology and what's going on in the private equity world.

09:26

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

BRUCE RAUNER, CHAIRMAN, GTCR, JAY PRITZKER, FOUNDER, NEW WORLD VENTURES, ARE INTERVIEWED AT BLOOMBERG TV

JUNE 30, 2011

SPEAKERS: BETTY LIU, BLOOMBERG NEWS ANCHOR

BRUCE RAUNER, CHAIRMAN, GTCR

J.B. PRITZKER, FOUNDER, NEW WORLD VENTURES

09:14

BETTY LIU, BLOOMBERG NEWS ANCHOR: I want to bring in two houses in the investment world here with me. Bruce Rauner is the Chairman and also Principal at GTCR, which just closed a new $3.25 billion buyout fund called Fund X (ph).

Also with me J.B. Pritzker, who is the Founder of New World Ventures, which invests mostly in young technology companies here in Chicago. One big tech company that we know about, of course, is Groupon, which we'll talk about in a moment.

Now, for you, two, and by the way, thanks so much for joining us here.

BRUCE RAUNER, CHAIRMAN, GTCR: Thank (ph) you.

LIU: For the both of you, has it gotten a lot harder to find companies to put your money in?

RAUNER: The answer is, yes. The markets are more and more efficient every year in the private equity, in the venture capital world, more competitive. But the reality is innovation and entrepreneurship is alive and thriving in the United States.

And there are a lot of good opportunities.

J.B. PRITZKER, FOUNDER, NEW WORLD VENTURES: Strangely, some of the best companies in the startup world are created in recessions. Google's a great example of that. Groupon is a good example of that.

And so at least in the venture capital world, there has been quite a lot of activity. It's booming. You see that in the IPO market now.

LIU: Right.

PRITZKER: And companies that were just created a few years ago.

LIU: So are you finding more startup investments?

PRITZKER: We are. There are an awful lot more people that are interested in looking at investing in startups even at the earliest stages.

LIU: Valuations?

PRITZKER: Well, they're lofty. And I think that's true across the entire spectrum of private equity and venture capital.

And I can't really explain why there are probably macroeconomic reasons why there's certainly a lot of lending that's available to private equity firms going in and buying companies and stable (ph) financings.

But in the venture world, I think there's a desire to look for, you know, risk reward that makes sense. And in the venture world, you can see these outsize returns at this point in the cycle. So I think people are diving in head first.

LIU: At this point.

Bruce, what about valuations in some of the deals that you're looking at? I mean, you know, we've been hearing, for instance, that some of the stellar, they just want too much in this environment and you wonder why.

RAUNER: Well, the answer to the question is there's plenty of capital out there. There is a surprising amount of equity capital available across the entire stage of investment. And private equity world, the venture capital world is relatively flush with money.

And that competition to that money creates is driving valuations high.

LIU: But what's going on here? Why is that exactly?

RAUNER: There is a demographic trend where pension funds are very flush with capital...

LIU: OK.

RAUNER: ...across corporate America and in state governments. And all that potential (ph) capital is looking for a high rate of return. They can't find it in bond markets. They can't really find it very well in public markets, in the stock market.

But they've been able to find it historically in venture capital and then private equity. And it's driven into our industry in large amounts.

LIU: Bruce, you know, looking through when I was doing some research, I mean, you've been actually pretty quite open about saying that the Obama administration, the White House has been hostile to business.

Why does that matter to you?

RAUNER: Well, I think the federal government sets a tone and a standard for economic growth. And I think you can't be pro-jobs and pro- economic growth and be anti-business. You can't be about regulation, taxes, coming up with ways to make it more expensive for employees to be hired.

And unfortunately, in recent years, the federal government has been on that track.

LIU: And you heard that even more, I mean, he's digging his heels in yesterday when he was talking about private jetsetters and all that sort of stuff in his comments yesterday. What did you make of that?

RAUNER: Oh, I don't know. I think we are on a bad track today in our attitude between the federal government and business community. And we've got to change that.

LIU: What about for you?

PRITZKER: Well, you know, in the startup world, we'll talk about that. You know, a lot of that discussion doesn't really impact it. You're talking about, you know, at the earliest stages, one, two, three-person companies. They aren't affected by the discussion about regulation, unions, et cetera.

And so what they are affected by is capital availability. And right now, in the venture world, there's a lot of capital available. It's not always the case. The problem really is in companies that aren't venture-capital ready.

And you know, folks who just want to start a restaurants start a small business, a barbershop in their neighborhood, that capital is not available. And the banks aren't loaning.

LIU: Right. And although we had Rick Waddell earlier who said the banks do want to lend but they are just not finding quality borrowers, essentially, so this debate can go on and on, I know.

RAUNER: That's true.

LIU: Bruce, thank you so much.

And actually, I want you both to hang on because we're going to talk more about the money management world. We're going to be back with Bruce Rauner and J.B. Pritzker in just a few moments, live here from Chicago.

09:18

(BREAK)

09:23

LIU: We are back with our two guests here, Bruce Rauner, the Chairman and Principal at GTCR, the private equity firm, also J.B. Pritzker with us as well, the Founder of New World Ventures.

I want to stay with technology for a moment, J.B. Did you invest in Groupon? You did invest, right?

PRITZKER: We did not.

LIU: OK. Are you picking yourself for not investing?

PRITZKER: Well, look, it's a great company. And the guys who created it are - they're operators. So they did a great job of putting together. It's a very young company. But it is, you know, a rocket to the stars...

LIU: But did they approach you at some point?

PRITZKER: Yes, later on when they were in their later stages. We're an early stage IT investment firm.

LIU: OK.

PRITZKER: So we weren't interested in kind of the multi-billion dollar valuations. But look, it's going to be a terrific IPO and a great thing for Chicago.

LIU: Well, I was going to say, I mean, the fame that Groupon has generated, you know, for the social media companies, you know, in the coupon space, how has that changed? Or has that been a game changer at all here in Chicago?

PRITZKER: It has. Look, I think Groupon is a symptom of something going on in Chicago right now which is we've created the foundation here for an unbelievably, you know, elaborate and well put together underpinning for a technology ecosystem.

So entrepreneurs that are starting businesses here had capital available to them. They've got talent available to them at our terrific institutions UFI (ph). You have seen Northwestern and IIT (ph).

So Chicago is really going to end up a center of technology. And Groupon is, again, it's going to be a great IPO. But just behind that are companies like GrubHub and Sittercity and other big companies that you're going to hear about.

LIU: Are those some of your companies?

PRITZKER: Yes, Sittercity is one.

LIU: OK.

Bruce, talking about IPOs, we've seen quite a few private equity firms come out into the public market. Would you ever consider that?

RAUNER: I don't think it would be right for our firm. And in general, I think private equity or venture capital firms that are focused on a particular strategy aren't very good public companies. They're too volatile and too unpredictable. The firms that have...

LIU: Well, you know a lot of these talks go (ph) down. I mean, it works it (ph) down with 70 percent.

RAUNER: We're in a very, very cyclical business in private equity investing. And the reality is the firms that have gone public, we'll see how their stocks do. But they've very much change and diversified. They're broad-asset management firms.

They're in mezzanine. They're in real estate. They're in M&A advisory works. So they have very diversified financial services.

LIU: But if you stay private, are you going to have any trouble retaining talent at all?

RAUNER: Not at all. Frankly, I think it's easier to retain talent as a private firm because we can be flexible on the compensations with our people.

LIU: Bruce, J.B., thank you so much. Really appreciate you staying with us and talking about...

PRITZKER (ph): Thank you.

LIU: ...all things technology and what's going on in the private equity world.

09:26

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

BRUCE RAUNER, CHAIRMAN, GTCR, JAY PRITZKER, FOUNDER, NEW WORLD VENTURES, ARE INTERVIEWED AT BLOOMBERG TV

JUNE 30, 2011

SPEAKERS: BETTY LIU, BLOOMBERG NEWS ANCHOR

BRUCE RAUNER, CHAIRMAN, GTCR

J.B. PRITZKER, FOUNDER, NEW WORLD VENTURES

09:14

BETTY LIU, BLOOMBERG NEWS ANCHOR: I want to bring in two houses in the investment world here with me. Bruce Rauner is the Chairman and also Principal at GTCR, which just closed a new $3.25 billion buyout fund called Fund X (ph).

Also with me J.B. Pritzker, who is the Founder of New World Ventures, which invests mostly in young technology companies here in Chicago. One big tech company that we know about, of course, is Groupon, which we'll talk about in a moment.

Now, for you, two, and by the way, thanks so much for joining us here.

BRUCE RAUNER, CHAIRMAN, GTCR: Thank (ph) you.

LIU: For the both of you, has it gotten a lot harder to find companies to put your money in?

RAUNER: The answer is, yes. The markets are more and more efficient every year in the private equity, in the venture capital world, more competitive. But the reality is innovation and entrepreneurship is alive and thriving in the United States.

And there are a lot of good opportunities.

J.B. PRITZKER, FOUNDER, NEW WORLD VENTURES: Strangely, some of the best companies in the startup world are created in recessions. Google's a great example of that. Groupon is a good example of that.

And so at least in the venture capital world, there has been quite a lot of activity. It's booming. You see that in the IPO market now.

LIU: Right.

PRITZKER: And companies that were just created a few years ago.

LIU: So are you finding more startup investments?

PRITZKER: We are. There are an awful lot more people that are interested in looking at investing in startups even at the earliest stages.

LIU: Valuations?

PRITZKER: Well, they're lofty. And I think that's true across the entire spectrum of private equity and venture capital.

And I can't really explain why there are probably macroeconomic reasons why there's certainly a lot of lending that's available to private equity firms going in and buying companies and stable (ph) financings.

But in the venture world, I think there's a desire to look for, you know, risk reward that makes sense. And in the venture world, you can see these outsize returns at this point in the cycle. So I think people are diving in head first.

LIU: At this point.

Bruce, what about valuations in some of the deals that you're looking at? I mean, you know, we've been hearing, for instance, that some of the stellar, they just want too much in this environment and you wonder why.

RAUNER: Well, the answer to the question is there's plenty of capital out there. There is a surprising amount of equity capital available across the entire stage of investment. And private equity world, the venture capital world is relatively flush with money.

And that competition to that money creates is driving valuations high.

LIU: But what's going on here? Why is that exactly?

RAUNER: There is a demographic trend where pension funds are very flush with capital...

LIU: OK.

RAUNER: ...across corporate America and in state governments. And all that potential (ph) capital is looking for a high rate of return. They can't find it in bond markets. They can't really find it very well in public markets, in the stock market.

But they've been able to find it historically in venture capital and then private equity. And it's driven into our industry in large amounts.

LIU: Bruce, you know, looking through when I was doing some research, I mean, you've been actually pretty quite open about saying that the Obama administration, the White House has been hostile to business.

Why does that matter to you?

RAUNER: Well, I think the federal government sets a tone and a standard for economic growth. And I think you can't be pro-jobs and pro- economic growth and be anti-business. You can't be about regulation, taxes, coming up with ways to make it more expensive for employees to be hired.

And unfortunately, in recent years, the federal government has been on that track.

LIU: And you heard that even more, I mean, he's digging his heels in yesterday when he was talking about private jetsetters and all that sort of stuff in his comments yesterday. What did you make of that?

RAUNER: Oh, I don't know. I think we are on a bad track today in our attitude between the federal government and business community. And we've got to change that.

LIU: What about for you?

PRITZKER: Well, you know, in the startup world, we'll talk about that. You know, a lot of that discussion doesn't really impact it. You're talking about, you know, at the earliest stages, one, two, three-person companies. They aren't affected by the discussion about regulation, unions, et cetera.

And so what they are affected by is capital availability. And right now, in the venture world, there's a lot of capital available. It's not always the case. The problem really is in companies that aren't venture-capital ready.

And you know, folks who just want to start a restaurants start a small business, a barbershop in their neighborhood, that capital is not available. And the banks aren't loaning.

LIU: Right. And although we had Rick Waddell earlier who said the banks do want to lend but they are just not finding quality borrowers, essentially, so this debate can go on and on, I know.

RAUNER: That's true.

LIU: Bruce, thank you so much.

And actually, I want you both to hang on because we're going to talk more about the money management world. We're going to be back with Bruce Rauner and J.B. Pritzker in just a few moments, live here from Chicago.

09:18

(BREAK)

09:23

LIU: We are back with our two guests here, Bruce Rauner, the Chairman and Principal at GTCR, the private equity firm, also J.B. Pritzker with us as well, the Founder of New World Ventures.

I want to stay with technology for a moment, J.B. Did you invest in Groupon? You did invest, right?

PRITZKER: We did not.

LIU: OK. Are you picking yourself for not investing?

PRITZKER: Well, look, it's a great company. And the guys who created it are - they're operators. So they did a great job of putting together. It's a very young company. But it is, you know, a rocket to the stars...

LIU: But did they approach you at some point?

PRITZKER: Yes, later on when they were in their later stages. We're an early stage IT investment firm.

LIU: OK.

PRITZKER: So we weren't interested in kind of the multi-billion dollar valuations. But look, it's going to be a terrific IPO and a great thing for Chicago.

LIU: Well, I was going to say, I mean, the fame that Groupon has generated, you know, for the social media companies, you know, in the coupon space, how has that changed? Or has that been a game changer at all here in Chicago?

PRITZKER: It has. Look, I think Groupon is a symptom of something going on in Chicago right now which is we've created the foundation here for an unbelievably, you know, elaborate and well put together underpinning for a technology ecosystem.

So entrepreneurs that are starting businesses here had capital available to them. They've got talent available to them at our terrific institutions UFI (ph). You have seen Northwestern and IIT (ph).

So Chicago is really going to end up a center of technology. And Groupon is, again, it's going to be a great IPO. But just behind that are companies like GrubHub and Sittercity and other big companies that you're going to hear about.

LIU: Are those some of your companies?

PRITZKER: Yes, Sittercity is one.

LIU: OK.

Bruce, talking about IPOs, we've seen quite a few private equity firms come out into the public market. Would you ever consider that?

RAUNER: I don't think it would be right for our firm. And in general, I think private equity or venture capital firms that are focused on a particular strategy aren't very good public companies. They're too volatile and too unpredictable. The firms that have...

LIU: Well, you know a lot of these talks go (ph) down. I mean, it works it (ph) down with 70 percent.

RAUNER: We're in a very, very cyclical business in private equity investing. And the reality is the firms that have gone public, we'll see how their stocks do. But they've very much change and diversified. They're broad-asset management firms.

They're in mezzanine. They're in real estate. They're in M&A advisory works. So they have very diversified financial services.

LIU: But if you stay private, are you going to have any trouble retaining talent at all?

RAUNER: Not at all. Frankly, I think it's easier to retain talent as a private firm because we can be flexible on the compensations with our people.

LIU: Bruce, J.B., thank you so much. Really appreciate you staying with us and talking about...

PRITZKER (ph): Thank you.

LIU: ...all things technology and what's going on in the private equity world.

09:26

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Zuckerberg ha planeado su visita a Bruselas para explicar los intentos de Facebook de autorregularse, de controlarse. Jourová ha explicado que eso no es suficiente

Mark Zuckerberg, CEO de Facebook, no tiene mucha experiencia visitando Bruselas, pero tiene la suficiente como para saber que en la capital comunitaria nadie le va a recibir con cara de buenos amigos, para saber que el viaje no va a ser sencillo y que van a aprovechar cada reunión y cada encuentro por los pasillos para apretarle las tuercas, para recordarle las normas.El Ejecutivo comunitario sabe que una de sus cartas principales, como han demostrado los últimos cinco años de actividades de Margrethe Vestager, entre 2014 y 2019 comisaria de Competencia, es que luchar para que los ‘peces gordos digitales’ cumplan con las normas ha sido una receta de éxito entre los ciudadanos europeos. Y no piensa apartarse de esa pelea.Calviño baraja aplazar el cobro de la tasa Google para evitar el choque con TrumpNacho Alarcón. BruselasLa vicepresidenta ha confirmado que el Consejo de Ministros aprobará este martes las tasas Google y Tobin, y quiere “dar un poco de tiempo para ver cómo avanza el debate”Zuckerberg ha planeado su visita a Bruselas para explicar los intentos de Facebook de autorregularse, de controlarse. Vera Jourová, vicepresidenta de la Comisión Europea a cargo de Valores y Democracia, ha explicado que da la bienvenida a los nuevos intentos del gigante digital, pero eso no es suficiente. “El tiempo de los ‘acuerdos de caballeros’ ha terminado.

Deben ir acompañados de regulación y responsabilidades para las plataformas, y eso es en lo que ya estamos trabajando en la Comisión Europea”, ha asegurado la checa.Cuando Zuckerberg planeó su visita a Bruselas, ya sabía lo que le esperaba. Porque no es nada nuevo y porque es la postura que la Comisión Europea lleva defendiendo ante el gigante digital desde hace mucho tiempo. El americano se ha visto con el comisario de Mercado Interior, el francés Thierry Breton, y también con Vestager y con la vicepresidenta Jourová.No es la primera vez que Bruselas le aprieta las tuercas al CEO de Facebook. En mayo de 2018, el Parlamento Europeo le llevó a una audiencia pública con los líderes de los distintos grupos políticos. Zuckerberg pidió perdón: “No hemos hecho lo suficiente para evitar que las herramientas que hemos creado se utilicen también para causar daño”."El tiempo de los ‘acuerdos de caballeros’ ha terminado. Deben ir acompañados de regulación y responsabilidades para las plataformas"Durante la anterior legislatura, Jourová peleó para conseguir que las grandes plataformas digitales trabajaran para controlar el discurso del odio en sus propias redes, las noticias falsas y las interferencias que afectaban a los procesos democráticos de los Estados miembros. La checa siempre se mostró disconforme con el trabajo hecho por las compañías, con quienes se reunía de forma habitual.“Me alegra ver que el pensamiento de Facebook está cambiando y está más alineado con el enfoque europeo en diferentes aspectos regulatorios. Como siempre dije, veo a las ‘big tech’ como parte de la solución a los problemas que ellas mismas ayudaron a crear”, ha asegurado Jourová tras el encuentro.La UE está entrando en una nueva semana grande en lo que se refiere a regulación digital: se prevé que publique un 'libro blanco' sobre inteligencia artificial en un ambiente cada vez más tenso entre EEUU, China y los distintos gigantes digitales, con Europa en el centro intentando establecer las normas.La experiencia del GDPR, la ley de protección de datos europea, es el modelo a seguir para la Comisión Europea: una norma que ha funcionado y que ha sido vista como un ejemplo para implementar en otros países. Ahora, Bruselas se prepara para dar los próximos pasos, que volverán a ser incómodos para Facebook, pero con los que el Ejecutivo comunitario quiere ser de nuevo pionero.

urn:contentItem:601V-Y651-F068-F02H-00000-00Bruselas tendrá poderes para frenar de forma preventiva a las big tech en la UE;medidas antimonopolio/Las autoridades de Competencia quieren evitar que gigantes tecnológicos como Google, Amazon o Facebook consoliden posiciones dominantes, impedir la irrupción de otros nuevos y controlar su incursión en diferentes sectores.2020-06-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:24ZLexisNexisECONOMÍA/POLÍTICAPág. 20Bruselas tendrá poderes para frenar de forma preventiva a las big tech en la UEmedidas antimonopolio/Las autoridades de Competencia quieren evitar que gigantes tecnológicos como Google, Amazon o Facebook consoliden posiciones dominantes, impedir la irrupción de otros nuevos y controlar su incursión en diferentes sectores.

J. J. Garrido / J. Díaz. Madrid

Margrethe Vestager, considerada desde hace años la bestia negra de los grandes grupos tecnológicos estadounidenses, podría convertirse para ellos en el futuro en una pesadilla mucho mayor. La comisaria danesa, a la que Donald Trump llegó a apodar la señora de los impuestos de la UE y una de las pocas que no solo revalidó su cargo al frente de Competencia en el Ejecutivo que lidera Ursula von der Leyen sino que además vio reforzadas sus atribuciones con su nombramiento como vicepresidenta ejecutiva de la Comisión, quiere dotarse de herramientas legales que le permitan frenar de forma preventiva la expansión de las big tech en Europa y su incursión en otros sectores de actividad. Es decir, frustrar el nacimiento de futuros monopolios antes incluso de que hayan sido concebidos.

El equipo de Vestager diseña un nuevo marco regulatorio que le permita intervenir de forma preventiva en aquellos sectores susceptibles de padecer un alto grado de concentración y restricciones de la competencia como consecuencia de la irrupción de grupos con gran poderío económico, según explican a EXPANSIÓN fuentes próximas a Bruselas.

Es una medida de gran trascendencia y que, sin duda, elevará la temperatura del debate político en Europa, donde debe pasar el filtro de los gobiernos nacionales, lo que no será fácil dadas sus enormes implicaciones. La aprobación de la normativa requerirá presumiblemente el visto bueno de los Estados miembros y del Parlamento Europeo, lo que sin duda podría resultar complejo desde el doble plano político y jurídico , explica a EXPANSIÓN Alfonso Gutiérrez, abogado de Uría Menéndez.

La Comisión Europea solo puede actuar ahora cuando detecta indicios claros de abuso de posición dominante y aplicar sanciones a posteriori que, aunque multimillonarias en muchos casos (ver información adjunta), no disuaden a las grandes multinacionales. La nueva legislación le permitiría anticiparse, irrumpir en un sector en su conjunto e impedir que evolucione hacia la concentración; es decir, actuar con carácter profiláctico, antes de que se cometa ninguna infracción. ¿Recuerdan la película Minority Report, en la que una unidad policial del futuro próximo evitaba los delitos antes de que se cometieran? Salvando las distancias cinematográficas, Vestager aspira a algo similar pero trasladado a la competencia en el ámbito empresarial.

Si se aprueba la futura normativa, la Comisión Europea podría intervenir preventivamente en mercados que considere que se encaminan hacia una situación de competencia reducida, sin necesidad de constatar una infracción previa y pudiendo imponer obligaciones de desinversión o de acceso a datos y tecnologías , señala Gutiérrez. Es decir, un escenario que provocaría un vuelco sin precedentes en la legislación antimonopolio europea, confiriendo poderes de intervención inusitados a las autoridades de Competencia.

En el punto de mira

Aunque la iniciativa no se circunscribe a un sector en concreto, sino que facultaría a la Comisión a actuar en cualquier área de actividad, desde el comercio al turismo, pasando por la industria farmacéutica, donde Bruselas ha puesto ya, de hecho, la lupa en más de una ocasión, todas las miradas están puestas en los gigantes tecnológicos, como Google, Facebook o Amazon, que en los últimos años han ido extendiendo su tentáculos a diferentes ramas de negocio en un sinuoso efecto de mancha de aceite. Pero también en los emergentes, en los gigantes que están por venir.

Google ya irrumpió en el negocio de sistemas de pago, con Google Pay, y a finales del año pasado logró que el Banco de Lituania le concediera una licencia para operar como entidad de dinero electrónico, franqueando una puerta de entrada a Europa para su proyecto de ofrecer servicios financieros: Google Bank. El desembarco de las tecnológicas en el sector financiero se ha convertido en uno de los mayores dolores de cabeza de la banca tradicional.

Uber, tras ser acusada por los taxistas europeos de querer romper el mercado, opera también en sectores tan dispares como el de comida a domicilio o la salud, mientras que Amazon, que comenzó su trayectoria como una simple librería online, es hoy un gigante del comercio electrónico, ofrece servicios de almacenamiento en la nube (cloud computing), y compite con gigantes como Netflix en el negocio del vídeo online.

El espejo británico

La nueva legislación, que se encuentra aún en fase incipiente, recibe en parte su inspiración del Reino Unido, donde la poderosa Autoridad de la Competencia y los Mercados británica (CMA, por sus siglas en inglés) tiene licencia para abordar investigaciones en sectores completos e imponer severas condiciones, entre las que figura la obligación de desprenderse de activos y negocios si estima que existe un alto grado de concentración.

En 2013, las autoridades británicas de Competencia irrumpieron en el sector sanitario y obligaron a los dos mayores grupos hospitalarios privados presentes en el país, HCA y BMI, a desprenderse de casi una decena de hospitales, llegando incluso a restringir los incentivos a los médicos para evitar que desviasen pacientes hacia un determinado centro sanitario.

En plena era del coronavirus y el Brexit, las autoridades británicas quieren ampliar aún más sus ya de por sí extensas prerrogativas con la lupa puesta en la big tech estadounidenses.

El regulador británico busca reforzar su poder para imponer multas a las compañías que realizan prácticas anticompetitivas sin pasar por los tribunales, garantía que se exige actualmente, y para poder suspender cautelarmente dichas actividades aunque la investigación no haya concluido. Un endurecimiento de su labor de supervisión y control que persigue pese a las advertencias de que ese hostigamiento contra los gigantes digitales podría lastrar la llegada de inversión tecnológica al Reino Unido tras el Brexit.

El caso de Amazon y Deliveroo resulta ilustrativo del modus operandi del regulador británico. En diciembre pasado, la CMA puso en cuarentena la entrada de Amazon en el capital de la plataforma de reparto de comida a domicilio, que se había producido en mayo, por considerar que daría lugar a una situación relevante de fusión, lo que, a su vez, podría acarrear una diminución sustancial de la competencia en cualquier mercado o mercados de bienes o servicios en el Reino Unido. Es decir, la autoridad británica optó por poner la venda antes de la herida. Paradójicamente, la CMA decidió en abril pasado dar luz verde provisional al desembarco de Amazon en Deliveroo para evitar la quiebra de esta última a raíz de la crisis del coronavirus, que amenaza con provocar la asfixia financiera de cientos de miles de empresas europeas. El regulador argumentó que la salida de Deliveroo del mercado británico sería peor para la competencia que permitir la inversión de Amazon , lo que finalmente inclinó la balanza del lado de la autorización.

La iniciativa de Vestager se produce en plena pandemia del Covid-19, que ha puesto en jaque conceptos que eran indiscutibles hasta hace apenas unos meses, como la globalización o el libre mercado, haciendo soplar aires de proteccionismo en la UE y de intervención sin precedentes del sector público en el privado al dar luz verde a inyecciones generalizadas de los Estados en sus empresas para evitar quiebras. Una operación de salvamento masiva que, tal como reconoce la propia Vestager, puede provocar la fractura del mercado único.

De momento, ya ha provocado los primeros roces entre las autoridades europeas de Competencia y algunos Estados miembros, a cuenta, por ejemplo, de las ayudas de 9.000 millones de Alemania a Lufthansa. Para acceder a ellas, Bruselas obliga a la aerolínea a renunciar a sus hub en los aeropuertos de Fráncfort y Múnich.

Margrethe Vestager, vicepresidenta de la Comisión Europea y responsable de Competencia en el Ejecutivo comunitario.

urn:contentItem:5X1K-4PP1-DYTY-C2W1-00000-00Brussels couldn't be more serious about taking on US Big Tech2019-09-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 39Brussels couldn't be more serious about taking on US Big TechSimon Duke

On Monday, the attorneysgeneral of 50 American states did an extraordinary thing: they attacked one of the nation's most successful companies. Ken Paxton, Texas's top law officer, said he had seen evidence that Google violated competition rules. Thanks to its huge trove of personal information, it "undermined consumer choice, stifled innovation [and] violated users' privacy".

Their investigation marks a sea change in America's oversight of its technology industry. In 2013, the Federal Trade Commission investigated Google for potential breaches of antitrust law, but took no action. However, times have changed. Public anger over privacy violations, tax dodging and disinformation has turned the industry from a prodigal child into a pariah. In July, Facebook was fined $5 billion by the commission over the Cambridge Analytica scandal and there are inquiries into Big Tech at state and federal level. A day of reckoning seems to be approaching, even if US politicians are unsure how to tame their buccaneering companies.

The crackdown in the United States is no isolated event. Washington is taking its lead from the European Commission, which has become the most potent regulator of the technology industry, setting standards that others are adopting. Margrethe Vestager, appointed to another five-year term as the competition commissioner yesterday, has been Big Tech's tormentor-in-chief. Since 2017, she has fined Google more than (EURO)8 billion for abusing its dominance in online search, mobile phone software and online advertising.

Before that, she ordered Apple to pay Ireland (EURO)13 billion in back taxes. Apple and Google are www.appealing.No wonder Ms Vestager has earned the displeasure of President Trump. In June he tweeted that she "hates the United States perhaps more than anyone I've ever met". Expect more fireworks during her term as Europe''s antitrust enforcer. Ms Vestager has been made de facto "tech czar", with powers to write the rules for the European Union's digital economy, as well as to implement them.

Her elevation is a tacit acknowledgment that the present regulatory has failed. For all the acclaim she has won for her attempts to rein in Silicon Valley, Google, Facebook, Amazon and Apple retain their strangleholds over large portions of the internet economy. Alphabet, Google's parent, has added a new reporting line to financial results called European Commission Fines. It suggests that to the $840 billion goliath financial penalties are a mere business expense, an unavoidable cost of doing business in Europe.

In the past Facebook, YouTube and other "free" platforms have been elusive prey for competition watchdogs. How, for example, do you prove that consumers have been harmed when they are not paying for a service? But there are signs that Europe is moving towards a fundamentally different approach to policing Big Tech. Local watchdogs are beginning to take the EU's data privacy laws into account in competition cases. In a landmark decision in February, Germany's cartel office ruled that Facebook had abused its dominant position in social networking to improperly gather data on its users without their consent. Of particular concern was its practice of melding data from third-party apps with information gleaned from Facebook, Whatsapp and Instagram and the tracking of non-users through "like" or "share" buttons. Facebook was ordered to desist, but has won a temporary reprieve while it appeals against the decision.

The monopolists of today derive their power from the industrial scale harvesting of personal information. This digital surveillance will be top of Ms Vestager's list of targets as she designs new rules for Europe's digital economy.

Simon Duke is Technology Business Editor of The Times

urn:contentItem:5X1F-4T51-JCJY-G29Y-00000-00Brussels couldn't be more serious about taking on US Big Tech2019-09-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:25ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:2Brussels couldn't be more serious about taking on US Big TechSimon Duke

On Monday, the attorneys- general of 50 American states did an extraordinary thing: they attacked one of the nation's most successful companies. Ken Paxton, Texas's top law officer, said he had seen evidence that Google violated competition rules. Thanks to its huge trove of personal information, it "undermined consumer choice, stifled innovation [and] violated users' privacy".

Their investigation marks a sea change in America's oversight of its technology industry. In 2013, the Federal Trade Commission investigated Google for potential breaches of antitrust law, but took no action. However, times have changed. Public anger over privacy violations, tax dodging and disinformation has turned the industry from a prodigal child into a pariah. In July, Facebook was fined $5 billion by the commission over the Cambridge Analytica scandal and there are inquiries into Big Tech at state and federal level. A day of reckoning seems to be approaching, even if US politicians are unsure how to tame their buccaneering companies.

The crackdown in the United States is no isolated event. Washington is taking its lead from the European Commission, which has become the most potent regulator of the technology industry, setting standards that others are adopting. Margrethe Vestager, appointed to another five-year term as the competition commissioner yesterday, has been Big Tech's tormentor-in-chief. Since 2017, she has fined Google more than (EURO)8 billion for abusing its dominance in online search, mobile phone software and online advertising. Before that, she ordered Apple to pay Ireland (EURO)13 billion in back taxes. Apple and Google are appealing.

No wonder Ms Vestager has earned the displeasure of President Trump. In June he tweeted that she "hates the United States perhaps more than anyone I've ever met". Expect more fireworks during her term as Europe''s antitrust enforcer. Ms Vestager has been made de facto "tech czar", with powers to write the rules for the European Union's digital economy, as well as to implement them.

Her elevation is a tacit acknowledgment that the present regulatory has failed. For all the acclaim she has won for her attempts to rein in Silicon Valley, Google, Facebook, Amazon and Apple retain their strangleholds over large portions of the internet economy. Alphabet, Google's parent, has added a new reporting line to financial results called European Commission Fines. It suggests that to the $840 billion goliath financial penalties are a mere business expense, an unavoidable cost of doing business in Europe.

In the past Facebook, YouTube and other "free" platforms have been elusive prey for competition watchdogs. How, for example, do you prove that consumers have been harmed when they are not paying for a service? But there are signs that Europe is moving towards a fundamentally different approach to policing Big Tech. Local watchdogs are beginning to take the EU's data privacy laws into account in competition cases.

In a landmark decision in February, Germany's cartel office ruled that Facebook had abused its dominant position in social networking to improperly gather data on its users without their consent. Of particular concern was its practice of melding data from third-party apps with information gleaned from Facebook, WhatsApp and Instagram and the tracking of non-users through "like" or "share" buttons. Facebook was ordered to desist, but has won a temporary reprieve while it appeals against the decision.

The monopolists of today derive their power from the industrial scale harvesting of personal information. This digital surveillance will be top of Ms Vestager's list of targets as she designs new rules for Europe's digital economy.

Simon Duke is Technology Business Editor of The Times

urn:contentItem:5X1K-4PP1-DYTY-C2FT-00000-00Brussels couldn't be more serious about taking on US Big Tech2019-09-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 39Brussels couldn't be more serious about taking on US Big TechSimon Duke

On Monday, the attorneysgeneral of 50 American states did an extraordinary thing: they attacked one of the nation's most successful companies. Ken Paxton, Texas's top law officer, said he had seen evidence that Google violated competition rules. Thanks to its huge trove of personal information, it "undermined consumer choice, stifled innovation [and] violated users' privacy".

Their investigation marks a sea change in America's oversight of its technology industry. In 2013, the Federal Trade Commission investigated Google for potential breaches of antitrust law, but took no action. However, times have changed. Public anger over privacy violations, tax dodging and disinformation has turned the industry from a prodigal child into a pariah. In July, Facebook was fined $5 billion by the commission over the Cambridge Analtyica scandal and there are inquiries into Big Tech at state and federal level. A day of reckoning seems to be approaching, even if US politicians are unsure how to tame their buccaneering companies.

The crackdown in the United States is no isolated event. Washington is taking its lead from the European Commission, which has become the most potent regulator of the technology industry, setting standards that others are adopting. Margrethe Vestager, appointed to another five-year term as the competition commissioner yesterday, has been Big Tech's tormentor-in-chief. Since 2017, she has fined Google more than (EURO)8 billion for abusing its dominance in online search, mobile phone software and online advertising.

Before that, she ordered Apple to pay Ireland (EURO)13 billion in back taxes. Apple and Google are www.appealing.No wonder Ms Vestager has earned the displeasure of President Trump. In June he tweeted that she "hates the United States perhaps more than anyone I've ever met". Expect more fireworks during her term as Europe''s antitrust enforcer. Ms Vestager has been made de facto "tech csar", with powers to write the rules for the European Union's digital economy, as well as to implement them.

Her elevation is a tacit acknowledgement that the present regulatory has failed. For all the acclaim she has won for her attempts to rein in Silicon Valley, Google, Facebook, Amazon and Apple retain their strangleholds over large portions of the internet economy. Alphabet, Google's parent, has added a new reporting line to financial results called European Commission Fines. It suggests that to the $840 billion goliath financial penalties are a mere business expense, an unavoidable cost of doing business in Europe.

In the past Facebook, YouTube and other "free" platforms have been elusive prey for competition watchdogs. How, for example, do you prove that consumers have been harmed when they are not paying for a service? But there are signs that Europe is moving towards a fundamentally different approach to policing Big Tech. Local watchdogs are beginning to take the EU's data privacy laws into account in competition cases. In a landmark decision in February, Germany's cartel office ruled that Facebook had abused its dominant position in social networking to improperly gather data on its users without their consent. Of particular concern was its practice of melding data from third-party apps with information gleaned from Facebook, Whatsapp and Instagram and the tracking of non-users through through "like" or "share" buttons. Facebook was ordered to desist, but has won a temporary reprieve while it appeals against the decision.

The monopolists of today derive their power from the industrial scale harvesting of personal information. This digital surveillance will be top of Ms Vestager's list of targets as she designs new rules for Europe's digital economy.

Brussels has defended the lack of blockbuster fines for big technology groups under the EU’s tough privacy laws and urged European regulators to find other ways to sanction companies breaking its data rules. 

Reviewing the first year of its General Data Protection Regulation, the European Commission said it was unconcerned by the absence of big sanctions for tech companies breaching privacy rules. 

“National data-protection authorities have adopted a balanced approach to enforcement powers,” said the commission. “They have focused on dialogue rather than sanctions, in particular for the smallest operators which do not process personal data as a core activity.” 

Under the GDPR, the EU’s 28 national regulators have the power to sanction companies as much as 4 per cent of their annual revenues or €20m — whichever is the larger — for failing to comply with rules that force them to disclose to users what data are held about them and to make clear what purposes the information serves. 

Vera Jourova, the EU’s commissioner for justice, has called the GDPR a “loaded gun” for regulators to pursue privacy breaches and protect the fundamental rights of EU citizens in the wake of scandals such as the data leak from Cambridge Analytica. 

So far, the largest fine has been administered by France’s data protection authority, which hit Google with a €50m sanction for failing to provide its users with enough information about how it processes their data. 

Google’s fine is by far the largest since the GDPR was implemented last May and raised questions about the resources that data protection regulators have to pursue high-profile legal cases against tech giants. 

Ireland’s regulator has come under particular scrutiny because it oversees companies such as Apple and Facebook. They are registered in the country and the regulator has yet to administer any fines. 

Brussels noted that the Irish data protection office had opened 15 investigations into international companies under the GDPR.

“The success of the regulation should not be measured by the number of fines imposed, but by changes in the culture and behaviour of all actors involved,” said the commission.

Instead of using sanctions powers, the EU urged regulators to use other tools in the GDPR, such as ordering temporary bans on the processing of data by companies.

EU officials noted that the lack of high-profile fines was a result of authorities wanting to put together legally watertight cases against companies or risk being taken to court. 

“It is essential that data protection authorities gather relevant evidence, respect all procedural steps under national legislation and ensure due process in often complex files,” the commission said. “This requires time and involves a significant amount of work, which explains why most of the investigations launched after the entry into application of the regulation are still ongoing.”
